reviewText:
First off, let's talk about the cons. It's easy to praise and speak highly of something, but to give a fair and honest overview is another thing entirely.

The leader choice, although not particulary very important, is limited. Seeing the same couple faces every game is a bit of a letdown, but not a real detriment. The look and feel also is very similar to Civ 5. It feels like a glorified reskin when it comes to the basic look of the game.

On a neutral standpoint, the game is also very challenging. If you are coming here from Civ 5, prepare to be overwhelmed. Though I personally find this to be a good thing. A high skill ceiling means it will keep you entertained for many many hours to come.

Now, onto the sugary bits. The most shining thing this game offers is its customization. It's as if they took Civs system, stripped it down to the bare bones, and gave the players the ability to customize their Civ to the T. You can be a focused empire or a hybrid empire and it is quite effective. The tech tree is overwhelming, but golden and offers so much creative freedom. Every game you will pick and choose the flavor of techs that matches your situation best. Mix and match to achieve what you deem worthy as the perfect Civ.

Some say this should have been a Civ 5 expansion. I disagree. It has it's own standalone atmosphere, and offers one of the most flexible and robust tech trees i've ever seen in a 4x (And I'm a huge Endless Legend/Space fanboy). The music is also delicious, and the game flows very smoothly.

I highly recommend this game. It will be a gem for years to come.
voteText: 154 of 253 people (61%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A B- game from a AAA publisher. It's like a bad Civ 5 mod. There is no polish to this game. Building the wonders is unspiring. All the voice acting is done by one person regardless of who the quote comes from.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. YOU WILL BE SEVERELY DISAPPOINTED. I AM VERY SAD I SPENT ANY MONEY ON THIS.

INTERFACE

The interface is extremely lackluster, with very poor choices about how to navigate through menus. Even the menu design itself looks boring. All the icons are flat puesdo-gray scale images that would look better on a mobile app than in a AAA game. The trade route interface does not sort to maximize by science, energy, food, or production (as it did in Civ 5) and every 15 turns you have to renew each trade route, which becomes a huge time waste when you have 4 trade routes per city in the mid to late game. Trying to send people through the earth domination gate requires you to send military units one at a time for ~20 turns or so. This is a super frustrating experience.

This bad UI is pervasive throughout the game. If you highlight the technologies based on a certain type, you can't select anything else but the ones you've filtered by, so you have to go back and unclick it.

Moving a spy around requires multiple clicks through submenus when it should just be a single one.

The workers seem much, much stupider than the ones in Civ 5. I've seen them get stuck multiple times while multiples are automated near each other, and they will bankrupt you with the -6 maintence improvement if you don't watch them. They also don't proiritize maglevs at all, which are just railroads from Civ 5.

Satilletes
This is probably one of the most interesting, and equally dispapointing parts of the game. The satilletes come so late in the technology tree, and have such limited effects, that there are no interesting choices in boosting your production with them. You also can't stack them in any way.

Combat
The combat is actually less interesting than in Civ 5 which is pretty painful. I don't know how you take a step back here. There are less units, and you can only upgrade them by researching one of the three foundational systems, and then you upgrade all of them exactly the same way.

Research
The web tech tree is definitely a better setup than the linear one from Civ 5, but because of the three paradigms, it's much less expansive than it looks, you're virtually forced to pickup useless technologies because they happen to have a paradigm increase on them, which is super frustrating.

MISC

Wonders have no visible improvement on the city. Energy and health are just money and happiness. The three paradigms of Adaptation, Purity, and Improvement are super boring. There's nothing interesting about them compared to the society alignments of Alpha Centarui.

reviewText:
I want so very badly to recomend this game, I dearly love the franchise and think firaxis is among the best studios out there today. However, this game just doesn't live up to the hype or the reputation that they have worked so hard to build.

Where to begin with this game. I think the most obvious and perhaps worst aspect of this release is that it is such a thinly veiled clone of Civ 5. I feel ripped off paying $50 for what amounts to little more than a reskinned game from 2010 with a cool intro video. Sure, its fairly pretty, but its so unbelievably dull. I'm baffled that with a concept as fantastic and well-loved by fans they couldn't think up anything even slightly more engaging. There's no wonder videos (static pictures only), no dynamic cities that show the buildings they contain (already done for Civ IV), no interesting AAA voice acting for the tech tree, and paltry number of playable civilizations that differentiate the game exactly not at all. Unit design is also absent, with a very linear affinity-based upgrade system that is extremely unsatisfying next to the fully custom unit design system in Alpha Centauri, which made unit design a combination of economic, technological, and strategic considerations. While trade routes are a cool and immersive idea, they are done so poorly here that I wish they weren't included. Having to reassign these units every few turns makes my blood boil.

reviewText:
Civ 5 - 236 hours played on steam (probably more like 300 if including off-line play)
Civ BE - 33 hours (been 4 weeks since I last played it.)

It's not a terrible game on its own, but after playing Civ 5 w/ all their factions, special units and buildings and unique faction perks it honestly kind of feels like im playing a civ game made for a cell phone. I loved this game when it came out... I played it for probably 20 hours in the first week alone, but for me, the replayability of the game was just not there. (one of the greatest achievements of civ5 imo)

There are no factions like in civ 5... just starting perks you can choose.
There are no special units that only you can get because of your chosen starting perks... Every player can get EVERY unit w/ the required research and resources. There are the 3 branches of tech which kind of makes the appearance of race/faction... but I think this system is just a few steps down from Civ 5.
There is alien life!!! But they are simply barbarians ie: unintelligent cattle with chitinous armor, sharp teeth and the occasional acid spitter.
There is no challenge!!! Even with the difficulty on higher diff's it is extremely easy to maintain peaceful relations with every other NPC faction on the planet for the duration of the entire game.

I could go on, but its basically a list of things I would have wanted to see or things done differently.


My bottom line is:
It just gets boring really quick, and after a handful of games (33 hours played), I find little reason to launch the game again, which in my opinion is the polar opposite of the last couple civ games (sorry didn't play very much of the earlier civs so I can't comment on those)

The next time I feel an urge to play a civ game, I will probably be launching Civ 5 rather than Civ BE.
It's not that Civ BE is a horrible game, It just doesn't come close to being as good as Civ 5, which to me was a huge letdown.

reviewText:
Feels like a cash grab tbh. Not worth $50 at all IMO. Plain and simple, the game is boring.

-No matchmaking or anything so you have to play against AI which really isn't that well done. I'm not sure what the devs really expected here... I can't see anyone playing against the one(?) difficulty AI for all that long. If this game had some sort of matchmaking it might be a bit more replayable but the archaic lobby system doesn't offer much in terms of a PvP experience.

-No real attempt to immerse you in the game. Textures, audio, cutscenes, are all average at best. Experience just feels stale and unimportant.

-Going back to my first point there's no real campaign and overall there's just a lack of content and things to do. The quests" are all shallow and unfun. You're basically playing the same game over and over again against inadequate AI.

-Little bits of innovation here and there that really don't do much to enhance the experience. It's not quite a Civ 5 reskin but what it does try to do doesn't really accomplish anything.

-As far as strategy goes there really isn't any. Just a bunch of meaningless choices. They try to make the game seem "complex" but if you can see through the abitrary number crunching and superflous tech trees then you realize the game is relatively simple and rigid.

Overall just feels like a game that knew it could ride on the name it had already made for itself. Clearly the devs weren't very interested in making this title and it showed. Really just a lack of effort IMO. The game isn't completely terrible but it really isn't worth the $50 and you can find much better games for much less. Save your money

reviewText:
Rather disappointed, but I did let my expectations get too high. Just played a game with Vostok (medium) difficulty .

Pros:
- I rather like the unit system. Upgrading the units with affinity levels creates immersion. With a little bit more love it would be great addition.
- Quests and victory conditions are a good innovation. I like the way you progress through them in several steps.
- Strategic resources. I find the affinity related resources a good idea. Creates some strategic levels for the game.
- Wildlife feels immersive.
- Affinities. Although the factions are bland, the affinities are not.

Cons:
- Game is short. Just finished the first one in 10 hours. Thats bad for a civ game.
- Wildlife is too weak. By midgame you just overrun them with no consequences attached. Don't know if this one scales up by difficulty levels.
- The AI doesn't seem to mind you winning the game. It would be great if by the time you start progressing in the victory conditions, the AI would react in some way. This feels like a lost opportunity to create more content to this game. Perhaps something that was cut off to make the deadline?
- There is no city specialization. Not even on the level of Civ V. You just build everything everywhere. This makes for a bad strategy game.
- Contact victory seems to be too easy.

Grade for the current state game with the pricetag of 50 euros observed: 7-

I had a nice (second) game of Warlock 2 going on, which I plan to return to. CIV: BE can wait for the huge content patch or DLC. And I will be very wary of paying the full price for that. The DLC content notes will be read with a magnifying glass and I will still wait for the early adopters to rate it.

reviewText:
As it is now I cannot recommend it. After playing the game for about 11 hours I grew tired of a Covert Ops bug (where you cannot redeploy your agents, and this is a known bug since October and hasn't been fixed up to now.) There is also a lot of unneeded micromanagement that is simply driving me crazy. Having to reassign my trade routes (to the same route they were already doing even..) every so many turns and that for every single trade route. Also having to redeploy my satellites to the same positions every so many turns. And having to build the same type of buildings in every city every time and time again.

The game is really lacking some proper macro management tools like:
-Auto redeploy trade route check mark.
-Queues for city builds (set up your own preferred queues and let the city follow one of your setups) or even a mayor who can auto build the things for you.
-An option do auto replace a satellite when the old one comes down or even some option to relift it higher in orbit at a cost.
-An option for your workers to upgrade all your roads. (Instead of having to do that manually.)

I'm also missing some chances they had to make it more fun, perhaps some real terraforming where you can change the actual terrain, lower it, raise it and so on.

Basically the game is a lot of fun, but it could be so much better, but with all the unneeded micromanagement there is now it's simply not my type of game. I will probably pick it up again though after a few patches and perhaps some dlcs if those bring the game to a more complete package like civilization.

reviewText:
Disappointment.. .. .. .. ..  Has already been said, and I second this, but Civilization Beyond Earth is basically 'an extension of/to Civ V. . . .  Civ Beyond Earth could have easily been a simple $20 MOD to patch Civ V!  Why is it so tough to find corrective patches to the gameplay of Civ Beyond Earth......  Having purchased and downloaded the game through STEAM, I am not sure that the issues I am having are related to missing input through the online download - as apposed to having a physical PC CD copy. . . . . . . .  Every time I have run and attempted to play Civ Beyond Earth ((Which has completely ruined any excitement I once had to play it)) the land masses are spattered in a rainbow-like pattern as if it were meant to be looked upon with 3D glasses....  Another hindrance in playing the game for more than 2 friggin' turns is that all of the sudden the 'Next Turn' button does not work.... Click - Click - Click - CLICK of the mouse button to function THAT option. . . . . . . .

Have to turn the game off and re-run it for it to work........  But this continuously happens...  And I cannot find a patch for these issues!!  As for Civ Beyond Earth, If somehow I am able to play it for more than 2turns the only enjoyment I expect to glean from this is my own Sci-Fi minded personality which will allow me to find other enjoyments of this game beyond its dated game play!  There is nothing futuristic about this game, isn't it 2014/15.......  There are games like WOW or even Call of Duty which depict fantasy worlds and are FAR MORE Graphically detailed; isn’t that the point of PC gaming that there are more components to assist with and providing in delivering an Avatar world like landmasses…????!!!  Civ Beyond Earth is very Cartoon-like, and maybe I feel this way because of my current rainbow-3D like lands, what is this a 5bit game – Nintendo gaming provided a more well-thought out detailed graphics experience than this current Civ game!
I have always felt it would be cool if from Civilization V, that once a player reached modern times in the gameplay that the Civ world would be invaded by Aliens that each country would have to thwart off the alien foes ~ or something to that affect.   I mean, the intro to Civ Beyond Earth makes you believe that you start out on Earth in a depleted state, as to the reason for humans needing/wanting to leave Earth…  I thought that you would get to choose where in the galaxy, you the player, would be able to determine where to explore.  So, you start the game already on some planet….

Have played the Civilization Games for years now…  Anticipated THIS game and it was a fail.  Tres disappointed!

reviewText:
So I'm 7 hours in and I can already tell you what this game is worth to me. Honestly I really don't want to say this but a lot of those who said that this should be a paid scenario for Civ 5 are 100% correct. This game is essentially just a reskinned civ 5 with a few added gimmicks (tech web doesn't count, all thats changed on that front is its no longer a linear path from left to right) and some minor changes here and there.

So lets begin with my first irk, the factions. Normally in a civ game you'd have all the historical factions from every era like the Romans, French, Vikings etc with their own unique bonuses, units and city layouts. Well that's certainly not the case here with Civ Beyond earth. For example you have the Slavic Federation and the ARC (American Reclamation Corporation), now you'd expect the buildings and units to look like futuristic Russians and Americans right?, well you'd be entirely wrong there. All units are exactly the same with no visual difference (even the special upgraded units are the same for each faction) or stat changes from start to finish, making the experience of choosing a faction completely pointless as they are exactly the same.

What makes this even worse is that during the custom game set up screen you are literally given the faction logo and a paragraph of text to help you decide the faction you want to play as, but seeing as they're all the same anyway there isn't any point in deciding a faction beyond choosing the one with the name that you like.

The only true addition to this game is the affinity system with its three selections to choose from. The latter being Harmony which allows you to acquire alien units, Supremacy which turns you into a robotic cyborg race and Purity which gives the middle finger to everything non human. This is where all the visual changes take place and the higher you go up an affinity the more your faction changes, but that is also pointless as all the factions are the same anyway and will always have the same units as you meaning choosing an affinity is purely a cosmetic choice.

The aliens themselves do add a bit more of a challenge as opposed to the barbarians of old, being more of a mini faction that you have to deal with and will become stronger the more you play. But even they are just as easily dealt with just like the barbarians as you can simply put up force field barriers that repel all aliens, regardless of strength, from as early as turn freakin 50. One of the most reported strongest aliens during the early game stage, the seige worm, was easily dealt with as I simply put up barriers in all of my cities and had them shoot at the worm until it was dead, and all it did was move back and forth trying to get to my units just behind the force field, making what I thought was a terrifying enemy into more of a simple pest that is just as easily swatted away as the barbarians.

Honestly I could go on but right now I'm too tired from all the bland dullness that this game is emanating so I'll just wrap this up with a final verdict. Don't buy this and just stick with Civ 5, wait for mods to come out and for the price to drop before even thinking of buying this. Whilst it's not a game that's on par with horrible games like Big Rigs or Air Control, it's so incredibily dull and bland that you'd be better off playing those games instead, just so you don't end up falling asleep after only 200 turns.


So with all that the final score is:
5/10

Come back in a month or two when all them smart modders make this game worth £30

P.s Might write a full review once I play a bit more (god help me on that one) and post it on youtube so this score isn't final for me.

reviewText:
As has been stated by many others: This game is NOT the spirtual succesor to Alpha Centaruai. It's basically a mega mod for Civ V.

Had this been a $25-30 title and advertised as a modified Civ V then I wouldn't feel so robbed by it. As it stands I'm just really, really disapointed.

I see a lot of people hoping that this game might get better with future expansion packs but I have my doubts. The core game is a stripped down Civ V experience. In order to make this game stand on it's own they would need to introduce some very unique game mechanics to capture the feeling of taming an alien planet. One would think said mechanics would be in the launch title, right? So if they didn't bother with getting creative at launch why would they get creative down the road with an expansion? Let's face facts, any expansions this game gets are going to be modified versions of GK and BNW.

At this point I'm wondering if Firaxis does not have the capability to give us a successor to Alpha Centauri. You could feel the passion the devs had for AC with each game you played. But this game? This game right here is completly devoid of passion. The world leaders are lifeless and generic. The aliens are Starship Trooper knock offs. And the wonders! Seriously what is with the wonders? In Alpha Centauri you were treated to a full FMV with an epic and long quote from one of the faction leaders. Here? You get a picture of a bland blueprint and a sentence from the same VA that's been reading all the other quotes in the game. Prime example of the total lack of passion and life in this game.

Trying to cash in on the demand for the next Alpha Centauri experience was a pretty low blow from Firaxis. Unless future expansions are simply mind blowing I think I'm done with this one.

reviewText:
If you come in with an expectation of a game at least as deep as Civ V you will be disapointed. The game needs work ... more work than the Civ V needed when it was released.

The quests are a cool idea, the units models are nice and epic but ....

... it has almost no depth, parts seem overpowered (trade routes - you feel like playing as Venice) while others seem pointless (favors - you get them for big chunks of strategic resources and AI will give you a bit of energy in return). Affinities are underdeveloped and underwhelming, your allegiance makes no difference other than other affinity AIs sending you awkward messages, UI is horrendous to the point of obstructing important information, extremely plain and ugly on top. The AIs are rather random, asking for favors a turn before attacking you. Automated workers will either ruin you, waste your precious resources or sometimes just get stuck in a cycle of replacing one upgrade with another. Etc etc ... and that's just after a couple of games.

I hope I really hope I will rewrite the review after a major patch ... or a couple, it just should be so much better than it is. Civ V became a great game but it took a couple of years, I hope BE will not take that long.

reviewText:
I am passionate about turn-based strategies like civilization, master of orion and galactic civilization series. I spent hundreds hours playing all of them. If you have similar taste - DO NOT BUY this game. It is not ready.

Civilization BE is more like civilization 5 DLC, not standalone game. It looks like Firaxis/Sid cheated on you changing planet texture and research tree (stealing idea from endless space, huh?). They added satellite units, outposts, miasma and changed tech tree but, in general, it is civilization 5 with renamed unit/buildings and completely same mechanic. And, frankly, they cut off many nice things civlization 5 has, probably, to sell them as an additional content.

I also personally expected new, modern Alpha Centaura. People who played original game would understand me. But it's not Alpha Centaura. You don't have terraforming or underwater cities here. There is no prototyping. No aliens race. Many things that stuck in my mind for years from my childhood are missed here.

Pros:
+ new civilization look&feel

Cons:
- cut version of civilization
- not even close to original Alpha Centaura
- unjustified very expensive

If you didn't play civilization 5 you might like BE. If you don't see original Alpha Centaura you won't probably miss it. But if you have a choice what to buy civilization 5 or civilization BE - grab civ5, it's much better now. I don't say here that BE is a bad game, no. I say that this game is not ready, it requres a lot of DLCs and your money, of course, to make it a civilization 5 level.

There are many good games I can play and wait for years until they release all DLCs, make complete pack and push it with a good discount. Save your time and money and enjoy playing cool games!

Thank you for reading,
VPSnake

reviewText:
Didn't try Civilzation V? Buy and play Civ V first, by the time you're done this will be cheaper and therefore worthwhile.
Already played Civ V? Get this if you REALLY want to try the Sci-Fi aspects, but you should probably wait for a sale.

Everyone always says Civ 5 is only complete with its expansions. Well, I've never tried the expansions and Vanilla Civ V was better than this game, BY FAR. Of course I'm not expecting a storyline to go with this kind of game, but all the personality was ripped from it, leaving behind a robotic shell.

Sure, it's a decent game, but it's not up to the quality of its predecessors.

NEGATIVES:
This does not look like an AAA game that I paid $50 for. Firaxis apparently didn't learn a damn thing from their vanilla Civ V launch or listen to any complaints about the issues in G&K/BNW.
The AI feels barely functional just like Civ V vanilla's release.
Firaxis showed phenomenal ability to make their own idea as terrible a possible - if with CivV you had to deal with 5 or so TR now you have 3 per city, you have to manually reassign EACH an EVERY of them; why is there no 'automatically continue this trade route' option?!
Diplomacy somehow managed to become even worse than in CivV, which is achievement on its own.
The AI looks to be completely unchanged from Vanilla Civ V, despite the glaring deficiencies that AI had. Much of the text in the game is carried over verbatim from Civ V, such as diplomacy and alien alerts, with just words like gold" substituted for their BE equivalent. Voice acting is extremely limited; take for example the AI condemning you. Now

reviewText:
Civ:BE is a very similar experience to Civ 5, adding very little to better the series and missing many opportunities. I don't think the game is terrible, but it's definitely sub-par in my opinion. The base game is good, but the current content is underwhelming and bland. I will briefly go over all of the new features and changes to the game that improved the experience, and those that hampered it.

The Good
--------------
[Web Tech Tree] Giving players more freedom in their technology choices creates for a much more open experience. The 'late game' technologies are just a few nodes away if a player chooses to go straight (usually not a good idea though). Civ V's linear tech tree was ok, but your options were severely limited and you often ended up with a similiar path each game.

[Espionage] Spying is actually interesting now. Whereas in Civ 5 the espionage system was just a fire and forget kind of system, the new spy system feels much more involved, allowing you to have a lot more control over what you do - from siphoning energy (money) from the enemy capitol or potential overthrowing the city and claiming it for your own. Yes, you can steal cities. I've done so in the past by rushing the technology with the Russian's free tech bonus and it is hilarious.

[Satellites] Not a real complex system, just a nice little addition to the game. Basically you place a stationary unit that affect a grid of tiles under it for X amount of turns.

[Expeditions] Right away your Explorer unit can dig up artifacts from satellites and other things much like an archaeologist from Civ V. This adds a neat extra thing to do early game.

The Bad
--------------
[Technological Progression] The tech tree might have improved its layout, but as a player I felt very detached from the world. I don't even know what I'm researching 90% of the time. What the hell is Alien Ethics? What kind of upgrades can I expect from something like Field Theory or Transcendental Math? Why do I need to research Physics and Engineering? I mean it's so far in the future, shouldn't I already have a really good grasp over those? As I get more and more research, I don't feel any progression. In Civ V it was VERY obvious, as your people went from cavemen to a more civilized and culture people ... but in Beyond Earth it feels so cold and lifeless, nothing I do has any real visual impact on my faction.

[Quests/Decisions] A new system which allows you to make small decisions throughout the game. Do you want +1 Food, or +1 Energy? +5 unit healing or +1 Science and Energy? As well as things like Be nice to the bugs
date: or eradicate them (affects affinities)". These are soon forgotten and very inconsequential. By the time you reach the end of the game
recommended: you'll have more or less forgotten about your choices as they have such an incredibly low impact on the game. This system is good conceptually but was executed in a very boring way.\n\n[Wonders] Unexciting and bland. Even the "you completed the wonder" message is lame

reviewText:
I was hoping to get blown away, but it plays mostly like vanilla CIV5 before Brave New World and feels woefully uninspired and unoriginal overall... so it's basically a re-skin for CIV5 DLC with a lot of the features removed and with worse graphics than CIV5. AI, diplomacy, city management, unit management and function, among other things, are nearly identical, which would not be so terrible if CIV5’s weak points were not copied to a dot as well (yes, including the broken/cheating AI).
The unit customization we were promised is almost comical. Landscape is repetitive. The different factions are virtually identical to each other. Aliens are boring and pretty much pointless except as hindrance at the beginning of the game before you get better tech. City states are just trade posts now with essentially no function and are 99% irrelevant to the gameplay. They did rework espionage nicely though and the orbital units/layer are nice, but not very varied. They could have done a lot more with it!
UI is not great... They should have taken some cues from games by Amplitude Studios when it comes to that… it doesn’t feel like it belongs in 2014 at all. Also what's up with end game? The screen tells me that I won or lost and I’m back at the main menu. No recap, no score breakdown, no map, no ranking, not even a reason WHY I won or lost...
It is at least relatively stable and free of any major bugs based on my experience. Some small bugs and one crash so far after ~14 hours of play. Others have not had such luck however from what I've read?
Having already played games like Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, Pandora First Contact, Endless Space, Galactic Civilizations, Sins of a Solar Empire, and Endless Legend I was really hoping for a lot more (they were not exactly pioneering the genre here), especially with all the hype and promises.
Being a huge fan of the Civilization games and CIV5 I was immensely excited for this game and even pre-purchased it, which I have never done before for any game… and whew! What a letdown. Really tried loving the game, but I just can’t force myself do it. I like it enough, it’s a good start, but it’s entirely unfinished. Would rather just play CIV5 or fire something up by Paradox Interactive. EU4 here I come! BE, sorry, but you were a waste of money. Should have waited for the 75% off sale. It needs the equivalent of what Gods & Kings and Brave New World did to CIV5 ASAP. Never pre-ordering a CIV game again... haha If you haven't bought it yet then just wait for a Steam sale, or similar.

reviewText:
Do you like Civ 5?  Do you like Alpha Centuri?  Good, then you can skip this game.

Beyond Earth is worse than both games in every concievable way.  The UI is exceedingly poor, for example a componant that should be entirely simple to implement like the world map is so tiny and horribly presented that it has been rendered entirely useless.  The information bar at the top of the screen is tiny yet cluttered.  The grid itself is ugly as is the fog of war.  The game itself is just so dark.  It's like being in a room with no windows and the only ligthing coming from an old 30 watt bulb that's been dyed blue (or yellow depending on the map).

What first seemed an interesting twist, the tech web is difficult to navigate and read.  Maybe after you dump 40 hours into the game you'll remember what upgrades are under what leaf and branch, but I grew sick of trying to find where that stupid tech was that let me harvest float stone (or whatever I was looking for at the time).

The game does a really terrible job introducing the new quest mechanics, and at no point did it ever explain victory conditions.

Religions and culture trees have congealed into a bland, overly condensed and boring set of 4 cultural trees you can advance down.

Leaders/states have no personality, aliens are little more than window dressing for each planet, and jeeze what an ugly planets they are.  Do you like blue on blue on blue?  How about puke yellow worlds with oceans of dirty water?  Then boy does Beyond Earth have some property for you!

Beyond Earth has unambiguously poor presentation, and offers nothing mechanically new or interesting over Civ 5, it strips away depth, yet some how it's become more obtuse.  If you're looking to get more out of this current gen of Civ I think you'll be much better served turning to the workshop than spending your money on this poorly designed and ill conceived addition to the franchise.

reviewText:
A competent entry in the Civ franchise but dissapointing overall

This really feels like a mediocre expansion to Civ 5. Despite taking place on a bizarre alien world, the setting feels quite lifeless and dull. The leaders and factions have zero personality. The quotes (that might give some insight into their personalities) are bland and generic and all voiced by the same actor. It's like they took everything that was so flavourful and unique about Alpha Centauri and turned it on its head.

Other than this, the engine is almost identical to civ 5, albeit less polished and balanced. The affinities are an interesting innovation. The AI presented very little challenge (I was able to win my very first game on the 2nd hardest difficulty without much difficulty). The tech tree is diverse and seems to be based on 'Endless Space' to a large extent. However, it's quite hard to learn what each tech does since they all have baffling (albeit generic) sci-tech names like 'gene harmonics' and 'alien splicing'. Again, unlike previous Civ installments the tech advancements provide very little colour to the world.

There isn't much else to say about this game really. If it was a free fan-made mod for Civ 5 I would call it 'impressive'. However, considering how expensive it is it's hard not to feel dissapointed and a bit ripped off. Perhaps I'm holding it to a higher standard than most games since it's part of the Civ franchise but I don't think that's unreasonable. This will be the last time I pre-order from Firaxis and if you haven't ordered yet I recommend you wait till it's on sale before throwing away your money!

reviewText:
Wait until the game is finished.

The game is nice as such, but there are just some really obvious flaws.

Trade routes are ridiculous. In civ5 you could have serious advantages of going for a tall type gameplay with few large cities. This is no longer an option, due to the insane amounts of mfg+food or sci+energy you get from trade routes you just need as many cities as possible. It is not hard to keep up health, which just has to be below 20, even above for a while is fine.
I managed to get a size 1 useless tundra city at 60 base mfg, in size 1! I don't see the point to removing the global limit of trade routes and even so, the issue is that the output should be lowered to 1/4th of what it is now.

The ais are more useless than ever. It may be partly because they don't know how to abuse the trade routes, but it seems silly that even with all the cheats they get in apollo they are still super easy. They have always been quite bad at the civ5 combat system and you have always been able to win over a large force with a few ranged units luring them out, but now you can easily totally overpower them in everything from science to amount of units or whatever you like at the same time.

Since civ1 there has been a linear tech tree that gave you somewhere between 1-8 tech options, usually a lot less than 8. Now you can easily end up having 20+ techs to choose from at one time. I guess this is something you could easily get used to in time and strategies will come up, but what is the point of making it such a grid of messiness? It's just a bit larger than my screen too so I have to move around it on the minimap" to try and get an overview
date: and I am not really wiser on it after 4 games.\n\nHope these things gets fixed in a patch soon and I really think the game shouldn't have been released like that. Just because you have the ability to easily patch things does not mean you should release half finished stuff
recommended: just look at the steam reviews and how fast they are going downwards."

reviewText: I had very high hopes for this game, but it feels like a lot is missing.  Best points - orbital system is very cool, fungal worlds looks really good.  Good points - one unit per hex similar to panzer general, and of course Civ V, different unit looks between factions.  Bland - leaders are all the same in diplomacy.  Bad - affinity level has huge affect on units, I think this was just a poor design decision so save complexity (say versus the actual technologies selected having a direct affect on units, regardless of affinity... I think scrapping the idea of affinity would have forced a more complex game, but adding it in made it easier for the development.  Also bad, trade routs... wtf why did we go from a workable number of routes (in Civ V) to 2-3 PER CITY, its ridiculous, and managing that many is boring at best and annoying at least.  More bad - AI is really stupid.  Several times I've seen the AI leave a low heath unit right next to my counter-unit for an easy kill... or an enemy ranged unit sits right next to my armor (akin to archer moving next to enemy cavalry) DUH... they have no sense of tactics at all.  More bad - buildings are uninsipried, and wonders are worse.  Sadly, worst point - immersion is not there.

reviewText:
Not quite sure where these 9/10 all came from. This game is a poor excuse for a Civilization game. After playing through it for a good number of rounds, I find myself mostly clicking for trade routes, an AI that is as arbitary as it is stupid and a game which feels incomplete.

There is limited stats in game, there are *no* end of game stats and the information that you get presented during the game is a scratch of what you would expect based on previous Civilization games.

Firaxis have a lot of work to do to bring this games feature set into something that might resemble a finished product.

reviewText:
I'm sorry. I did read the negative reviews. Then I played the demo. Then I bought it anyway. I've now played 2 campaigns.

This is my first ever review on Steam. It is there to protect people who have a limited budget from wasting a purchase on this. (I have more money than sense)

I'm such an idiot. The game is seriously lacking. It has no charm and is beyond pointless. It is little more than a bad DLC for Civ 5. There is lots of stuff in the civilopedia which you basically have no reason to ever read.

1) There are 5 strategic resources and I still have no idea what 2 of them do.
2) There are 6 real units (plus 1 or 2 extras). Basically, marines, tanks, ranged tanks, ranged marines, ship, plane (yes 1 ship. 1 plane - there is a carrier to move your planes around but it does nothing else so it's not really a ship). You don't really ever need tanks AND marines (either/or) so you just need 2 units. Period.
3) Units upgrade constantly and  do so because you change affinity level (which it is tricky to consciously control in any satisfying way - think of it like leveling up in an RPG, i.e. you are generally always trying to do it). That means you have no control over strategy because you may have 6 useless units and then the next turn all 6 are suddenly brilliant.
4) But you can't conquer anyway. Because happiness has been replaced with health and is incredibly restrictive over how many cities you or the AI can control at any one time (think 2/3 initially, 5 by mid game, 8/10 by late game if you put a lot of effort in). So in one play through I did 8 players on a 6 player map and 1/4 was still empty by the end (epic speed circa 400 turns).
5) But you wouldn't want many cities because every city needs 2 trade convoys and ever 25 turns you have to micro manage both convoys (so most turns in mid game are 'unit needs orders' 'trade convoy' click, click, scroll to find 'previous route' click, click 'yes I'm sure' *repeat* x 20 units is a bit boring)
6) I won one and lost one. Losing one everything just stops and you have no warning and had no idea why. Winning one is laborious and boring - construct this 'have I won?' *sigh* 'no' 'construct this next' sort of thing. When you win there is nothing - no cinematic, just a message box.
7) There is literally no depth. In Civ 5 I still sometimes sing the jewish faith jingle to the irritation of my wife. I also still quote CEO Morgon on the ethics of greed etc. etc. This game has nothing. No memorable sounds, no music, no wonder videos, no throne room (yes, I'm old). Nothing. Zilch.
8) Aliens, yes there are now basically barbarians with different units (there are 4 land and 2 sea). But luckily once you realise they only attack if you are within attack range of their nest, you can just ignore them, so they are even less of a challenge than barbarians.

Mostly you sit inside your borders hording useless resources you will never use, improving your cities in exactly the same way and endlessly refreshing trade convoys until one of the players wins and puts everyone out of their misery.

This is a very very bad game. I love turn based strategy, I play hundreds of hours (much to the annoyance of said wife). Unlike the launch of Rome II I don't see how patches will save this. It has no redeeming features.

Sorry, but if you have a limited budget then do not buy. If you are like me you'll buy this anyway. I would say I told you so" but really you will have been punished enough."

reviewText:
Big fan of the Civ series. Played Civ3 Golden Edition for days on end as a kid, and have again with Civ5 BNW.

Gonna be honest here, for all the hype this game got, it is really boring. I understand wanting to have a base to start fresh from on a new game, but this is a really poor start.

The corporations or whatever they are have zero personality or charisma. So from the beginning you're not that excited about starting a new game, because it really doesn't matter who you are, they all feel exactly the same and have nothing to set them apart from each other.

The UI is more futuristic looking, but again not really that aethetically pleasing, and functionality wise, not even close to Civ5 in terms of fluidity.

The terrain is actually really annoying to navigate, especially early game...which is the only time you need to navigate it really. The miasma thing is really irritating (-10 HP to unit, basically on every tile), and to be honest so are the aliens. The aliens are basically barbarians except instead of one or two near a camp, there's like 10 of them, and they just slaughter your units early game. Which isn't even that big of a deal, because each explorer can only excavate one site (ancient ruin), but it makes settling new cities early game really frustrating.

There is no surprises, you know where everyones capital is the second they 'land' on the planet.

The affinity system is interesting, for about 5 minutes. Harmony (get along with aliens) doesn't actually stop the aliens from attacking you, which i thought would be the most interesting point of deviation. Purity (kill aliens) is clearly the best, as its units are the easiest to reach through technologies and the resources needed to get them, and focuses on killing aliens, giving your units an experience/upgrade bonus over other affinities, which is huge becuase they give you a flat 15% damage boost instead of just terrain bonuses or utility.

I don't know man, this game was really disappointing, I hope they still produce some civilzation packs and expansions for Civ 5 because this Beyond Earth is light years away from everything you love about Civ. I hope this review stops people from purchasing the game so they go back to producing new civ's to use in Civ5.

OHHH. One good thing. The ominous space background music and orbital sound effects are really cool when you're smoking weed, other than that, it's impossible to maintain interest in this game.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is much like the previous Civilization 5. You get thrown into a world where you rule a civilization and compete, barter, go to war with and befriend other civilizations on your way to conquer the world. This is a turn based strategy game on a hexagonal grid. When all your units have taken a turn, you let the next civilization have its turn. You start with a home settlement that increases in size over time. With each settlement, you select a unit or facility that will then be complete after X amount of turns. During your turn you'll also pick a technology to research that results in new facilities that can get unlocked to build in your settlements. Its all streamlined so you don't have to hunt for the next city or unit to move, you'll already have them selected.

It looks like plenty of people are complaining that this is too similar of a game to Civilization 5, and they're right. However, it still feels like a good fresh sci-fi version of the game. The previous Civilizations made good use of historic characters, but this game lacks those characters and that personality. They still manage to put in all Earth's nations into this game without any sort of alien races. The real hurdle for me was the game crashing every time after the opening cinematic. That seems to have gotten fixed.

No matter what randomly generated world you play, its a hostile one, full of insect aliens that will oppress you. They spawn from nests, attack your troops, and cities. It can be difficult to even get out of your cities to grow and thrive. The game has a combat edge to it. There are combat troops, both melee and long range that can fight on land, water and air.  The insects are there to grind and train your troops, to give them experience, get them leveled up with selectable perks for each level.  Melee units can only attack the tile next to them, while long ranged can attack up to two tiles away. Each unit has its own movement distance and you can set up a unit to move far away and it will get there over X amount of turns without you having to move it each and every turn.

Each unit has a wide array of commands, move, attack, explore, alert so they wake up if an enemy comes in range, fortify to heal themselves, and more. When you have a combat unit selected and hover your mouse over an enemy, you can see the likely outcome who will do more damage. Its a nice system.

Its not all combat though, there are worker units that will gather resources and build things. Thankfully you can assign a worker to work on his own so you don't need to control him. Explorers can find and mine resources. Colonists can go out and make a new settlement as long as its three tiles away from any other settlement. It is best to have an armed escort go with them, since they aren't meant for combat.

When a new settlement forms, it controls a few tiles around it, making that your territory. As the population grows, so does the radius of tiles. So you can connect your settlements into one big territory. Since its your territory, other civilizations need to ask for your permission to travel freely through it. They will offer you tributes for the rights and you barter back and forth with them to make a deal happen. Do you want energy (currency) each turn for their travel? Do you want rights to travel through their land as well? Do you even trust them to travel through your land? They could be setting up a siege to conquer your settlements.

The civilizations can be both nice and hostile. Some civilizations feel that your rapid expansion near their territory is a cause for concern and they'll warn you to stop. The game keeps track of your promises too. If you say you won't build another settlement, you might risk a war if you do. Then at some point the game will tell you that your promise has been kept and you can build another settlement at your leisure. Some will even warn you that you've slaughtered too many people or insects and you need to stop. Its all a delicate balance.

You can make alliances with countries, ask them if they'll go to war with another civilization. There is a lot of depth here, but some are justifiably unwilling to budge. Just because someone declared war on you doesn't mean one of your allies will help save you. There is a nifty diplomacy tab to see what is going on politically. Who is at war with who and your relationship to other civilizations.

If combat isn't your thing, there are covert ops. You can unlock the ability, build a facility, train your agents by defending your cities from spies that will steal your technology or energy. Then send your agents abroad to other cities and do the same to them. It also becomes a political issue, when agents are found or killed. Do you let it slide or declare war? Its all a way to get around combat. I did find a giant covert ops breaking bug. When an agent was idle, the covert ops panel was just black and empty.

Beyond Earth feels like a race to see who can decimate the other civilizations. A tranquil, relaxing game can turn very stressful when your neighbor picks a fight and declares war. I would say the game lets you play how you want, but like other Civilization games, I felt dragged into war, bullied and unable to stop it. If someone declares ware, you can always make a peace treaty by offering them up resources or things like cities. Yep you can give them your cities, because they'll take them anyway.

Settlements can defend themselves, but they'll soon get overwhelmed. Its really a competition over land. Who controls the most land. Who has the most settlements to generate things. There is a problem though. Sometimes the civilization outgrows its energy consumption. If energy consumption dips below the reserve energy supply, the units will begin to disband one per turn. This balances out the energy consumption, but makes units disappear and leaves you vulnerable. That is the risk you run having a grand civilization.

Sometimes there is not enough food in your cities and it will halt their growth. To compensate, you can unlock trade depots and trade convoys, then set their trade routes between settlements to distribute food, energy and resources.

For those that need goals, the game does have quests, but I found myself ignoring them to do what I wanted. Competing a quest, gives you a choice between two perks. It was always a real toss up. I never felt like any perk offered was that much of a game changer.

The game feels excessive when it comes to frills. There are civilization perk trees, technologies to unlock and even troop upgrades. The upgrades change every troop of that type. You even get to select a permanent perk for that type. The choice and the random worlds make for huge replay value. The excessive frills are useful for marathon games. You'll always have something new to unlock thousands of turns into the game. With different difficulties and different sizes of planets to inhabit, one game could go on forever!

Beyond Earth is still a good game, its just like Civilization 5 and its expansion with a sci-fi twist. I would have appreciated alien races other than insect fodder.

reviewText:
Let's begin with explanation here: I hated Beyond Earth, since it crushed my dreams of SMAC remake. Though I have enjoyed the game, it felt bleak and shallow.

Not anymore.

I was skeptic first when Rising Tide was announced, and had a lot of doubts whether it's going to be worthy expansion. And let me tell you, boy I was wrong.

Rising Tide enhances gameplay significantly. It's definitely worth to buy it, if you already have Beyond Earth. New units, hybrid affinities, floating cities, volcanic planets, new diplomacy, new sponsors. There's a ton of new features that will refresh Beyond Earth's gameplay.

Like in Civilization V, with every new expansion the game becomes more and more complex and fun. Go grab it, you won't regret.

And remember! Space Korea is the Best Korea.

reviewText:
Civ: BE at the time of writing isn't worth the money unless on sale. While the game is good, it's not different enough (yet) from Civilization 5 to warrant purchase in my opinion. I am of the full belief that this game will at some point be a game worthy of individual purchase, and will follow a formula similar to Civ 5, in that it will have very good DLC that make the game considerably better. But, for the time being, unless you've invested 500 or more hours into Civ 5 and desperately want a slightly different Civ feel, I'd recommend sticking to/purchasing Civ 5 and it's DLCS.

I should mention this game, like Civ 5, has a great Workshop community creating mods at an ever increasing rate.

EDIT: The most recent DLC, Rising Tides, does make the game a bit more enjoyable, completely reworking the way diplomacy and war works, as well as adding somewhat mobile floating ocean cities. The DLC is an improvement, but not enough to add more than around 10 hours of gameplay for me.

reviewText:
These reviews don't give this game justice.

First off this is not Alpha Centauri, it never was suppose to be. If you have that expectation you will be disappointed. If you have not played and loved Civilization V in the past, there is a strong chance you will may not like this game. This is a turn based strategy game, which means that this is not for everyone.

Features/Gameplay compared to Civ V:

This game uses the same engine as Civilization V however, there are major differences in gameplay. First and most important: the aliens are not like barbarians in Civ V. Sometimes you leave them alone and they will leave you alone, they have these unofficial terroritories and if you don't go into those areas they usually will not come to you unless somebody has been ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ them off by killing them. Two important aliens are the siege worms (land) and the kraken (sea). It is a huge pain in the ♥♥♥ to kill these things in the beginning to mid game unless you are near a city firing ranged.

Trade routes are available from the start, and who you trade with impacts diplomacy with the AI players. Stations will leave if nobody trades with them.

There are tiles that are infected with Miasma, a poison. Depending on the type of Affinity you choose, you either destroy the Miasma (it hurts you) or spread it (it heals you). Each player chooses their own Affinity so there are inherent conflicts of interest.

Technology is no longer linear, it is now a web. Which means you can go in any direction at any time. As you gain new technologies you gain Affinity points. When you get more points your units globally upgrade instantly.  You can also complete quest and do a few other things to get Affinity points. In order to win certain victories, you have to have a ton of Affinity points. You will NOT get all the technologies in a single game. Mid to end game units are unique to Affinity.

Spies are more important, in my last game I had a coup and took a player's CAPITAL from them, peacefully. (We did not  go to war). You can detonate a dirty bomb in peoples cities ,attract siege worms, steal tech, steal science, steal money etc with spies.

I almost forget the orbital system. You can use these satalites to give you every advantage (economic, military, add/remove  Miasma, counter-intelligence etc)

The victory system is not so sudden. You can tell the progress each player has made toward winning. You will know early on how far ahead/behind you are and if a full scale invasion may be necessary to prevent the leader from beating you. It is easy to stop a player in the final stages from winning if you have the military to do so.

My impression:

This game takes the Civilization series in the right direction. The gameplay changes made are beyond the scope of a mod or expansion pack, this is a NEW game that goes beyond new skins and units. I love the game, it is well made, and definitely worthy of being a civilization" game.

This is a very good guide for people are interested: http://well-of-souls.com/civ/civbe_overview.html




"

reviewText:
Civilization Beyond Earth is yet another mixed offering in a storied franchise that continues to bank on (and make bank from) its name.
The game features a number of system overhauls compared to Civilization V that are largely a mixed bag. The first of these major overhauls is the affinity system which creates a faction system inside of a traditional civilization structure. This system is effectively the evolution of the religion system from earlier civilization games and in theory is powerful and interesting. Unfortunately it isn't implemented in the most interesting way often leaving you to simply level up a faction by researching certain dead end technologies. Once more the system as it supports gaining levels of multiples of these factions at once could potentially make the diplomacy more interesting but in true fashion for the series this opportunity is missed as your AI rivals only care about your most prominent affinity in relation to their most prominent. If you have 9 purity but 10 supremacy you'll no doubt notice the negative effect this will impart when dealing with opponents with 3 purity and 0 of the affinities.
Also new is the shift from the traditional civilization technology tree to a technology web more common in space 4x games. This is largely a positive change though many leaf technologies (dead ends related to another technology) feel underwhelming and only relevant in relation to the affinity system.
The unit upgrade system has been significantly limited and also linked into the affinity system. Experience will only allow your unit a minor attack bonus or an instant heal while certain affinity break levels will result in much more powerful upgrades many of which are familiar from previous upgrade systems. Unfortunately while this system alone may be serviceable with appropriate balancing it contributes to a wide ranging problem in the game: readability. This unit upgrades each result in a unique name most of which are exceedingly bland and non-descriptive (such as phantom, cruiser, etc). This means while in a civilization game you may be able to instantly recognize a musketeer has an advantage on a spearman in Beyond Earth you will spend tons of time trying to figure out just what your opponents units are.
Similar readability problems are plentiful through out the game. City name plates and worker assignment buttons are so huge they can obscure units or a clear view of the resource points of each hex in city assignment. Many button positions are arbitrarily flipper from Civ V with little reason for instance the city inspection close buttons. Most technologies have no clear indicators (such as color coding) suggesting either what element they are focused on or even if elements they unlock are buildings or wonders.
Finally the game suffers from a terrible case of misallocated funds. Rival faction leaders each feature a 3d model with multiple part/texture changes based on affinity and fairly large amount of voice acting. Wonders lack engaging artwork (featuring a pan over generic blue print style drawings of ambiguous mechanical junk) and much of the dialogue with voice acting related to affinity levels, technologies, and wonders seems like it features only one or two voice actors (which of course becomes rather tiring). Once more the writing which is obviously trying for the rather difficult tone of Alpha Centauri falls flat. While Alpha Centauri featured a mix of solid sci-fi tropes most related to the genera were somewhat were familiar with punctuated by brief flights of whimsy to justify a funny aside, Beyond Earth features largely science dumb gobbledygook with repetitive jokes many being recycled in numerous places.

reviewText:
Look it's kinda interesting but it feels like a reskin of Civ 5. Largely could have been done with a mod on it in fact. All the original problems of Civ 5 at the start are there.
-AI is dumb(er), not even to the standard of Current Civ 5 with expansions.
-Trade:  It's ok at the start but most of the time but as it progresses AI ask for rediculous deals or demand rediculous prices
-Final tier units: are not remotely equal to others of tier.
-Tech web: Not nearly diverse enough-could be a lot of improvements on it.
-Victory conditions: Are all basically slightly dif flavours of the same thing and the only option to interfere with people's     victories is war.

It needs a couple expansions that I'm not excited to pay for. Very glad I bought this offsite at half price. Oh and a final nitpick. It's not pretty. Colours just clash.

The good. Trade: Much more important. The Bad: needs better implementation, auto repeat trades things like that.

reviewText: Like most people that loved Civilization 5 I couldn't wait to get my hands on this game. Even though the gameplay trailer showed that it looked very similar to its predecessor I still pre-ordered it. This was a huge mistake. Beyond Earth pales in comparison to 5. They have taken 5, reskinned it and then taken everything that was good about it and thrown it away. I thought the addition of a technology web would add a new feel of variety to the game when all it does is overcomplicate things and confuse the player. The quests that it gives are quite often very buggy and there is no clear goal in sight when you start. I don't think I could be more dissapointed with this terrible game. Don't make the mistake I did, do NOT purchase this game. If you have never played civilizations before then I emplore you to get Civilizations 5 with or without the dlc.

reviewText:
Just won my first marathon game! I wanted to play the most alien thing I could so I played on a Fungal world, played for Transcendance, and set aliens to 'high'. I'll compare the game to Civ 5 rather than AC since I think thats more relevant to those claiming it to be DLC-like.

Pros:
-Game runs smoother than Civ5. Even in late game the game loaded turns faster which may be something to consider if that caused you major grievances on less than awesome machines.
-No happiness. Several things simply got a 'sci-fi' name from Civ5 counterparts, but happiness being replaced with the health system is a very good thing. Large empires in more difficult settings were kind of a silly thing to do in Civ5 so this really opens the game up more.
-Tech tree. Its more complicated than normal research in Civ5 and many of the sub-branches allow you to further your affinity that shape your civ. Its possible to go into mupltiple branches that dont link well early on, or do the opposite and go too far in one branch without getting basics from others that leave you crippled. I think there will be good metagame here.
-Starter perks. Unlike Civ5 where you start as some thugs beating rocks together, BE lets you pick your crew types, spaceship type, and supplies you bring with you that lends to a more custom start up appropriate to a sci-fi setting.
-Esp and Trade are the same and slightly improved from the Civ5 versions that came in DLC. The spys in BE have far more options here that can really hurt your enemies (I let out a thumper that called Alien Siege Wurms in an enemy city) and the amount of trade routes you have running rivals that of Venice without actually playing a 1 city civ.
-Aliens. I started my game with the sensors that locate alien nests, which populate over the largest xeno pools in the game (a resource needed for a heavy Harmony Affinity) so I knew right off if I wanted to re-start the game and where I would first go for my expansions. The alien hordes themselves feel more natural in civ. They basically behave like aggresive animals and I appreciated their AI far more than 'barbarians', even on their most aggresive setting.
-Satalite layer. I didnt get too far into satalites as some affinities might with orbital attacks but these really add new options. Some would populate un-modded areas with lux and strategic resources, another pumped down miasma (a toxic gas thats poisons enemies but heals and gives combat bonus' to Harmony civs), and this giant low orbit squid that pooped more miasma and gave combat bonus' to units down below. Its definately a good addition.
-Late game. The combat in late game gets really fun. All your units get upgraded for free based on your chosen affinity and by the end all your 'rovers' and 'missile rovers' are hovertanks flying across the ocean. The affinity-based units, and mega-units are a huge deal. 1 turn before my MInd Flower finished I had 2 Evolved Xeno Titans (think GDR *10) wreck my enemies earth gateway while shrugging off all the stuff they were throwing at them the whole time; it was a good ending!

Cons:
-NPC identities. The bonus' you get for each civ seem limited. In Civ5 you got more 'things' that defined you. You can definately shape your civ over time the way you want more in BE but by end-game you likely have your main affinity maxed and went on to others and begin to lose your uniqueness. The actual bonus' that are unique to your civ seem so marginal I kinda wonder why they even bothered putting them in. I'd have liked to see more special units/buildings or abilites for each civ that pushed them more in the dirrection of certain affinities.  One civ asked me to declare war on another by the name of their leader alone and without being able to open my diplomacy tab I was just left thinking 'who the heck is that?'. Its not like you had the same issue in Civ5 when someone asked you to kill Washington but... I'm sure I'll get used to it.
-City States, or outposts as they're called. The game dosnt just found cities; it starts them as an 'outpost' early on that developes into a city (which by itself I think is fine). My issue is these random outposts that pop up, never turn into full cities, and pretty much act like city states with even less options. Beyond a few good trade routes, they seem to be completelly irrelevant. NPC civs attack them without issue from the rest of the world, there is no friendship meter with these people. It seems a step in the wrong dirrection and lots of wasted potential.
-No global politics. I know this was added in a DLC, but.. considering how these people are supposed to be futuristic, and instantly connected the moment they pop into the world, I find it wierd that there would be no futuristic council when the story goes: they just left a world that HAD one. AI of NPC civs in BE is slightly better but the global politics and amount of favors we curried from city states made the Civ5 game feel more developed on a global scale.
-No terraforming. I know know, its not AC, and I was honestly too young to even remember much about that game. I do remember the terraforming though which allowing you to + and - land and ocean, and being able to build cities underwater. A 'terraformed' tile improvement is just a really good jungle and you can do some terraforming-type stuff with the new satalites but I was kinda hoping for a little more. Maybe its a limitation with the Civ5 engine, but I still have my fingers crossed some DLC with add this.

All in all I think this is a very good game. I'd give it a 8-8.5 depending on much you <3 sci-fi.  I think I'll have quite a few very good playthroughs with the different affinities but I'm not sure I'll get as much playtime from this as Civ5. If that turns you off maybe wait until its a little cheaper but even at full price I still think its worth it.

reviewText:
This game is...a Civ game.  There's nothing big about it compared to other Civ games.  You can specialize your units in a certain direction based on the decisions you make (making them drastically different) but in the end it really feels like those choices don't necessarily matter.  At the end of the day, you're going to make the decision to go down a tree that you have the resources to go down.

The game makes it seem as though you're going to be colonizing the galaxy, yet all you're doing is colonizing another planet that is just like Earth with some alien biology.  I was hoping for some planet jumping instead of just the same thing skinned as an alien planet with future tech.

If you have previous Civ games, I recommend avoiding this.  There isn't enough change to warrant buying another one.  I made the mistake while it was on sale and somewhat regret it.  The concept was promising, the execution was not unfortunately.

reviewText: Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth? More like Sh*t Meier's Sh*tilization: Beyond a Sh*tty F*cking Game. This is the worst game I have ever played. The fact that it was released at a $50 pricetag is a crime against humanity. Every single aspect is a failure. Boring, lifeless factions. Awful gameplay. You will be confirming trade routes 90% of the time. Combat unit strength feels extremely unbalanced and units become obsolete very quickly. Wonders in this game are nothing more than a joke. I remember there was one late game wonder that took or so 40 turns to complete, and then gave +1 food? No interesting dyamics, and an inconsequential effect. Win conditions are tedious and boring. Want to build 40 of the same unit? I know I don't. But if you do, congratulations, you can now look at this static 'you win' screen, leave the game, and play again! The game is also a graphics hog. Everything lags so much even on the lowest settings on my Asus G75. It's like they forgot to test this game at all. The new mechanics that were introduced, miasma and aliens, are simply nuisances that the player is forced to spend time to remove. It's like, here, we're going to stymie your progress until you buy this unit and get this building. It's not fun, and is absolutely a chore. You know what though? It's worse than a chore. I'd rather get up in the middle of the game and do the dishes than play this game. It's not even a game. It's a scam. It's 0/10 trash appended with the names Sid Meier and Civilization to trick suckers like myself and many others into buying it. I am writing this review to warn you not to be one of those suckers. And what's certain to come next is numerous patches and DLC to milk more money out of the poor souls who were tricked into buying this. Please, never, ever think about playing this game. Avoid supporting this garbage.

reviewText:
At a 0 money price tag (free weekend on Steam) this game has the potential to change your life.

One of the best ways to enjoy it is to install it and then go out and have a drink with your friends. Over time it may improve your social skills, expose you to new and interesting people, and who knows, maybe some of them will share great stories, or present you with incredible business opportunities. Some may become mentors, others may become enemies. You may find passion, love, passionate love... the possibilities are endless.

If you're not that into other people though, you could also install this game and then go out to the park, catch some sun (it's great for your skin and essential to maintain your vitamin D levels), listen to the birds and feel the wind gently caressing your face. You could also hit the gym and work on those flat glutes you got from sitting down all day, every day.

As a third option, if you really prefer being indoors, you can always install Civ:BE and then go watch a movie, read a book, perhaps even study for those finals.

However, if you REALLY want to play a strategy game, then you can install this game and play any other title within the genre, like Duck Hunt.

All things considered, Civ:BE is incredibly diverse and will allow you to explore a whole universe of things to do while you ignore its existence. Installation not required.

reviewText:
Nothing but a big mod for Civilization V. Lacks new innovation, sluggish and boring gameplay. Makes you appreciate the original Civ games much more.

Pros:
- Alien AI's present a better challenge than barbarians had
- Basics for the game are easy to learn if you've played the other Civ games
- Quests present a fun way to extend benefits for your basic buildings and tiles

Cons:
- AI Civs have no personality and quotes are exactly the same as Civ V
- No innovation in new gameplay, techs, buildings, and units
- Units can only be upgraded after you've reached a certain level, and only one class at a time, making your units stale for long periods of time
- Health (Happiness) is very hard to gain, there are no luxuries but about 10 more resources for building
- Aliens are the biggest threat, it's hard to explore water or land without dying in on hit
- Tech system is horrible, that's all there is to it

reviewText:
While visually impressive, this game could use a lot more work in the gameplay department.

After having played Civ I, II, III, IV and various offshoots, it's time to re-think the Civ game and not just churn out yet another iteration of the same old thing. If anything this new version strips away some of the more nuanced elements of Civ V and introduces a lot more busy-work that distracts from what should be the core focus of the game.

Highly disappointing.

reviewText:
I love the Civilization games and have played all of them. This installment feels rushed. It's obviously based on Civilization V and feels more like an add-on than an entirely new game. Unfortunately most of us are paying full price.

The different factions feel generic and even at higher difficulties the AI doesn't really put up a challenge. The trading system feels broken, it's far too easy to generate huge amounts of energy, science and production. The aliens are well done, but they are not more than a hindrance. Somehow the planet feels lifeless...

I regret paying full price for this game. Also, what's up with most gaming sites scoring this an 8 or 9? Even with a few hours of game time the significant problems with balance should be visible.

One month since release, yet they haven't even fixed the most glaring issues with a patch or hotfix, instead they say they are developing a major patch. Well, guess what, you still can't play the game on a >60 Hz monitor in normal resolutions in fullscreen (biggest it let's me select is 1300something to 800something), achievements don't work properly in multiplayer (and multiplayer doesn't run stable at all).

I'm not even gonna comment on the game much here, even though I will say that it feels VERY barebore at this point (only 8 factions, victory types are extremely boring etc), but their release/patching policy is disgraceful! If I hadn't been gifted this game by a friend, I would've already asked for a refund at this point and I can only urge others to actually do it, to send the message that this behaviour from a developer will not be tolerated! I used to like Firaxis, they're one of the few studios, who make games in one of my favourite and under-representated genre (turn-based strategy that is), but this release again only confirms: DON'T BUY THEIR GAMES ANYWHERE NEAR RELEASE!
Pathetic, Firaxis and 2k, shame on you!

reviewText: Good mechanics, good diplomacy, excellent tech tree. But... Lack of buildings, cold feel, and long term games loosing the spark. Why? Because it simply gets repetitive, I feel like there's something missing. I think you shouldn't be able to upgrade troops, instead you should get new ones as the game evolves. If a civilization has one upgrade over you, you will get smashed in combat. Aliens are really painful at the start of the game it happens often that you get completely invaded and can't do anything. And there are no luxuries in the game. I also feel like some items from Civ 5 are drastically missing. Like boats, for example, there are only two main naval units. Also, wonders aren't that important anymore. It feels like building them is pretty much useless. But the main aspect that is missing is population interaction. There is no more religion, it feels like the people are just robots, you hardly notice they exist. As a cherry on the cake, the graphical aspect makes the game feel really cold and lonely. Some people love it, but others, like me find it to be diverting me to other occupations. This game will keep you entertained for some time, but you play a few games and then simply get bored of what it offers, which is my case. 50 hours in and I simply don't feel like clicking play now...

reviewText:
I want to like this game. I loved Civ 5 and for the most part, Beyond Earth plays a lot like it... Which is partially the problem. It plays like Civ 5 with less content and depth.  The new features in the game don't really do enough to make it feel any more than a mod or expansion to Civ 5.

There are only 8 factions to choose from, making it impossible to play with anymore than 8 players, even in singleplayer. You can modify the files to allow 8+ AI in singleplayer but it will only result in duplicate factions, rendering diplomacy confusing and practically unusable.

The UI is a lot less... informative than Civ 5. Many dulled, grey tones . In particular, telling factions apart on the minimap proves quite difficult with many simply appearing grey. The minimap is also way too small to make out any important details and minor feedback features such as trade route caps and just finished building/researching" information are completely absent.

date: this game feels more like an unfinished expansion back or a decent mod than a quality civilization title."

reviewText:
Civilization: Beyond Earth is a very difficult game to summarise.
This is a franchise I have followed for a long time and Civilization V is a game I've spent nearly 500hrs playing. On the one hand it is an extremely enjoyable game and some of the new gameplay systems - the tech web, aliens, enhanced espionage and quests - provide a lot of depth; on the other the game lacks contextual relevance, with technologies, wonders and leaders coming across as rather bland.

This is a game I expect to see develop with the release of content patches and expansions. Obvious areas to overhaul would be the satellite system (which is currently overly gimmicky and tedious), the tech tree (it has variety but it's hard to get a sense of what to research for a balanced game) and sponsors (previously called Civs, they are few in number and extremely shallow). The interface is rather lacking, with buildings and wonders using a monotone colour scheme making it extremely difficult to see at a glance what you're constructing and what you should research.

However, there is a lot that the game gets right. The new expansion system - whereby you must create an outpost and wait for it to expand to become a city - means that you have to be more strategic with your city placement and defence; the quest system allows you to shape the game around your play style; the espionage system allows for capturing cities and requires you to monitor your own cities; wonders are better balanced, as the tech web means players can focus on different areas with less overlap; happiness has been replaced with health and is no longer as punishing, as well as providing rewards for higher amounts.

Those with an open mind and an interest in strategy games will love this. Those extremely attached to previous versions or hoping for a straight remake of Alpha Centauri will be left wanting.

Any true Civ fan owes it to themselves to get this and give it a proper go.
