reviewText:
Over 450 hours. That's how much time I have on Civilization V. So, needless to say: I'm a big fan of the series, especially the predecessor to Beyond Earth. That said, I'm still not fatigued by the game, and I still can go back to Civ V and have a lot of fun on it. So, when Beyond Earth came out I was very excited to see what they'd do now that they're changing the setting to the future rather than the past and present.

I'm going to be blunt: this is a massive letdown. This game is Civilization V if you sucked out all of its soul. This game has absolutely no personality, you don't get any of the old Ghandi and his nukes, or the backstabbing of Napoleon, or the wonder-stealing of Ramses. I've clocked up a good few hours on this game, and the leaders from this game are still yet to show any personality or do anything even remotely memorable.

This is a big problem, as in Civ V: part of what made it fun was the fact that each Civilization had a unique AI, as well as unique abilities. The abilities of those Civilizations would mean that every game would feel different, not only based on the Civilization that you choose: but the AI you're pitted against, your starting location, and sometimes just plain luck would play huge a part in how the game plays out. In Civilization V, each Civilization got its own unique ability, unit, and/or building. But, in Beyond Earth, when you're choosing your Civ, you get one stat boost, and then you pick three more bonuses. These bonuses lack any depth, it's stuff like Get a free worker" or "Reveal minerals on the map" or "+2 culture for every city"

reviewText:
I'm big fan of Civilization series... This game, however, is not worth buying.
I just might not like psychedelic colors but aliens are fun. And there ends the fun.

Tech tree (or rather tech web) is gigantic messy innovation I was never able to navigate through. In contrast with intuitive tech tree from earlier Civilization series... it is just so wrong and annoying... new player in earlier Civilizations is given choice of tech to discover. Not here. Here you have to bother with the whole tech web since first play and first turn.

In Civilization V (and IV) we had upgrades and we could focus these upgrades according to battlefield situation. So we can here, we can heal or add 10% strength bonus... and that's it... a joke...

Cities have tons of structures, and here is a great idea to upgrade structure via quests, but other than that structures are just a mess to remember, just too many buildings...

I could continue but every other game aspect (factions, units, city states...) is similiar: attempt of innovation, alienish look and feel, and definitely messed up.
But everything should be forgiven if the game is fun - IT IS NOT:
First play is just chaotic, there is no joy from discovering alien world and game mechanics,
And there is not much replayability...

The one good thing about Beyond the Earth is that you can finally realize that Civilization V was quite OK.

reviewText: -I wouldn't recommend the game at its current price: $50.00 US and $70.00 US in others.\nI do enjoy the game, and can acknowledge that while it may be named as a spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri, it certainly doesn't look and feel it.  What irks me about Beyond Earth is that several items that were originally in previous Civ titles (city-states, demographics, strategic view, etc.) have been removed. In addition to that, the tech tree feels awfully clunky, making you research the entire tech tree and thus every affinity, ♥♥♥♥ing up whatever affinity you had wanted to choose and stick with (you'll probably finish a game before this happens), while also having everything in the tech tree be the same color, irking me further. In essense, BE is a re-skinned Civ V with the addition of sattelites and subtraction of the things listed above. I'd wait for a sale to buy this baby, but if you love Civ like I do it wouldn't hurt to give it a shot now and see how you like it.

reviewText:
As someone who has put in 800+ hours in Civ V and god knows how much in IV and III, it sucks to admit that I'm pretty dissapointed with CIV:BE. Overall, it's a fun new experience, but doesn't compare to Alpha Centuri and its UI is begging for a patch out of the box.

Summary:

+Affinities are a great expansion to how your units and cities look like.
+Enhanced narrative through sidequests / city state colonies
+Social policies have been put into 4 trees and it works well!
+Harmony affinity / alien units are pretty rad!
+Terrain generation is really cool and has good variety.
+Spying has been improved so you can stage a Coup and snag an entire city if you're successful.

- [~personal] I'm not a fan of how units are perma upgraded now.
- [~personal] CIV:BE feels like it chose visuals over gameplay
- No natural wonder equivalents [ Gimme a badass Volcanoe that gives +8 science!]
- No religion of any kind [ Gimme cyber future religion!]
- UI could use a LOT of color differentiation [ In the Tech Tree I can't tell what's a building and what's a wonder].
- Affinities should function like ideology [Once you pick one you stick with it rather than juggle 3 of them].
- [~personal] Another thing that bogs this title down is the limited expressions and butchered fake voice acting for some leaders (Slavic Federation and Brasilia; Kozlov's voice is just some Berkeley hipster reading off Google Translate with a Russian accent / which is odd because Catharine's voice in V was 100% authentic. )

+/- Trade works the same way as in Civ V, and thats ok I guess.
+/- Diplomacy is exactly the same and thats ok too, I guess
+/- No Nukes / Mass Destruction
+/- No Space Mongolians / Space bandits

At the end of the day, while it does offer a brand new experience, an impressive terrain script and an expanded narrative in the form of quests, I cannot recommend this game in its current state at its current price until it's at least patched and some gameplay elements are significantly improved.

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to this game, it's a shame it's such a let down.

The game feels like it lacks a layer of detail. No advisors, no demographics, no wonder videos. The victory options are all basically the same tech driven ones. There is way too much emphasis on trading. Late game I find myself every turn reconfirming  trade routes. The game just suddenly ended for me with no warning or explanation. I feel like you should have more to do with stations. The AI was attacking a station but you can't threaten or negotiate a cease fire, all stations are good for is a place to send yet another trade vessel. Even just the game UI feels like it lacks detail. No notification of what was just built in a city, or what research was just completed. You don't even see the wonders you built in the city.
The aliens just feel like an easier version of barbarians. They didn't attack me until I hit them.
Maybe this game will be worth it in another year...

reviewText:
Civilization: Beyond Earth is a good game when looked at in isolation. The problem with Civilization: Beyond Earth is that it will be compared in one of two ways by almost anyone who plays it, one of which is a unflattering comparison to a huge degree:


1: Against Alpha Centauri (not really a fair comparison in many ways, but understandable given that this is a sci-fi setting)

2: Against Civilization V (an incredibly fair comparison, since much is reused from Civ V and a majority of players probably owned Civ V before getting Civ:BE).


Now, let's deal with the first comparison: Alpha Centauri came out a long ways ago, pre-dates the game that Civ:BE is based on (Civ V) by a good number of years, and Civ:BE clearly was not going to have the same mechanics as Alpha Centauri. So, what's left to even draw a comparison to? Well, the sci-fi setting. Believe me, there are issues with Civ:BE, as I'll get into, but the comparison with Alpha Centauri is mostly not a fair one. That said, passing mention in interviews with those working on Civ:BE was made that Civ:BE would be a sort of 'spiritual successor' to Alpha Centauri, which may be true in one sense but in another sense was only going to encourage comparisons to AC despite the games being rather unrelated.

But the big, fatal flaw with Civilization: Beyond Earth is that it fails in every conceivable way when compared to Civilization V. First of all, if you own Civ V with all the DLC, then you have the classic 'Civilization Sequel' problem of every Civ sequel having none of the DLC features of the game prior. Even Civ V launched without religion, which, actually now that I think about it, was a standard feature at launch of Civ IV. But what saved sequels in the past was that new mechanics were brought in that couldn't be added in another expansion: in Civ V, we have 1UPT (1 combat unit per turn), among other things, which really changes combat. But then we have Civilization: Beyond Earth, and whether you call it a sequel or a spin-off, it's still the next Civ game to come out. And it does virtually everything Civ V did, with a few minor tweaks, a less-linear tech tree (that still has distinct paths for certain strategies anyways), and way less content.

If you already own Civ V and all its DLC, you have almost everything in Civ V as well as a bunch of things Civ:BE got rid of. Civ:BE eliminated different air-unit types... there's only one air unit now, which has branching upgrades that give you a choice of an ability. That's it. No bombers. No fighters. Just one basic unit. Civ:BE also back-tracked to having no melee naval units. Civ:BE also has no unique music (all music plays for all sponsors). Civ:BE also lacks unique units (no sponsor has any units that the others can't also get). Civ:BE also lacks artistic details for leader screens (very minimalistic  indeed).

Add all that to the already in-grained issue of every new Civ game losing some features from the previous games, and you have a really good game that is virtually identical to the last one that probably a majority of prospective buyers already own.

Even 'new' features are not all that new: aliens are barbarians with a tiered system of aggression... affinities are basically an extension of the tech system since most affinity levels come through teching and not quests...  the tech web itself still plays out in a way where you will bee-line key techs and follow several linear paths. In fact, the tech web most-of-all is a let-down, because it's really just a different-looking tech tree you already saw in Civ V. To be fair, there are fewer pre-requisite techs for bee-lining certain things, but the new lay-out is not as different from Civ V, strategy-wise, as you might first suspect.

In the end, Civ:BE is a really good game... but is one that is likely to irritate its purchasers, as a large chunk will compare it to Alpha Centauri despite the two games being quite different, while an even bigger chunk will look at it and find it to be far less immersive than Civ V and drastically lacking in content *even before factoring in DLCs*. That's right, Civ:BE is one of the first Civ games in a long time that is virtually no better than the vanilla game before it (and Civ V vanilla wasn't even all that good). Which is ironic given that Civ:BE does incorporate some elements from Civ V's expansions (trade-routes, for one).

I can't recommend Civ:BE. It's just too much like Civ V, which with all its DLC is not significantly more expensive than Civ:BE. I can easily recommend getting Civ V, but not Civ:BE. In an alternate universe where Civ V does not exist, maybe then. But the fact is that Civ V exists and does everything better, especially the artisic elements.

Don't get me wrong: I like Civ:BE and will continue to play it. But not nearly like I played Civ V, because Civ V came out first and was a better game right-out-of-the-box in terms of interface and presentation. And even content-wise, Civ V had far more interesting unique elements for the civilizations than we'll probably ever see in Civ:BE.

reviewText:
Right, after fifty hours of gameplay, I'll get straigt to the point with Pros, Cons and Misc notes on this game

Pros:
-Decent Graphics
-Good mechanics
-Good art work
-Great soundtrack
-Nice pallet of units

Cons:
-Needs a bit more content
-Interface needs some work
-AI needs to be a bit better educated and more active and stop porposing crappy deals

Misc:
-No nukes (Wish they explained why)
-Not Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri
-Want to see this universe expand

Notes:

-In my heart, this isn't a Alpha Centauri spiritual successor, it doesn't have the distrubing undertones, infact it is something else, it shows more of a hopeful future for mankind in the stars.

-Seriously people should really look at Civ V pre DLC, it had even less content than BE

-For recommendations about this game... For new to the genre or even the civilizations series, yes I do recommend it, but for us veteran players... Well, wait till there's DLC to beef up this game a bit, though it still can be enjoyable.

reviewText:
This is an enjoyable game if you're already a Civ fanatic, but others are unlikely to enjoy.

The game is very dense, and puts a fair amount of 'burden of knowledge' on players, i.e. the amount of unique information points in the game.

Civilization I-V have this problem as well, but they're able to cheat and alleviate it somewhat because of the fact that the game is based on the real world - I have some intuitive understanding that grassland or plains is better than snow or desert, I understand that a tank is going to beat a horse-mounted knight, I have some grasp on what the Iron or Gold resource might do for my empire, etc.  I know what the farm" tile improvement is for.

Beyond Earth has little of that - one terrain type is visually indistinguishable from another
date: it can be difficult to tell exactly what unit you're facing
recommended: etc.  There is a lot more to take in
hoursPlayed: and it isn't communicated as visually as it could be to the player.  There's a lot of mousing over and reading tool tips and not a lot of knowing at a glance.\n\nThe game is devoid of personality.  Your mileage may vary
voteText: but after sinking a lot of hours into it
helpfulPercent: I just don't see anything endearing in Beyond Earth as compared to Civ V.  The sponsors just aren't memorable
votesHelpful: and don't feel unique.  The flavor text that goes along with the tech tree just doesn't pack the same charm.\n\nThe game isn't well balanced - I was able to jump from the easiest to the most difficult setting (Apollo) with no problem when I realized how easy it was for spies to take an AI capital via coup - domination victory by turn 100 every time.  There are a lot of choices in the game - affinity

reviewText:
I'm not going to lie, after seeing some reviews of this game, and comparing it to Civ V, I was not thrilled by it. But this free weekend has allowed me to experience Beyond Earth for myself, and I was actually quite impressed! My only point, is that this would be better suited as a higher-priced DLC for Civ V, as it runs off of most of the same features.

They have made a lot of improvements to the old Civ V to make it seem quite different, and they have added some completely new features which add to the enjoyability of the game. Sure, it may not be AS GOOD AS Civ V, but we have to wait. Civ V became so much better with the arrival of DLC, especially Brave New World. This game shows so much promise and with DLC it could be loads better than it already is.

Positives:
All of the improvements to Civ V (inc. Tech Web and City States)
New factions to play as and starting bonuses are a nice touch, giving each player the chance to be equal to another, so there are no over-powered factions.
Generally fun gameplay. I enjoyed played single and multiplayer, the features are largely the same as Civ V so I could adapt quickly to understand and enjoy the new features.

Negatives:
The colour scheme. It's so dark and, I suppose, dank. There aren't any vibrant colours which stand out and it makes the game feel glum and morose. I hope a DLC can change the colour scheme, such as Brave New World did for Civ V.

There's no feeling of reward or accomplishment. Just managment rather than fun strategy. I'd prefer going to my job and getting paid to do these things myself.

Beyond Earth feels like it's going to be to the Civ series what Empire was to the Total War series. A dark smudge."

reviewText:
While not a terrible game by any stretch of the imagination, it's just not worth a recommendation when there's better games available somewhere else.

This game is inferior to its predecessor, Civilization V. It's inferior to one of it's major influences, Alpha Centauri. It's inferior to Endless Legend or Endless Space. And it's inferior to many other 4X games that were made with more heart and soul than this space paint-job of an already existing game. Also, as an added bonus, you can probably pick up any given one of those games at a lower price and they'll probably keep you playing for longer than Beyond Earth ever will.

There's just too many other games that are more worthy of your time and money than this.

reviewText:
Was desperately hoping the franchise would learn from CIv V's successes/blunders and improve upon it's playability with this new release...

However, as it currently stands I can't give this game my endorsement.
- the online play is prone to constant crashes.
- demographics are more vague than ever and access to strategic information is lacking, glitchy or non-accessible.
- the trading post (CS equivilant to civ V) is almost pointless. They lack depth, resources and are an in general a nuisance with unchecked faults. [can't declare war on them with a ranged unit to give an example]
- the intrigue from spying is interesting, but I ended up with more spies than cities I could place them in. They only let you place a spy in someone's capital and not their other cities.

This game is new so this is an early review and I just needed to vent my frustrations.

I LOVE Civ V and hope they can raise the bar with this series to an equal if not better level. Until they can fix what looks to be an obvious rush-to-release job with this game I would reccomend waiting.
voteText: 90 of 161 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Essentially a different skin for Civ 5 without expansions, lacking polish and personality. Do not buy.

Due to the way the faction generation and affinity system works, all factions and leaders end up being completely generic, other than the ethnicity of their leaders, which is a lot less interesting than developed characters characterized by their ideologies. Tech-tree falls completely flat as generic baseline sci-fi, lacking the interesting speculation into the development of future technology that was present in Alpha Centauri, and and the combination of the two above factors makes all the tech-quotes completely uninteresting. There aren't even cutscenes for Wonders or Victory conditions. The one saving grace is the quest system, but even that could have been handled better and less predictably (Like the quest system in the Fall from Heaven mod series for Civilization 4).

In the end it just feels like a board-game. If that's what you're after, fair enough, but if you an actually good sci-fi game, go on GOG and get Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri. Or get the Planetfall mod for Civ 4.

reviewText:
Disappointing! - Sid Meier is a guru of strategic depth and balance vs. fun factor. This game does not feel like a Sid game. It feels like a corporate fiasco, rushed to the market, incomplete, overpriced, simplified to allow for more expansions and more dollars. Stay away from it and let's see if Firaxis will have the decency to fix this without a $30 dollar price tag xpack.

Its a step back from Civ V even in simple things like UI and Civilopedia. Mechanics are watered down... Religions are gone, world congress is gone, deep city specialization and great people gone, tall empires - gone.

What's left? A broken, infinite city sprawl only strategy supported by difficult to manage OP trade routes.

Sorry guys, I really wanted to love this, I'm a major fan of Sid Meier and the Civ franchaise, played every game they ever made (anyone remember Railroads!"?)

except this...

Its a sad sad day today.

reviewText:
For anyone totally new to any kind of CIV game who likes sc-fi themes, I can recommend it when it goes on a sale.
It is a very solid complex turn-based strategy game which offers different kind of winning conditions. If you don't read guides and etc, this game will offer you hundreds of hours of fun trying to find out what is best under different circumstances. You progress and keep progressing by learning from your mistakes on different difficulty levels. This stands apart from the sci-fi theme which you can like or, like me, dislike.


However...

Build on the CIV 5 engine and the 100 turns pre-release video you'd expect this game to be CIV 5 in a different theme. A reskined and renamed game. And pretty much that's it! It is easy to relate resources, textures and names back to what they are in CIV 5. Really a somewhat 1:1 copy. I wonder how long it takes before workshop items appear that restores all to what they are called and look like in CIV 5.

As BE is being sold as a stand alone game and not as an expansion package to CIV 5, you'd expect the game to progress in terms of bug fixes, system resource hungryness, gameplay and etc. But no progression on that.
Random events are back from CIV 4 (or was that a mod?) and is the only additional thing. You can choose between two benefitting event options and that is the only gameplay that has been added in comparison to CIV 5. They claim to have worked on the multiplayer part, but it functions just as bad as CIV 5. Resync in turn 1, free techs being given to your opponents...

Sad enough it is build on the same engine as CIV 5, but they removed the dx9 and touchscreen executable. Dx9 offered way less desync issues while playing multiplayer and the touchscreen executable in CIV 5 let you play the game without the game crashing while touching the screen.
On the other hand they added mantle support to improve multicore performance, but hell i prefer a better functional product above mantle or a dx12 low level kind of api support.


Looking further into the game there is some unbalance, unfinished work or too cheap reskinning ruining the gameplay.
Playing on marathon in turn 75 ~ 150 and I have to put my city production to work on energy or research as I already literally build every building that I researched. This is the first time in a CIV game that I can't build anything anymore in a city so early in the game. Ofcourse I can put effort in researching tech so I can build more buildings, but w00t so early in the game and nothing to do.
The cityproduction advisor tells me to build a building which improves the energy (gold for civ 5) output by +1 for each desert tile. But, I don't have a single desert tile anywhere near any of my cities so this building is going to cost me energy for each turn instead?
Than the developpers crafted some awesome tile add-on called miasma (a marsh for civ 5) which gives you negative health for each turn you stand on it. By researching the correct stuff you can regain health when standing on it. A very neath idea, BUT... they did not change the code of the AI players when attacking defending. The AI idles in miasma losing health or attacks you from out miama... If they declare war you can just do totally nothing and wait for them to die in miasma!

They should have made this an expansion to CIV 5, should have worked on the multiplayer desyncs and should have added mantle support to CIV 5 instead of this unlogic split. As a standalone BE is standing in the shade of CIV 5 as it offers less content, more unbalance and the very same bugs that CIV 5 today offers.

reviewText:
I'm going to make this review simple and short.

1. A modder could of done this. You most likely heard it before now you're going to hear it again. The features that the game have added are little and insignificant. They even take some features out like Luxury recourses.

Quest one of the new features. Most are just killing 10 aliens, building some kind of building, getting resource pods or excavations. You get a choice usually when you build a building. All it is a chose of one befit or another. Like +1 Health (Happiness) or 1+ Energy(Gold)

Orbital Layer is nothing but lunching a satellite that you wont see very much over a piece of land with give some kind of benefit in a AOE/AOI (Area of effect, Area of influence). Nothing all that special.

There is only a very small number of units. With only upgrade with your Affinities.

Affinities give bonuses and buffs. These act like you ideologies.

There is now favors which the AI will give you when they want something you have and they don't have or don't want to trade something for it. You can then trade them in for Energy, recourses, etc...

2. Bugs, bugs everywhere. They are so many bug that I can even begin to list them out. It could easily take up this hole review.

Here's a couple, some Aliens turning invisible when attacked, and then making the Attacking animation take a very long time while you look at nothing. Quest bugged, Crashing at start up.

3. Hello, Do you have a Sweet kickass Gaming monitor that can do more then 60hz?

WELL THEN YOU PLAY AT 1280x1024! Oh yea. If you have a high Refresh rate you have to play at 1280x1024! Or you can play in window mode. NO! NOT BORDERLESS Window mode. Window mode. It's been TWO WEEKS since launch, and still no hot fix for it. They don't care. How does this make it pass play testers?

4. Do you have out dated computer that meets recommended
System Requirements with room to spare? You will get a Weird rainbow box pattern Graphical Glitch on the land when you load up a save file, or at random. This supposedly has to do with older GPUs. Even if you meet the recommended
System Requirements.

5. AI is still on the brain dead and weak side, or even worst. The AI never really talked to me or even went to war with each over. Maybe 2-3 time and they were very short.

6. No personality in this game. Factions are bland, have no personality. They nothing different with them other than a bonuses, a color and a flag. They might as well have called them by colors of the rainbow. This game tries to tell a story with some special quest and the victories., but fails hard.

Theres rumors that some features have been taken out of the game to be later resold to you as a DLC.

There isn't enough here to be anything that great. At the time of writing this I have 10.0 in this game. At about turn 200 I got so bored with this game that I did every thing I could just to my victory as fast as I could so i could end this game. Going through turns as fast I can. I still haven't finished my game.

I wouldn't say walk away from this game, I would say Run!


Update 2/2/15: I thought i would just give a little update about how this game has progressed. It took them a month and a half to fix their game, yet that patch even broke the game for a lot of people. That inexcusable for a AAA Dev. Most Dev have a patch within a week to fix the big bugs, and then patch the rest ASAP. It's been about 3 and a half months and there is still many bugs that haven't been fixed. Firaxis Games has been very silent on what's going on. No one knows what they're doing, or even how long it could be for a partch, if they're even working on one.

Please don't listen to the Fanboyism. They will defend their purchase, and their favorite Dev, to the very last drop of blood!

reviewText:
I am sad to say, but I would pass on Beyond Earth as a title unless it happens to be on some super cheap steam sale.
There is a lot of new stuff to be seen in BE, including a few features that I would love to see in Civilization proper, such as Quests, Orbital, and a non linear progression. However, many of the bugs that were in the Civ 5 engine come along through space here too.

Early game is perhaps the best part of the game. You start off alone and weak, hoping to not anger the planet as you explore and get your feet wet. However the longer you play, the more you come to realize the blandness of the game. Quests are there, but they tend to only play a minor part of the game as a whole. You end up feeling you have a lot to do, but none of it really matters. The AI is some of the dumbest ive ever seen in a Civ game. They almost never directly confront you, and even if they decide to war against you, they wont do anything with it.

TL:DR Nice concept, but feels hollow and empty. It has the makings of greatness, but for now, it is just mediocre.

reviewText:
I wish I liked this better. I wanted to like this better. I made myself keep playing even after I had the sinking feeling that I didn't like this better.

It's just not very good, and I say that as a gamer with a broad tolerance range and a willingness to find something to like in most designs. There just isn't much here to praise even with a generous eye. When the gameplay is decent, that's because it's essentially re-skinned Civilization V. The tech web is really the only innovation that changes Civilization V's core design in some intriguing ways.

Otherwise, this is totally lacking in polish, in meaningful iterations of Civ V's designs, in anything that would give it one-more-turn attractiveness. The factions are dull and uninvolving, which I think explains why the designers were so eager to discourage comparisons between Beyond Earth and Alpha Centauri. The aliens are just pointless nuisances rather than a major, interesting wrinkle in the Civ formula. The game could barely give a ♥♥♥♥ about building Wonders--they get no description and their impact is buried under their incremental bonuses. The interesting endgame units often don't even come into play. The AI is fairly bad, though that's not exactly unique to this installment in the Civ series. The end of the game just sort of happens without fanfare. The whole thing feels amateurish and underimagined, like the job was shoved at some interns.

Civ V was underwhelming at launch too, but this has a much longer way to go before it's any good. I'm not sure that it even can be made good, compared to what was done with Civ V.

reviewText:
Game seriously lacks polish - even compared to vanilla Civ V.

Terrain looks worse and with less variation. There is very little leader dialogue and the quality of the flavour text is variable - it's no Alpha Centuri. Diplomacy and the AI has been copypasted from Civ V. Game needs a balance patch as well - covert ops and trade routes are crazy strong. There isn't a lot to distinguish the affinities/civs in terms of gameplay. The stations, quest system and aliens are cool additions but don't redeem the core gameplay.

The game just feels like a mod for Civ V. Don't get me wrong I loved Civ V - I beat the game on Deity and have spent endless hours with my mates in multiplayer - but Beyond Earth isn't there yet. Save your dosh and buy it after the expansions. Maybe have a look at Endless Legend instead.

reviewText:
FIrst of all I've put 180 hrs into this game, and 350 into Civ 5, and I've been playing Civ games since they started being made, so I like to believe this is an informed opinion.

If you love sci-fi and love Civilization games, ignore the negative reviews. This game is awesome, it just takes some time getting used to. When I played this game for the first time I felt lost, which I didn't expect after putting 350 hours into Civ 5, expecting this to be just a reskin. The game also felt so flavorless to me just like the negative reviews say, and leaders were without personality.

But when I've given the game enough time and started to understand it, I realized I was looking at it the wrong way. The game is not a reskin of Civ 5 unless you want to see it that way, and that's when you'll hate it. There are many layers to the game that gives it its independent personality and lets it walk on its own feet.

The biggest thing I'm referring to is afiinities. Affinities are the main pillar this game stands on, and it's the main factor seperating it from Civ 5. Affinities are what give this game its identity and flavor, not leaders. As you progress in each affinity, you get awesome snipets of story unique to each affinity that drives the story forward in a way Civ 5 never could. You start getting awesome unique units, buildings, and even a unique rich-in-story-and-flavor victory condition for each affinity as you tread their paths.

There are many other mechanics that make this game cool, like the sattelite layer, interacting with aliens, and artifacts. The tech web, while not beginner-friendly at all, makes for very interesting and diverse choices every single game once you are more familiar with the game.

Also the expansion Rising Tide" makes the game even better
date: and the positive reviews on its Steam page prove that. Such a shame that didn't reflect on the game main page reviews as well."

reviewText:
Having played a solid 40+ hours of this, I feel I can give a fairly straightforward review.
First of all, if you are a fan of Sid Meier's games, especially in the last several years, then you will likely find enjoyment with this. It feels like 75% Civ 5 and 25% Alpha Centauri. I played very little AC in the past, and don't remember a whole lot, but the spirit of that game is noticable in Beyond Earth.
Those familiar with Civ 5 will have no trouble getting started in BE, requiring low in-game-advisory assistance. At first the game feels somewhat like an expansion to Civ 5, but you slowly realize that it separates itself fairly quickly with the tech-web and some of the missions/quests.
It's a lot of fun for a Civ-junkie like myself, but I still question the $50 price tag. There doesn't seem to be much change in the Civ 5 game mechanics to warrant a $60, but also feels much more than a $30 expansion. It also feels incomplete. Not like there are bugs of any kind, most of the errors in the game are the same that exist in Civ 5 and they are pet-peeves that could be worked on to improve stream-lining the gameplay more than bugs". I just feel that the game was designed with limited flair and depth to make way for future DLC. Looking at how expansions were handled in Civ 5
date: I can see all sorts of additions to BE such as playing non-humans or a reworking of some units and the tech-web itself.\nOne thing I have considered from trying to get a broader view of the variety of quests/missions that are unique to this game is the potential for a much deeper story
recommended: something that strays from the usual Sid Meier's style

reviewText:
The game is fun. It's like Civ 5, but with completely bland leaders. It also repeats things that peeved me in Civ 5, like snapping me away from a unit I'm already interacting with to automatically put me in control of a different unit, or wasting my time by showing me somebody else's low-rank warrior fight a bug a hundred miles from one of my towns.

The new aesthetic is pretty neat. Everything is very spacey.  Your towns and units change in appearance to suit one of three general game paths that you go down. There's harmony, which is coexistance with the aliens, and purity and supremacy, which honestly seem to be the same, as I can't tell the difference between the two. One's orange, the other is red, and they're about...being violent, maybe? Or being a militaristic human? I don't know. I don't think anyone does.

The leaders? There are a small number of them, and they're meant to represent groups on earth that banded together. I.E., there's the Pan-Asian Cooperative. None of them are really interesting in any way. They have different accents, different colors for zones of influence, and have varying weak and generally non-influential powers. None of them have unique units. It's really a letdown. My favorite is one that speeds along espionage, as that seems to be the most useful. As the game goes on they have some kind of visual effect to denote the path they've chosen (they're subtle, and some paths may not even have ones, it seems), but you will never be able to see yours. That's a dropped ball.

I'm new to the Civ series, and while this game is fun, vanilla Beyond Earth just isn't that good. I recently bought vanilla Civ 5, and this is just so inferior. When compared, the rulers in this one are weak and uninteresting, the wonders are nearly pointless, and the names of military units are completely unrelatable (and, by the way, the names of them change throughout the game - have fun keeping track!). Maybe expansions and future patches will make this game better. Until then, I feel like I've wasted my money...

tl;dr It's Civ 5, with a new skin, the return of irritating features, and new boring leaders.

reviewText:
Solid foundation with some questionable additions // Recommended for fans of the series
+ The 'one more turn' mentality is still present in full force
+ Indigenous wildlife boasts much more of a challenge, of a variety, and of a better collective design than barbarians of the previous installments
+ Combat against cities and units is as well-implemented and satisfying as ever; the audio design and smooth animations make for a very fulfilling experience
+ Upgrades are free of resources requirements and are universally applied amongst all units of that type; does well to eliminate the need to hunt down and manage obsolete units
+ Research tree is vastly improved; it can be daunting at first, but the superiority of this system comes through on subsequent playthroughs (once the player is more familiar with the 'branches and leaves' and what they unlock)
+ The three possible affinities are a welcome addition and do much to offer great variety and customization in the mid- to late-game
+ 'Favors' are a very welcome concept, and work perfectly to improve productivity of player-AI interactions and general diplomacy
+ Sleek, aesthetically pleasing, and functional UI
+ Effortless and rewarding to experiment with mods through the Steam workshop
+ Satellites are a welcome addition, adding another layer of possible resource buffs to the game without cluttering the map
+ Stunning environment designs; flora and resources really stand out in beautiful and creative ways
+ Espionage and trade work in largely the same ways as in Civ V, with some minor improvements

- Culture is now an empty and lifeless statistic in the absence of art, musicians, etc.
- Confusing loss of custom game modifiers as compared to the previous installment of the series
- Steep learning curve, mostly due to alien and unfamiliar terrain features
- Finishing a game is underwhelming, and does little to reward the player, especially compared to previous installments
- Health, as a resource, seems to be a slightly poorer implementation than the happiness of Civ V, and feels unreasonably difficult to manage effectively
- There are no more natural wonders to be found, taking a bit of fun and reward out of exploration
- Quests are boring and repetitive; they do little to add to the game's dimensions
- The available factions feel somewhat bland and uninteresting
- There are no faction-specific units; the only difference between factions lies in the starting bonuses
- AI have almost no aggression factor whatsoever, even into upper middling levels of difficulty

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
9th August 2015:

It's basically a re-skin of Civ 5. Some new elements here and there, but not enough to make the game feel fresh :S
Do not buy instead of Civ 5. Civ 5 has much much more content - we have yet to see what the Beyond Earth DLC will bring, but as of now, it's a no-brainer to get Civ 5 over this.

Personally I love space which is why I got this - other than that Civ 5 is sooo much better ^^

12th January 2016:

I picked up the first downloadable content pack, Rising Tides - pricey at £25 but it wasn't really discounted much in the winter sale anyway :(. It does freshen up gameplay by adding new features (aquatic cities, artifacts, marvel quests) and expanding upon existing ones (hybrid affinity bonuses, more in-depth diplomacy)

However this should not have been an expansion. Vanilla Civ: BE is far too bland a re-skin of Civ 5 to warrant anyone paying full price for it. Also wait for the dlc to go down in price, cos it definitely isn't worth 25 quid.

Look forward to seeing what new features we can expect in coming dlc though :)

I do find myself wondering why do i keep playing it.  The trade system in the game is so completely unbalance it is depressing.  The end game is anticlimactic, and the quests quickly blur together into repetition.  I would have liked to have seen more of a cross between Alpha Centuari and Call to power represented here. That is not why i cannot bring myself to recommend this game.  I can not recommend it because I feel like this game was released because it was time for a new game to come out in the series people and franchise held with little to no regard.

reviewText:
Like Alpha Centauri before it, Civilization: Beyond Earth breaks the shackles of the third planet and offers up a gameplay experience that is both familiar and alien at the same time.

A friend once remarked to me that everything he knew about human history, he learned from Sid Meier’s Civilization games. Well, at least the stuff that he fondly remembers—not the Indian history lessons hammered into his brain thanks to the fear of an impending exam the following day. With Firaxis’s Civilization: Beyond Earth, however, there’s a different kind of learning to be had—you learn more about yourself as a person, or more particularly, whether you will turn into a megalomaniacal dictator with a thirst for blood, a defender of humanity in its current state of technological and social evolution, or a future-ecologist who has a curious love for all things alien.

IT’S NEVER TOO LATE TO GO BACK

If anything, Civilization: Beyond Earth made me realise that it was never too late to go back; back from the ocean of triple-a blockbusters with obscene production values and downloadable content to a game that’s mostly about building stuff, indulging in a spot of faux diplomacy and spending several hours to get a minor Tile productivity bonus. This is interesting because Beyond Earth is doing the opposite as far as the series is concerned; it’s going forward. No longer constrained by our miserable little blue planet (which Firaxis foresee becoming uninhabitable in the future), Beyond Earth takes you on a journey to the stars—the story begins with a moving cut scene in which we see a father bidding farewell to his daughter so that she can find hope for us all somewhere else in the universe—a theme that carries through across the game.

OF AFFINITIES AND FAN SERVICE

There isn’t much of a departure from the way in which Civilization fundamentally works in Beyond Earth—fans will be greeted with familiar visuals (which could use a sprucing up after all these years) and scenarios that require decisions to be made. While the game does allow for players to choose their own path by picking an ‘Affinity’, of which there are three: Supremacy, Harmony and Purity. Suffice to say, they’re both akin to ideologies from Civ 5, but offering military and other bonuses.

With Beyond Earth’s considerably hostile planets, armies are of utmost importance. Alien life-forms can be quite aggressive, while planets are laden with Miasma, a harmful gas that damages units over time (at the beginning, at least). Over the course of several hundred turns, I noticed that pretty much all non-military activity plays second fiddle to the might of your armies and their quest for blood. Yes, you can still achieve endgame objectives without annihilating all other human factions, but having already built up considerable forces to repel alien threats, it feels like a no-brainer to achieve your goals through might. Besides, diplomacy doesn’t always produce good results given that the AI is pretty dodgy for the most part.

CLOSING THOUGHTS

Civilization: Beyond Earth is the absolute perfect follow up to Civilization V, with strange new worlds to explore and advanced societies to establish. What’s more, Beyond Earth’s sandbox allows you to really play the way you want—made possible by the flexible research tree/leaf system. The quest system gives the game much needed context while easing players into the kind of choices they will need to be making on a macro level, while the endgame is greatly affected by the path you take in terms of Affinity. On the downside, I found the emphasis on combat to be excessive—more so than previous games in the series, while the UI (despite streamlining) can still feel overwhelming to new players.

My Rating: 8/10

reviewText:
First off let me start by saying that like others, I love Civilization. Got into it around it's third iteration and loved it, as well as, 4-5 + Alpha Centauri. I went as far as buying a Surface Pro 2, just so I could have a mobile touchscreen version of Civilization 5, that's how much I love that game. Despite a long backlog, it's the game I tend to play every night after work.

Beyond Earth will not be replacing CIV5 anytime soon unfortunately. The first thing that made this game a complete step backwards was the lack of Touch Support. Here is a game that is pretty much a modded civilization 5 and they somehow made it even less optimized and unable to support touch input. Despite lowering all the settings on my SP2 it quickly crashes after 2-3 turns.

So then my only option is to play on my gaming rig or stream it to the tablet. So I played through my first game on the gaming rig. While it wasn't terrible, I agree with everyone else. The AI isn't very intelligent, the leader screens are bland, aliens (barbarians) are really annoying, help is non-existent in the game or just not streamlined, it's missing things like advisor pages, etc... Health and energy, affinity and tech are all there to limit and draw out your city's progression.

To give an example of the difficulty I had with this game, I was at one point bored enough to attack another city. I could see from their defenses they could easily wipe out some of my military. But a few turns later they were begging to give me a city. Meanwhile I can't even explore the ocean without a group of Kraken ganging up on my ships.

The Tech tree is just convoluted and difficult just for the sake of saying oooo sci-fi." Did I mention that I'm color-blind and the colors do me no favors..? Not to mention the Miasma that just seems to blend into the tiles for my eyes. I of course will parrot the same disdain for trade routes constantly bugging you for renewal.

I want to love this game. I want to pretend that my disdain comes from it being different. But ultimately I feel like they got rid of a lot of the good and balance that was in CIV5. I know when CIV5 first came out there was a lot of hate and people felt there were balance issues. Hopefully the same will be said about BE and further patches + dlc will really develop this game.

This will be the last game I preorder from Firaxis
date: next time I will wait for a sale on HB or GMG with all of the DLC at $5-10. Especially if touch support is completely dropped."

reviewText:
If you liked playing single player in other civ games, hold off on purchasing this one for a while; the a.i is weaker than ever, with it being ridiculously passive throughout the game despite my attempts to royally ♥♥♥♥ it off (unlike a few certain civ's in civ V). The a.i does almost nothing except makes a few cities even on the highest difficulty.

The civ leaders also lack any real kind of personality and just come off as boring. They have very few lines and practically all non-spoken dialogue is word for word from civ V.

The aesthetic for the tech web and so on is horribly designed. It is very hard to differentiate things or tell if the tech you're researching unlocks a wonder. It's all just boring as hell monochrome.

The aliens would have been a great addition if they actually would attack your cities and destroy improvements, currently they just mill around outside your borders (even without city upgrades that force them two spaces away from your cities) even if you start comitting alien jihad. Sure, they'll actively try to murder your units when you ♥♥♥♥ them off/are within two hexes of a nest, but otherwise they really don't do anything.

Espionage is very fun and worthwhile in this, with you building up intrigue in cities by doing operations with your spies in them, unlocking new operations you can do within them. You also get quit a few spies to conduct these operations with, so if you wanted to focus on that you easily can.

Trade routes are a lot more essential in this than in other civ games, especially since there's no max distance a caravan can travel (just need a clear route) and that you can have two trade routes in each city. The changes to them have made the game much more fast paced, since you will have quite a bit of currency to spend to directly purchase buildings/units.

All in all, I would wait for a sale and/or for the first expansion to come out to round out the game better, it just feels kinda bare gameplay-wise in some areas and has strange mechanics decisions in others (new cities being founded take a few turns before they're fully built and operational being one of them, it isn't annoying or anything, but it doesn't seem to accomplish that much in the long run). Do not believe the hype.

Alternatively, if you have a few friends to play this with, this is probably the best civ to do it with to date, since the games end faster than in other entries in the civ series. Though there apparently are problems with the multiplayer, though I haven't really had any issues yet.

reviewText:
Absolutely incredible. Gameplay is similar to Civ V only better. There is a lot more decision making that makes you feel as if you were actually in charge of a civilization, and the results have real, almost tangible effects on the game. I felt like I was discovering a whole new world the entire time and really strategizing my resources and decisions, whereas Civ V, I often find myself in the same worlds making the same decisions. Here, the victory combinations and outcomes are endless. My favorite component of the game are the quests. It gave me something to do and incentives to build improvements, fight aliens, go on spy missions, etc. Similar to the quests given by city-states, but self-paced (no turn limit), no diplomatic pressure, and better rewards.

AI is much better. I played for about 185 turns and no one declared war on me. I also didn't feel as if someone were nagging me every two turns. There are no city-states, per-se, but there are stations you can establish trade routes with and the benefits are much better (more science, culture, etc.). No one begged me for money, either, which was nice. There was lots of room for expansion, even on the standard map, so border issues were almost non-existent, save one time I discovered artifacts near Brazil. You also get to choose missions for your spies and what they can steal (if they succeed). Alien personalities were pretty random and I had a few explorers killed, but not as much of a nuisance as the barbarians in Civ V. Never felt as if I had to constantly protect my workers or colonists, and they didn't pillage tiles nearly as often.

Few drawbacks: 1.) Resources and their management. Rather than relying on the a few basic improvements/resource types (quarries, mines, plantations, etc.) there are a lot more resources (which I liked), and most of them have specific improvements that need to be discovered by exploring the tech web. Thus, resources take a lot longer to obtain, are more scarce and harder to trade, and can drastically effect game play depending on your location and what type of victory you're aiming for 2.) I was a bit confused as to how expeditions work. I did a few, but there were times I would bring my explorer to an expedition site and couldn't do anything. This could very well be a big that requires what I imagine to be a small patch, but nonetheless it was a bit off-putting. 3.)The miasma was an inconvenience.

Overall, the strategic value and adventure in this game off-set these things. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys any games from the Civ series and anyone looking for a strategy game that really puts you in control. Still haven't finished the current game I'm on (I believe I left off at turn 185 which put me around 2900 AD from what I remember) or tried multiplayer, but I can't wait to see what else this game has in store. Overall score: 92/100.

reviewText: As much as I looked up to this game and wanted it to be good, it really doesn't live up to its title. Doesn't have the feel of progression that you got in Civilization, and it got pretty dull for me after the first game. Considering you start off with the ability to build roads, farms, mines, and generators(tradingposts like old civ) straight off the bat, and then later you are getting all sorts of tile improvements that are way better so you wind up having to build over half the stuff you allready made making you spend uncessisary amounts of time micro-managing your workers. (I've never been a fan out automated workers.) The Technology tree is, in my opinion, VERY unbalanced. Because of its web-like structure there are pretty much 3 levels beyond the middle. And when you research one of your technologies you realize that it would take around 30-40 turns to get a tech that is further away from it, so you research other techs instead while you get your science up. Not with free technologies though. With free technologies you can jump for techs that will give you HUGE advantages over everyone else. Say you research Physics, then that unlocks bionics which would normally take 60 turns to get from your position, but not with free techs. You can instantly research things that would normally be FAR beyond your reach until mid-late game. So far i've only seen a few ways of getting free techs, Franco-Iberia gives you a free tech after 10 virtues, and Slavic Federation gets one after they launch their first orbital unit. Also another way is if you put 15 points into the Knowledge virtue tree, which doesn't take long because the knowledge tree is focused on science and culture. By combining these you can gain technologies that are normally unobtainable until late-end game. Say you get 2 free techs some time during mid game and you have got robotics allready, You can then grab nanotechnology, meaning you can start building the exodus gate as soon as you reach purity 13. Using free technologies can allso be used to get affinity points quicker than everyone, and it doesn't take much to Upgrade your units into much stronger units. All you need is 6 points to get the 3rd tier Soldier giving it 24 str. where as the marines prior to it only have 14 str. , nearly DOUBLING your units strength compared to everyone elses. And once someone gets ahead in affinity there is normalling nothing you can do unless you can catch up, and catch up fast. Oh yeah and you know how in Civilization 5 you had to build any new units you got or upgrade your now-obsolite units inside your borders? Well once you upgrade a unit in this it automatically changes all of the units to the upgraded version. So you could be fighting a large group of enemys and then all of a sudden all of his men turn into super powerful Centurions (48 str.) who are literraly 2x as strong and the unit prior to them. Oh yeah, and because of that it means someone can build loads of units and then get one more point of affinity, having a much bigger army then if they built them after they got the upgrade. (Upgraded units cost much more production to build.) On the topic of affinitys I feel that purity may be a bit stronger than Supremacy and Harmony. Harmonies units abilities are that they get large bonuses for when they arn't adjacent to eachother and for being in miasma, and supremecies units get bonuses for adjacent unit to them and flanking enemies. Purity on the other hand get bonuses for attacking and defending. Their Soldier units can get bonuses when on defence and/or bonuses for unspent movment, along with the abilites to heal every turn with the Centurion. Then their tanks (instead of getting the same bonuses like the other affinities get for all of their units) get bonueses to their attack strenght and/or bonuses for unspent movement, (kinda the same but still a bit different), and with the Dragoon tanks they get 50% bonuses against cities. Also take note that their tanks are stronger than the other affinities tanks. Not saying that the other ones are bad, I just feel that purity gets move convenient abilities. And on the normal difficulty the ai are very unintelligent, taking forever to level up their purities making them very easy target mid-late game for players. Also I once played on a huge map and meet an ai whos capital was about a good 50 tiles from me who had a good location for a second city near it. Instead of settling there though, it traveled 50 tiles down to my capital and founded their second city in resource-barren location right next to my capital. Speaking of cities and resources, the removeall of happiness and replacing it with this 'health' system has, in my opinion, SEVERELY broken the ways you build your empire. Unlike in Civilization 5 where you could build many cities, just as long as you keep them relatively small until you build more buildings and improve some nearby resources to get happiness, you could have a large, vast empire of cities. In this that is nearly impossible, having more than 3 cities mid-late game you will still be struggling with keeping your health positive, let alone 5 or 7 cities. Why is it so hard to stay healthy? Because the only way to get health is through buildings, no longer is there any resourses to build cities at to make sure your empire stays in the posatives while the city grows. No longer is there any way of getting help from another Ai or Player and trade for a resource to get you out of a bad situation. All you can do is build buildings/and or raze every city that you can. In the end the customization is poor, Choose good upgrade A or near worthless upgrade B."

reviewText:
So much disappointment here.

The first thing I learned is that this game was made with the same engine as Civ V. That means most of the mechanics and the tools to modify them already existed. This game wasn't made so much as it was just slapped on top of it's predecessor. With all that I at least expected that the developers could put their time into expanding the game play and adding new features but after spending the last 3 nights with it, it feels like a gutted product. I couldn't find enough to like to justify the price or the name.

Here is what I found missing.
No religion - Now we have affinity instead. You gain levels by researching certain since paths in the tech web". All but two of the victory conditions require you to pursue an affinity at the cost of a well rounded society.

Confusing Interface layout left a lot of information hidden by default.
Neutered Diplomatic options left you with little options when it came to protecting the new versions of city states.

Boring victory conditions -You need to research a tech
date:
gain x affinity and then construct a wonder.
No cut scenes for wonders/victory 4 hours of playing and I was rewarded with the same tired victory screen from Civ 5.
Terrible wonders that take way too long to build. I saw very few wonders that actually had an impact greater then a regular building...they just took 50-70 turns to build.

I'm hoping for a patch of some kind soon...I feel like I got half a game here."

reviewText: This...well, put it like this: When I bought Civ 5, I played it for hours on the first day I bought it. When I bought-no, sorry, preordered-this, I played for a bit, realized I didn't know what I was doing, because of the nowhere-near-as-useful help system in Civ 5, watched the AI build wonders that I didn't know how to build because of the disorganized tech web as well as the fact that a Wonder looks like a normal building, and then played Civ 5. I really wish I waited for other people's reviews and give this one a miss. There's technically 1000 civs, no joke, but only eight sponsors, the things that would be considered actual civs. Eight's a bit of a step down from the full count of 43 with all expansions and DLC with no mods in Civ 5, plus, there's no feeling of dread if you meet a warmonger, no feeling of awesome when you meet that civ that's always your friend, and, since these are future civs, you have no idea what their personality is, especially their preferred affinity, as, it seems, that decides who your friends are. (Although these may not exist as I saw the Asian civ pick Harmony on my first full completion of the game, and Purity the second time, but since there are preferred ideologies in Civ 5, I'm assuming there probably is.) This game isn't terrible, but there are very few things that set it apart from Civ 5, and pretty much all of them have problems of their own. First, there's the tech web, which is a tech tree with less techs and higher science requirements. The tech web has branch techs" like Ecology which usually give a couple of buildings

reviewText:
I dunno where all the hate is coming from regarding this game. Sure there are a few issues here and there but overall it is fun. Although many have compared it to civ 5 and argued civ 5 is better, i disagree. This game is similar to civ 5 but different enough that it has its own personality (i.e. affinity levels are how you level up your units), quests for you to do (which is new) and instead of trying to use characters based on earth history (albeit loosely) like civ 5, this game starts you on a new planet.

Sure that path you choose (i.e. affinity) means that pretty early on you have to decide which affinity your going to major in (as this determines which resources you will need the most). Its still engaging. In my opinion this is no different than when I played civ 5 and had historical expansionist leaders nearby to me (i had to formulate a strategy early on to decide whether i was going to woo one or some of my neighbours or go full on military myself and quash my neighbours).

This game requires similar decisions as people with similar affinity will be warmer towards you and more hostile towards you if your not. So all in all i don't find it detrimental that early on i need to pick an affinity. In general though the comparison to civ 5 (which is also a great game, but has been around for years and has had expansions and other dlc content added on over time) is not a fair comparison content wise. Civ 5 has been out for awhile and they released content that expanded the game...beyond earth just came out and people are comparing to civ 5 as it is now (not as it was when it came out..which was still damn good).

The graphics are amazing, it plays similarly to other civ games so if you have any experience with previous civ games you should be good to go after a few games. New fans to the series will face the daunting task of anyone coming into any civ games (using the civilopedia and advisors often to find out WTF is going on.

I haven't played this game as much as some of the negative reviewers simply because i have bought a lot of games lol..what can i say i love games. But i can still come back to this game and enjoy my time spent here (i just have to be in the mood to play a 4x strategy title, and have the time to to so, as i like to play through a whole match in one sitting) as any 4x strat fan knows it takes awhile to go through a whole game.

All in all this game lived up to my expectations from viewing the early gameplay videos and developer videos. I read the reviews before i bought it and they recommended it too.

overall i am satisfied with this game and have already preordered starships (as this game although a standalone will have some cross over play features with starships).

final opinion...its a great 4x strat game, buy it if you like 4x strat games as there is a lot here to do, and its fun and has a good deal of depth.

reviewText:
Civilization Beyond Earth, whilst a very good game, feels like a good mod for Civilization V. If you have Civ V, in my opinion, you DON'T need this game unless you collect firax games. The only reason you would want this is if you have played every empire several times and you wnat something new but not too different. New players to the Civilization collection may want to skip Civ V and go straight to Civ: BE - don't. Civ V is a much more rounded game with much better AI and more choice. Ok, there are exactly 1000 different starting situations with the new set up game idea - which is very good but limited to 8 factions - but only three are really good adn meake a difference to the game. Certain factions are OP and whilst the patch fixed this, many are still always going to win.

The Ai is awful. I settled 4 cities as close to the slavic federation - the warmongers of the gaem - and they told me to stop 37 turns later. 37. Then they were still 'friendly'. i then declare war and as cities are so weak i capture all their cities within 5 turns.

Micro management needs more shortucuts. if you 10 citites you can have 20 trade routes and whislt that is great, there is no key to sewnd them on their previous routes which is not needed in civ as you have only 5 or 6.

I promise this is my last groan. Improvements. Tile mprovements are great in this game but they cost TOO much. Really 2 health for a petol well? then you have £2 on top of that. AARRGG. i am just in positive happieness - but i need the petrol to advance on my victory situation. then the better farms - terrascapes - cost 6 energy. If you have to settle near tundra at the start of the game YOU ARE SCREWED. Restart the game immediatly.

the affinity system is great and the fewer units makes it all so much simpler - but the affinity system is limited and it almost feels like it has been stuck at the end of the game to allow end game to be fun.

I love the virtues as i felt in Civ V there were too many different paths to go down, the four is just the correct amount.

in conclusion Civ: BE is a good game but has been shamed by previous civ games and after a long wait I expected more form the best stratagy game maker, in my opinion. Dont get me wrong I had fun playing but i think i prefer Civ V. I would recommend it but it is not worth he money you have to pay. With some patches, I think this could go to great places, but before them DONT BUY IT.

reviewText:
Really disappointing. I pre-ordered this game hoping for a spiritual successor to SMAC, and it instead turned out to be Civ 5 in a dull new skin. Actually, it is not quite that either. The gameplay feels more hollow than Civ 5 somehow, which is an accomplishment considering the additional game systems they have added, such as orbital satellites. Visually too the game manages to look underwhelming compared to Civ 5.

Narrative-wise, the game does itself an incredible disservice by laying bare all the major plotlines right out of the gate, inside quest/win-state descriptions. There is no sense of mystery to anything, and it really beats me why they decided to do that. What was meant to be the player's new alien world to discover, feels instead like an uninspired sci-fi B-movie reboot where nothing interesting ever happens.

What disappoints me the most is the lack of ambition and innovation from Firaxis at this point of the franchise's life cycle. If you are looking for a 4X style game that actually makes an effort to break the mould, I would highly recommend Endless Legend instead. Those guys are actually trying out new things, building amazing worlds and factions, while Firaxis seems to be sitting on its laurels and living off Civ's inheritance.
voteText: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disappointing.

There are some good changes to the Civ formula here, but it isn't enough. There's just so much that feels unfinished or half baked. If you're looking for a successor to Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, this isn't it. In the end, it just makes me want to play Civ 5 again.

Good: The map feels much more alive. I like that the aliens can be tolerated or destroyed. Eventually those alien nests become valuable, though, as they conceal a strategic resource.

Mixed: I don't actually miss trading technologies, but what are favors and why do I want to gain them?

Mixed: The addition of the orbital layer is kinda neat, but it doesn't really add that much. It will get some attention in the first expansion, but this is not a review of future potential. It's a review of what I already paid $50 for.

Bad: The science fiction technologies available in the tech-web are sciencey sounding gobbeldy-gook. There isn't a solid sense of scientific or technological progression. Thus, the implicit narrative of progress is largely lost. This is a major bummer. It just feel like you're constantly choosing the next bonus.

Bad: The endings are largely unuitive, anti-climactic, and unsatisfying. The writing and lore don't bring a satisfying or coherent sense of narrative and once it's done there isn't so much as an animation to pat you on the back. Worse yet, the old series of ranking, replay, and analysis screens are absent. About all the fanfare you get is a ticket back to the title screen.

Bad: There's a general sense of unfinished clunkiness to a lot of the UI. It doesn't even bother to remind you what a city just finished building when prompting you to chose the next project.

reviewText:
17 December 2014: I would not recommend Civilization: Beyond Earth yet, but that might change in the future. See below for details.

In short: The game as a whole seems LESS than the sum of its parts.

Similar to Civilization V when it came out - Beyond Earth for now is not a good gaming experience. With time Civ V was patched and extended and became one of my favorites. I hope the same will come true for Beyond Earth.

But  what exactly is the problem with the game? For me it's two things.

First of all the different pieces of otherwise very good mechanics don't exactly come together because of the lacking lore  of the game. The story, the different philosophies of the factions and personalities of their leaders and the overall world setting are far from complete, deep or anything but basic. And when inevitably compared to its spiritual predecessor - Alpha Centauri which had epic lore, Beyond Earth seems pretty poor...for now.

As a result the game does not escalate in scope, something that Alpha Centauri did quite well.

The second problem is the Technoabble" used in Beyond Earth. The naming of technologies
recommended: but really not clear in it intent and purpose. That kind of ruins the atmosphere. It makes you feel at times that you don't know what you are doing and prevents you from clearly setting your goals in game. Going through several replays of the game you will eventually figure it out
hoursPlayed: but IMHO it should be more universal and less clever to be more enjoyable.\n\nI'm hopeful that beyond Earth will grow with time to be much better."

reviewText:
I've been playing Civ V for a very, very long time, and yes, when the DLCs came out, it took me a little while to fully understand how the all tied in together, but it wasn't a big learning curve.

Compared to Civ V, this game just want in a completely different direction and not in a good way. I've only been playing for less than an hour because that is about as much as I can handle with this game.

After playing for as little as I have been, here's what I can take away from this game:

- The learning curve is you start out with the game turning on and then it just go right through the roof with the rest of it.
- It's not really clear the tech paths and how they are applied to the game.
- Yes, they do explain a few of the new features, but my issue with it is it's almost counter intutitive to what was in Civ V.
- They put too much, too soon on the game when you first start out. When we started in Civ V, a city, a unit, some hidden ruins, some state cities, and then the other AIs. All of it pretty straightforward. Here, they give you crashed space craft, aliens that seem to be able to kill you out right, AIs who seem to be able to get the upper hand faster than you, etc. and this was all on easy, are you kidding me?!

Do yourself a favor and do not buy this game. The only other game that is similar to this and more fun, IMO, is Endless Legend. It's basically like Civ V, but with a more magical theme to it along with some very interesting game play that is difficult at first, but you really get the hang of it.

I'm going to try and give Civ: BE another chance and at least try to play one game, but overall, don't buy this game. Just don't.

I'll update this review once I get a game fully completed.

reviewText:
Such a massively disappointing Civ game that I'm having trouble even beginning to describe it.  It took 18 months in my library before I even finished my first game, just because I felt I somehow owed it to a franchise I've been playing since I was 8.  I wish I hadn't.

The goal was obviously to take the game in new directions, abandoning things such as linear tech trees, unpredictable AI, and unit obsolescece.  Credit where credit's due, those have been major complaints of the community for several iterations and they are no longer part of the game.

However, what they were replaced with seem shallow and unintuitive.  Unit customization is just a shade of what was present in Alpha Centauri (a game which inevitably became the comparison for CIV BE), offering only two options that at times seem equally unimportant.  The tech web was a difficult to navigate and harder to comprehend mess.  The AI opinions were slim, and you can easily spend the whole game without ever drawing any opponent into meaningful conflict no matter how abusive you became towards them.

Not to mention minor quibbles, like the color pallette being evocative of an oil stain on an asphalt driveway.  Or the incredibly anticlimatic Wait timer" for victories.  Or the shifting and sometimes senseless Affinity system. Or the ... you get the idea."

reviewText: This is one of my favorite games.  Ever since I got this, I cannot go back to Civ V.  Perhaps its the alien atmosphere that pulled me in, or perhaps it was the aliens that are watching your every move, staring at the 'aliens' inhabiting their planet.  The tech web is amazing, to the point that it can be overwhelming to newcomers.  Long gone are the linear tech lanes of Civ V, which to me makes the game better in that aspect.  You no longer have everyone running to create the same Wonders in Civ V, thus making the game less linear.  I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys good 4x strategy games and enjoys Sci-fi titles.  Highly recommend.  10/10
