reviewText:
First, i am comparing this game to Alpha Centauri. Ruthlessly. Why, you ask? Because Beyond Earth was called „spiritual successor“ of that game. And because Alpha Centauri is truly a pearl of a game that sets the tone of every sci-fi Civ-like game in the future.

Second, I deleted my original review and added this more improved, more poisonous and better review instead.

Now, let us start.
-	The factions. Alpha Centauri had sever distinct factions. All of them were given proper personalities, they played different, they felt different, the AI treated them different. From fungus-covered territory of Lady Gaia to industrial lands of Chairman Yang, they were all different. And the quotes! People still quote the words of all of them and remember them. In CBE, the factions lack any personality. Previous Civs had the historic figures that would mean something to you, but in CBE, there are bland characters that add to nothing, are not really different and are completely forgettable.
-	The affinities. You can go for purity, harmony and supremacy- meaning staying human, becoming cyborg and hugging aliens. In theory. In practice, they are completely cosmetic and don’t matter much. You get some slight differences in units and cities use a bit different skin. That is all. And it is not logical- you can become purity without killing a single alien and you can become an alien-hugger harmony player and you can wipe out the entire alien population of the world without any penalty. Mostly- you can make a choice that does not matter.
-	The aliens. They were supposed to be different then barbarians in the Civ games- and they are. Unfortunately, they are more like neutered space-alien-barbarians. Never in my game had i had one attacking my cities. Especially when there is improvement that keeps them at least 2 squares away from the city. Even in the beginning, they are a no-threat. And even if you murder them by dozens, the aliens don’t seem to mind. Not more hostile reaction, aliens taking the offensive or something. Nothing. Even though there is first level harmony affinity that makes the alien hostility to come down easier and that does basically nothing.
-	The victories. Whatever victory you achieve doesn’t matter much. You get an uninspired pop-up text with a pretty picture saying basically „Congrats you won“ and voila, here comes the main screen. And all the victories except conquest one are basically science victories, where you have to build stuff and do some stuff as well.
-	The diplomacy. As bad as in Civ 5. Combine that with bland factions mentioned before and the diplomacy becomes a bore. Plus, no clear view on how one faction is feeling towards the other? Are the Polynesians and Africans close or do they hate each other’s guts? No way to tell? In addition, no Planetary Council or UN-like feature where you decide global things. And the city-states, now dubbed as “stations” are even less of a value then in Civ 5. You cannot interact with them diplomatically. You cannot warn other players who are attacking the station you are trading with stop, you cannot declare war on them. Or you can declare war on them by moving your melee troop (yes, the soldiers/marines are called melee troops) and attack the station. That is declaring war- no other way. And the AI is not aggressive. Wars are few and usually end up in status quo.
-	The planet. Looks like ye goode olde Earth, but perhaps with different skin and different kind of neutered barbarians roaming around. Terrain types are the same, terrain bonuses are the same, mountains have bluish skin. The resources are a bit different and occasionally, you see floating rocks or green goo. You feel right at home if you have played Civ 5- but is the point of Beyond Earth to feel right at home?
-	The military. Less units then in Civ 5. One type of ship and one type of aircraft. Oh, and a carrier. No choppers, no bombers, no fighters, no heavy battleships and light destroyers. Same with land units- one melee unit, one ranged, one tank or cavalry like things and one catapult with missiles. Plus some affinity-specific units. One unit per square, soldiers and tanks are referred as “melee” units. Guess they use the butts of their guns. They also upgrade automatically when you gain affinity level- that is kind of nice. But adds to confusion- suddenly all your soldiers are called Cobras or whatnot. And the combat is quite similar to Civ 5, only you see less, because AI is not very aggressive.
-	Quest system. Oh, the system that was going to bring the game to life! Really? Don’t hold your breath… Around 90% of the quest decisions are choosing what bonus to add to your building. So, do you want +1 health or +1 production to your new fancy clinic? Rest of them- you have to work really hard to fail and usually you get bonuses to your currently most advanced affinity. Sometimes you get to choose what affinity. And that is pretty much it.

In addition, there are minor nitpicks:
-	When the colony produces a construction, it does not tell you what building or unit it finished- just that project is complete. If you have 10+ colonies, you cannot remember what you built.
-	Wonder pop-ups- when someone else builds wonder, it does not tell you what it does. It makes sense when you get that someone build Sixtine Chapel, but less so when someone builds Archimedes Lever.
-	When you build Archimedes Lever, you get a nice boring blueprint nondescript wonder screen that tells you what bonuses you get, but does not answer the main question: the hell is Archimedes Lever?
-	Same applies to all techs and wonders and buildings. You get a name, not-half-as-good-quote as from Alpha Centauri and bonuses. To dig deeper, you have to look into Civilopaedia. Works fine for Civ 5, where for example “Gunpowder” and “Writing” or “Barracks” and “Temple” does not need further instruction, but when dealing with “Soma Distillery” and “Xeno Sanctuary” or “Alien Ethics” and “Dark Networks” in Beyond Earth.

There is still more, but the review is already two A4 pages long, so I’ll spare you. The conclusion- Beyond Earth is more like a badly done expansion pack of Civ 5 then a standalone game. It might get better with DLC/expansions, but at its current state I would suggest to wait with buying until the price drops about 75%. Or just do buy Alpha Centauri. If you manage to look behind aged graphics and terrible interface, you discover (or re-discover) a truly great game hidden behind it.
Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Civilization Beyond Earth has got to be, in my experience, one of the worst additions to the Civilization series. It is monotonous and has an uninteresting interface. I would consider myself a huge fan of turn-based strategy games and i love Civilization 5. It seems as though this sequel to the rest of the Civs is lacking in factions, interesting units, fun strategy and it certainly isnt as spacey as one made it seem. It makes me just want to carry on with Civ 5. There is a lot of improving to be done with this game to appeal to me. The game needs;
1) A better landscape - The current one is hiddeous and unimaginative.
2) More factions - The ideas behind the ones that are there are fabulous, however they lack in being clearly more different from one another so i feel like no matter who i choose i will be playing the same stategy.
3)The release price does not at all reflect the games value in its present state.
4) The Diplomacy interface is unorigional and too easy.
5) Finally, the level of difficulties are not challenging, it's almost like a game for Civ Noobs.

Overall however the game will be improved in the future i hope and it has some potential but right now i would not recommend the game in its current state.

reviewText:
I’m a long-standing fan of the Civ series and I’ve logged over 750 hours (!) playing Civ V. Needless to say I’ve been looking forward to this for quite some time. Unfortunately, while the new setting is welcome, I really feel that a lot of what makes Civ a charming and involving game has been stripped out – the core mechanics remain similar and the new tech web is a welcome departure – but it lacks the satisfying depth of its predecessors.

Something that you begin to realise playing Beyond Earth is how much the Civ series depends on a familiarity with its historical setting to give flavour and inform your decisions. You know that Atilla the Hun’s hordes rampaged across China and consequently what he might be like to deal with; you have an idea of who Ghandi is therefore what he might play like – their histories inform their game mechanics, but there are no such cultural touchstones here. Yes, the characters that lead each faction have certain traits, but they might as well be called “blue team” or “red team” – there’s no historical contextualisation or existing character to draw from and because of that it becomes difficult to care about them.

I’ve seen it argued that it’s actually the inverse of traditional Civ – that instead of having a pre-formed personality which eventually becomes more homogenised, leaders start out as blank canvasses which gradually develop personalities shaped by their tech. However, in practice I’ve seen little evidence in the writing that this is actually the case, merely that you mentally note that a faction is leaning towards one affinity and they might now shift their focus in one direction or another.

Additionally, because of the futuristic setting, it’s difficult to actually tell what you’re researching. Beyond providing stated bonuses to tiles or buildings, there’s no way to actually conceive of what the building looks like or its function.

That’s fine when it comes to basic buildings like the early trading posts and clinics but it really suffers when it comes to wonders. I know that a Bytegeist gives me a cultural and scientific bonus but what actually is it? The lengthy text descriptions do shed some light on this, but it’s hard to form an immediate connection with it in the same way that say, The Pyramids or The Statue of Liberty do. Wonders have been relegated to just expensive one-time buildings.

While you can argue that that’s all they ever were in Civ, a hallmark of the series is how well it hides the raw stats in each play-through behind charm and personality, something which is completely lacking here. This is actually where I really miss the little wonder cinematics which are also absent in Civ V – a little video could go a long way to showing what kind of effects that wonder has (something that Call to Power 2 did nicely way back in 2000).

This also extends to culture. Yes, a culture bar ticks up a few points every turn and yes you can build things to influence it but it’s hard to see what the culture is actually representative of. Culture implies a certain diversity and identity and that’s something that Beyond Earth really lacks, especially because there are no civ-unique units or buildings. That’s disappointing because the intro cinematic actually suggests a cultural dimension which is absent in gameplay.

The designers seem to be well aware that a lack of historical narrative is a problem and have introduced quests in order to give a bit of contextualisation and direction to gameplay. However, what these mostly amount to are just “choose one bonus, this or this” or “choose one action, find out what you get several turns later”, neither of which are particularly satisfying.

The aliens are a nice idea and welcome change to the usual barbarians, but they’re still more of an annoyance than anything else. They have rather unpredictable AI – they’ll ignore units and trade caravans one minute while decimating them the next – at least with barbarians you sort of knew where you stood. Also, once your Civ has reaches a certain tech level, they seem more of a chore than anything to deal with – all they really seem to do is pick off trade caravans which need to be tediously defended. I was disappointed that there wasn’t more interaction with them.

Even when you play towards the Harmony affinity which is ostensibly about integrating with the indigenous flora and fauna, there’s no obligation to keep the original aliens around and as they’re frequently in the way of valuable real estate, they just become cannon fodder. It’d be much more compelling to perhaps allow units to tame wild beasts with a certain affinity level and use them for more than just military units – then there’d be more of a trade-off between exterminating the bugs and keeping them around – and a narrative and gameplay reason to prevent other players from doing so.

Here I also think they missed an option to be really creative – different aliens for different worlds or even simply different habitats (curiously, all types of aliens seem to be found in every type of terrain) could lead you to assess if it was worth domesticating them.

The way that difficulty is implemented will be a familiar gripe to fans of the series. The AI has a base level and the way that the game is made harder is by giving the AI more stuff, not making the AI actually better at what it does. It’s no more cunning at higher difficulties; it just has more to throw against you. I’m not really sure if I expected this to change in a new Civ game, but it doesn’t require you to make more creative decisions, just more efficient ones. And the bizarre and unpredictable demands of the AI  - notably the “stop settling near us complaint” – which seems to occur at the drop of a hat, seem to have been intensified here.

That’s not to say that it’s not a solid enough game – the Civ franchise has had two decades to develop and the core 4x gameplay is decent, but the inherent charm, the soul of the game, seems curiously absent. It functions perfectly adequate as a collection of systems and numbers, but it doesn’t feel like more than the sum of its parts. All in all, in feels like a re-skinned and modded version of Civ V – but actually with some features removed; the religion stat added in the Gods & Kings expansion isn’t present here; you can’t win a cultural victory and the lack of diversity of units and buildings is disappointing.

That makes it hard to recommend even if it’s not actually bad per se but it’s certainly a much shallower, homogenised game and a much less satisfying game experience.

reviewText:
I have over 1100 hours in Civ V, and over 40 hours in Civ: BE. As of today (30/10/14), I have finished all victory types except domination, and am working on beating the game on the highest difficulty.

Firstly I would like to say this game is *not* Civ V. It looks like like Civ V, has many features like Civ V, but it is *not* Civ V. This is also not Alpha Centauri. Much like XCOM, Civilization: Beyond Earth  is a spiritual successor to SMAC. It brings to the table many new features, many of the things we loved in Civ V, and a few things that need improvement.

The biggest difference is the new Tech Web. No longer are we confined to a linear path of building, but now we can branch out as we see fit, adapting to our enviroment, and investing our sciences as needed. This is a breath of freash air from Civ V, where going through the Tech Tree was almost formulaic. This allows for each game to be different in how and what you build, as well as allows you to quickly change plans should the need arise, and focus your efforts elsewhere.

Unfortunatly, the Tech web is not intuitive. Since Civ V is about history, even those who know little about the past still have an idea what Metal Working would be, or what a unit called Knights" are. With Civ: BE

reviewText:
As others have said, its very very similar to Civ 5, and has a large set of major flaws (new and old). I could nitpick, but the two worst are:

-The AI is possibly even more idiotic than Civ 5. It ignores potentially game changing actions by the player, gets upset over random trivialities, and is generally poor in its approach.

-Trade routes are a big part of the game, and if you tend to play large maps and like expanding (like i do), you will end up with dozens. The trade routes are way too powerful to not fully utilize, and having to reassign one or more trade routes at the start of every turn just kills the feel of the game. I abandoned a recent game because of this issue. The AI was active for once and was down to two very large AI nations. I had also grown quite large in the end game (well over a dozen cities). I just couldn't deal with reassigning multiple trade routes at the start of each turn. Scrolling through the dropdown of countless possible routes, selecting the correct route, and confirming the same route as before was just boring me as I had to do multiple every single turn.

I am ready to play something else until the gameplay is cleaned up.

reviewText:
Dissapointment in the simplest form.
UI = no challenge even on top difficulty.
Diplomacy = what diplomacy? no point of clicking and wasting time - AI will do it for you asking for open borders mainly.
Aliens? No challenge unless they swarm you at start of game.

In-Game Depth?
The game feels like an unfinished product and is getting very very boring after turn 150+ each time you play.

Tech tree?
It looks like an exact clone of tech tree from Endless Space which is good but NOT for CIV genre of games,
Its far away from intuitive and looks like someone tried to be creative to make it look different the the regular CIV tech tree form...but why?
Its ugly now and you cant find anything in it.

Game help (CIV Pedia?) erm...well its nice to read about buildings but what do they do?

Wonders?
Wait...what wonders?
And where are they...oh yes. There are some special constructions but its very hard to make them out in the tech tree in first place to enable them to be built.

No need for trading anything with AI/other players.
There is plenty of resources and its just a matter of byilding your towns in few places and you dont need anything else.

It becomes a boring race for who will have more military units or who will achieve 'science-kind' of victory.

Oh...and the game tends to freeze and bug out occasionaly getting stuck  - you can still move and look around map or press ESC to get to the Menus but thats it...only thing left to do is 'save game' and restart the application.


In overall....unifinished product with significant lack in merit, very much overrated by who ever rated it officially - those listed in the 'REVIEW' bit as 9/10 recomendations must have taken good money to do so or they try to 'shine' by sticking themselves under a 'CIV' name.

TotalBiscuit - A cautious Recomendation = I am a big fan of TB but I wouldn't tag my name to this product even in such a cautious name...not untill they fix it and add more content that will make this game worth the money I spent  on it.

reviewText:
Very very disappointed.

I'm a big Civ fan, been playing since the origional and I love sci-fi so I was really looking forward to this game.

However instead I get a dumbed down version of Civ 5.
If you've got Civ 5, there is little to nothing to recommend you get this game instead.

Lets list the major issues:
1> AI still very poor
2> Terrain/Starting City placement even worse than Civ 5
3> Alien infestations can make it impossible to leave your base, or there can be no aliens near you at all.
4> 'Quests' with no explaination of where the rewards are coming from
5> Complete lack of anything resembling reality..... I can build satalites and missiles, but I can't build a basic scout plane or a tank......
6> Poor graphics, terrain types are not very well depicted. Hard to see a lot of features.
7> Lack of new features/gameplay. In fact its basically Civ 5 with a load of features cut out.
8> Tech (web) is basically the same old tech tree but more simple, yet made more confusing.
9> Unintuitve interface.

I'd like to include a list of good things about the game, but I'll let you know if I find anything.
I'm going to give it a few more hours and will update this if I change my mind, but I really doubt that I will.

reviewText:
Beyond Earth is stylistically and mechanically a Civilization 5 mod.
Basing the game on Civ5 is a good idea, but the game feels like Civ5 design principles held the game back.

There is a tech tree web, but the freedom this affords is all an illusion because all the victory conditions except total domination (capture all enemy capitals) are technology based.  This means two things: (1) the game is a technology race (2) you don't get to enjoy most of the tech tree, because most decisions are forced in order to win the tech race.

Pre-patch, there actually was a good mid-game military strategy.  But that got nerfed into oblivion.  So military option is a tech race, too.

Sid Meier has long been interviewed about why the Civ series does not continue into the future.  He has said that Civ game concept is to (re)play through world history.  So there is an overarching fear to not to change too much from original.  While I play these games a lot, Beyond Earth promised something fresh.  It isn't.
* Brand new foreign world or Civ 5 resources with different art and icons?  (There's oil and titanium, which serves the same role as aluminum...)  There are 3 faction specific
* Tech tree --> not really innovative for reasons above
* Combat -- this is stuck in Civ embark units mechanic -- it's 2600 and you don't start with hover tanks.
-- there are no melee naval units
-- your units upgrade for free with tech (hurrah ftw) but also your opponents (IMBA ftl)
* There is novel affinity/unit promotion system

On the whole, this game offers very little in the way of a new play experience.  It's mostly cosmetically atttactive TECH RACE.

reviewText:
I've finally started playing this game, although it's been waiting in my library for a while now. I kind of forgot about it, but I recently noticed there was a DLC out, right about the time I was looking for something new to play, so I figured I'd get the DLC and give this game its rightful chance.

I can't give you a thorough review yet, but I can tell you that at least so far (10 hours in), this game feels just like the previous games in the series, or at least like Civilization 2-5. I've never played the first, so I don't really know what it was like. I'll get to the specifics after spending some more time playing, but generally, it's pretty much what I was expecting, and what I suppose anyone who's ever played a Civilization game before should expect.

Anyway, I know this game wasn't received as well as the last couple of Civilization games, and honestly, if there's a good reason for that, I haven't found it yet. I'm writing these very lines after forcing myself to stop playing, so I could get some sleep before a long day tomorrow. I could have otherwise easily kept on playing for a few more hours at least.

More info to come as soon as I feel I have a good enough grasp of the specifics, especially in comparison to the previous games in the series.

Update (14h+):
While my general opinion of the game hasn't changed much since I started playing, I figured I'd share what I now consider to be its biggest flaw, which was also mentioned and discussed by many other reviewers. While the formula hasn't changed much since Civilization 5, the game's main backstory theme has, and in my opinion, it has changed for the worse. Up until Civilization 5, the series, at least for me, was about history, culture and progress. While Beyond Earth is also about progress, it lacks the other elements. Sure, each faction has its own history and culture, but those are totally alien and meaningless to me, as they're not an important part of the game, and I feel no urge to learn about them. If Civilization 5 was based, loosely as it was, on some true historical background, Beyond Earth is pure fiction in that regard. Some people may find this futuristic theme curious and refreshing, but I, for one, would rather have it the way it was before.

Having all that said, as of now, there's no other strategy game I'd rather play. Not even Civilization 5, which has my highest playing time count (500h+) on record ever since I installed Steam.

reviewText:
I made the mistake of pre-ordering this game based on how good Civ 5 is. I realize that Civ 5 with all expansions is a completely different and much better game than it was at release. Having paid twice as much as this game is frequently on sale for, I sure hope they release substantial fixes and improvements for free, rather than as relatively expensive expansion packs as they have in the past.

It's not Alpha Centauri, it's not Civ5. It's Civ 5 with a different skin and a few half baked ideas. It isn't fun. I've put hundreds of hours into Civ 5. I can't bring myself to put any more hours into this one. I gave it a fair chance I think, but I lose interest so fast.

EDIT 10-10-15: And just as I suspected, no real improvements to the base game. Instead they release a high priced expansion that fixes some things and further breaks others. Maybe by next Christmas they'll release another expansion that fixes this expansion, and maybe I'll pick that up on sale right before they release the third expansion.

reviewText:
At first glance the game does seem drastically different than Civilization 5. There seems to be quite a lot of negative reviews but I personally find it to be a very pleasant addition to the Civilization series. I started playing the civilization games way back when I was in middle school and Civilization 3 had just came out.

Here was my experience of this futuristic take on the civilization series:

At first I had a hard time trying to get focus on the game and understand what was going on. I played very on and off for a few days and stopped playing for about a week. I later resumed playing the game again and took the same approach I did to learning civilization 3. Once I understood the new mechanics and got a handle on the terrain, resources, improvements, and the daunting orbital aspect ( which actually turned out to be very simple to understand and is a fantastic element I have come to enjoy. Especially because you can create resources ;D ) so on and so forth of the intricate elements of the game. Once I played through one game, all the way (win or lose and I actually lost this one though it was close haha I started my first game on Vostok difficulty) I honestly have not been able to stop playing it. A lot of the nuisances that were present in civ 4 and civ 5 such as battling happiness and upgrading military units to compete with higher level ai (these are just a couple).

I really like how the virtues truly give you the ability to customize your sponsor (civilization). When the virtue tree has 2 bonuses branching to a higher tier bonus, you no longer need both of those bonuses to grab that higher tier and only need to pick one.

The way units upgrade is a really cool approach as too. Again, it gives you full customization of your nation. Even when behind you can still put up a fight, albeit a struggle, but it is doable and winnable. It also gives hope to being able to win a game when quite a ways behind. The instant upgrade of all units once the upgrade has been earned (affinity level reached a certain level for a particular unit) is a very nice adaptation. I remember in civ 5 losing games becuase I had no money to upgrade units and continue to fund new units.

Ultimately, I found this game to be very challenging, rewarding, and so many different ways to play the game and enjoy! I highly reccomend this game for someone willing to put in the time it takes to learn a game. Even if you are a civilization veteran, approach this game with some new eyes and it is all the more rewarding.

reviewText:
I love this game.

It is the first civ I've ever played, so those who find civ V better than BE, don't rage at me for this review. The game is nicely complex, the AI is good and graphics are not that bad.

Sure, there is some stuff that could use some fixing, probably they could add better diplomacy and the ability to select multiple units at once (micromanaging the stuff once you have 50+ units gets pretty tiresome), but otherwise the game is great. Sid Meier knows what he's doing. My only pet peeve is the normal price. 50€ is quite a lot.

Wait for the next sale and buy the game. It's definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Don't buy this game thinking it's going to be anywhere as good as Alpha Centauri.  It's not a worthy successor to Alpha Centauri and I don't even think it's a worthy successor to Civilization V.

It honestly feels like a reskin of Civ V; which would be fine if it was an expansion pack.  However, it's not an expansion pack; it is a full price game that should bring more to the table than what it does.  Civ V was a great game, but I already played it.  The changes Beyond Earth bring are not better, they're just different.

Pros:

Interface and game mechanics are similar enough to previous Civilization games that there isn't much of a learning curve.

Interesting Setting.

It's NEW

Cons:

Lack of cinematics: There is only one cinematic in the game: the intro.  Everything else is done through text boxes, with the occasional voice over.  Alpha Centauri was made fifteen years ago and had one for every wonder.

TEXT BOXES:  Congrats! You won the game!  Here is a text box explaining the ending(sort of).

Lack of voice acting:  There is less voice acting in this game than both Civ V and Alpha Centauri

Confusing world leaders, lack of story:  I haven't played Alpha Centauri in ten years, but I still remember most of the faction leader names.  I played Beyond Earth twenty minutes ago and I can't name one.

Diplomacy:  No united nations/ planetary council.  Some of the same bugs and AI annoyances from Civ V are present.

Tech Web: confusing, non-intuitive

Interface:  Hard to read sometimes.  Oh and if you're color blind you might find the game unplayable.

If you're a huge fan of Civilization you might love the game, but you may feel cheated if you pay full price for it.  If you're a huge fan of Alpha Centauri prepare to be let down.

reviewText:
Sid Meier should consider removing his name from this product.

Unlike Alpha Centari, or Civilization IV, who's production value drew a player into the world and made you care about what was going on, Beyond Earth is sterile, unimaginative, and process-oriented in the worst kind of way. It's like the developers started with a checklist and then made a game, instead of starting with a creative spark and figuring out how to make it work.

This game is a retread of old ideas, and it isn't fun. Not worth 50$ without a major overhaul.

Sid, I am not impressed.

reviewText: Currently the game feels as if the vanilla is stripped down to its bone. There are a couple of features that give it a different look and feel as opposed to Civ 5 and SMAC, which is a good thing. But I can't escape the feeling of wanting a more immersive experience in this game. Deciding for myself which way I would like to go, rather than founding myself lost in a maze of research goals, with a fixed capital city unable to move it, an AI randomly asking for 'favors' and declaring war the next turn or not really feeling connected with the building options. This all makes this a too confined experience. Simply give me a map editor, or some sort of option to increase my freedom of play.\n\nI seriously felt like I wanted to play Civ5 again, rather than continuing this game and after I noticed on the Community Hub that this game will be 'milked' with DLC incoming, I seriously advice to wait untill a hefty discount comes along. I'm sad that I can't give it an overall general recommendation, but I'm really hoping for a redemption patch in the future or some free or low-priced expansions.

reviewText:
Having been exited for this release for quite some time, I was not disappointed.  Beyond Earth is definitely a Civilization game, though there are many differences that set this game apart from its predecessors.  To keep this review relatively short, I'll make a list regarding the game based on what I experienced on my first full game of it.


- Similar to Civilization V's policies, Virtues allow you to pick and choose bonuses which will assist in the development of your civilization.  They are extremely well balanced and work well whether you focus mainly on one of the four categories (Might, Prosperity, Knowledge, Industry) or if you pick and choose throughout.  Synergy bonuses are given for both building wide or deep on the Virtue Tree.

- The technology web was very enjoyable for this type of a game.  The old technology tree worked extraordinarily well when Civilization was based on history, though the open web is an excellent change for a Sci-Fi futuristic 4X game.  You can, for the most part, pick and choose which technologies best suit the style of play that you are going for.

- Affinity, is somewhat similar to the Ideologies of Civilization V, in that it affects your relationship with others depending on which of the three that they have chosen from.  I focused on Purity, the affinity that seeks to keep humans human.  They seek to hold onto their culture and turn the newly colonized planet into a second Earth.  The other affinities are Harmony, which is the goal of integrating into the ecosystem of the planet, and Superiority, which is the modification of humanity via technology to reach a higher state of being.  Each affinity has it's own sets of bonus, special buildings, and unique units that give each and every affinity a different feel.

Though there are many other new features (and others that were cut) these were the three that I thought drastically differed from the Civilization games of the past.  This game is a lot of fun to play and I'm very excited to see the expansions that will be released for it.

Overall Rating: 9.5/10

reviewText: I'd like to suggest that anyone who played Alpha Centauri not buy Civilzation Beyond Earth. It has shook off all of its spiritual predecessors selling points. The distinctive characters have all become generic and lifeless. The frighting nature of the new alien world and its wild life have become plain big bigs and, most importantly, the strong sense of the dystopian civilisations struggling to survive on an alien world has been utterly lost. All these issues culminate into a bland, cookie cutter experience. It is possible that Fraxis intend to change things with future DLCs, but its a sad state of affairs when you spend $50 on a title that needs another $50 of investment before you get what was expected with the initial purchase. Do yourself a favour, spend $5 and boot up AC! ‪#‎BeyondEarth‬ ‪#‎NotAlphaCentauri‬ ‪#‎ThankGodICanClaimThisBackOnTax‬

reviewText:
There are a lot of good ideas here, but most of them feel half-♥♥♥♥♥. Here are my main gripes, based on 10 hours of play.

- At times UI is trying to be cool looking rather than functional. For example, minimap is quite small and contrary to store page screenshots, the color scheme has been changed so that continents and oceans are different shades black and gray. Not to mention you can see through the map which adds to confusion. Colors all in all are quite annoying. Sometimes miasma is quite hard to see, and resources of xenomass easily disappear into green mess that the map sometimes is (at least on lush biome I've been playing on).

- Aliens are quite interesting but in my opinion they should be more varied and far more aggressive (note: I'm playing with frenzied aliens" option on). Even when I killed them in the dozens and raided their nests they didn't seem to get more aggressive in return. Even AI civilizations are too passive. I can't remember a single instance where a civilization declared a war on another (in my 10 hours of playtime)

Devoting themselves to the memory of Gandhi and his empire in the hopes of one day bringing him to this new planet.\nLittle do the colonists know that their so-called Progenitor" predecessors on their new homes were actually early attempts from Gandhi to conquer other planets..."

reviewText:

The publishers are laughing all the way to the bank, as there's no ability to get a refund, but God don't buy this unless it's on special or you've waited a long time for it and have expendable cash. Cause honestly, it has less features than the fully expanded civ 5 game.

Some backstory, or fleshing out, of the factions would be good? Perhaps some scenarios, campaigns or something? This feels like the barebones have been implemented, and they've asked their friends to try it and see how it goes. Rather than released for the OBSCENE price in Australia as it has been.

shame on you. SHAME.

reviewText:
I am hugely disappointed, to say the least. I have waited for the reincarnation of Alpha Centauri for all these years, and have bought this game at the first possible occasion. What I got in the end was just a dumbed down version of Civilization V, which was (in my opinion) just a simplified version of Civilization IV in the first place. Alpha Centauri was an etalon, a perfect game, which required only a graphics' revamp perhaps. There is nothing new in Beyond Earth, neither it has all the brilliant features of Alpha Centauri (unit constructor, terraforming, unique leaders' personalities etc.). Some people say that they are really happy that they never played Alpha Centauri. Poor souls, they even don't know what they missed. Even when not compared to its spiritual predecessor, Beyond Earth remains just an empty husk, and no pearls will appear from it.

I WILL play this game, and WILL try to decribe all its cons and (if I find any) pros in more detail. Affinity system isn't bad, but it's more boring and less flexible than the social engineering system used in Alpha Centauri. So far, I consider Beyond Earth just a worthless waste of hard-earned money. It seems that the developers haven't even tried to make something worth the name of a successor to Alpha Centauri.

P.S. This is my appeal to the people considering buying Beyond Earth. Go and buy Alpha Centauri instead.

I regret spending $50 for what feels like a polished beta of a game.

Pros:
-Custom Civs and the tech web lead to unpredicatable gameplay with better replayability
-Alien AI actually feel threatening and pose a challenge for a good portion of the game
-Affinity-specific units look cool and are powerful; I was able to 1HKO an enemy outpost being built with my Harmony Ultimate unit.
Cons:
-Much easier/AI much dumber than Civ 5
-Gameplay changes like Happiness to Healthiness and lack of depth (no tourism/religion or equivilent) make the game feel dumbed down/lacking
-Lack of unit diversity; everyone practically has the same units until they start specializing down their Affinity; even then the majority of units are just reskins with some different stats.
-Color pallette is much darker; I personally found it to be unattractive after a long session."

reviewText: This is of course subject to change once it's balanced, but right now I do not recommend the game. This is coming from someone who happily has played 400+ hours of Civ V too.\n\nIt feels like a poorly balanced Civ V mod. There are some novel things in there - the affinity trees for instance are pretty neat. The questing (done better in Endless Legend) is also ok as is the esponiage. But there are too many annoyances - health severely limiting growth, overly aggressive native life forms, oribtal layer not being very well developed, bad AI - combined with balance problems and a real lack of personality make this one a pass. Frankly, I've found myself clicking next turn" over and over again because the game punishes you from exploring
date: the health problems prevents you from conquering and there's nothing else to do. What's the most maddening thing is that Civ V encountered - and then patched OUT - many of these same issues. There's no excuse for them to happen in Beyond Earth.\n\nThe real killer is the lack of personalities. Yeah
recommended: I know that this game isn't a remake of SMAC but it's supposed to be inspired by it. Well
hoursPlayed: the thing that SMAC did that was so innovative was to give each faction a very distinct - almost unique - personality. The wonder movies
voteText: diplomacy and even the tech tree descriptions were all written around those personalities. Instead of copying this strength
helpfulPercent: the factions here are all faceless until far too late into the game (and by then it's too late). It's an absolute deal killer.\n\nEven after patches it's still a collection of half-baked ideas that simply don't work together. There are far

reviewText:
Pros-
*Choices at the start of the game - (e.g. +2 food, production ect in each city) with quests" giving optional bonuses for different buildings (e.g. an extra point of culture for monuments or no maintenence cost for them) allowing greater specialisation. you are never limited by the fact there is only 8 factions. Unlike civ 5 where some factions were especially powerful perhaps even inbalanced.

*Ideologies - The three main ideologies are all realistic
date: compelling and ultimately lead to different styles of play and win conditions. Solving one of my main gripes with CIv 5 in that your civ almost always favoured a victory so doing your best to win involved simply repeating a tried and tested strategy.\n\n*Tech web - While confusing at first glance and for a couple of playthroughs time it really does allow you to specialise. In civ 5 that one player with the highest science got first dibs on every wonder
recommended:
not anymore!

*Aliens replace barbarians - More than just a cosmetic change the aliens are not inherently hostile and will treat you differently based on how you treat them. Some are hilariously overpowered at the start of the game but can be avoided. The difficulty setting probably has an effect too.

*Orbital layer - Allows another layer of military conquest where you can rain death from above with massive units or orbital weapons. But also satilites that can create new resources on blank tiles allowing you to develop the map in very new ways. I would love to see this be pushed further to allow a more earthlike climate for the purity ideology.

Cons-
*The game is outright missing some of the features that came with DLC for civ 5 and will probably end up being DLC later down the line. Including: religion
hoursPlayed: natural wonders
voteText: world congress
helpfulPercent: tourism/culture victory.\n\n*The game does not have distinct phases like Civ 5 which were based on different eras of human civilisation. As such it the game doesnt really have the same flow of technological advancement making it hard to see how well you are doing in comparison to your rivals. In times of peace this can make the game feel extremely detached almost like no progress is being made at all

reviewText: Though not without its flaws, Beyond Earth is superior to Civilization V (itself a great game), and the closest thing to a modern Alpha Centauri on the market.  Its rich graphics, audio, and art proved delightful, leaving me wanting more.  The formula of turn-based strategy may be archaeic, but it still lets me get up for another beer or drop everything when the wife is calling.  My initial frustration at the near-identical gameplay mechanics to previous Civ iterations was overcome by the smooth graphics and slick execution.  If you're a Sid Meir fan, Civ player, or just generally like turn based strategy, this game is the best available circa 2014/15!

reviewText:
I had lots of fun beating Beyond Earth. It plays a lot like a full conversion mod for Civilization V, but to say that's all it is betrays the beautiful restructuring of game mechanics that this version posseses. The game feels more dynamic (thanks to a tech web, as opposed to a tech tree), making each playthrough a completely different game. While Civilization V (and its predecessors) was completely addicting, Beyond Earth makes each game a radically different experience, something that Civ 5 did way better than any of the other installments of the franchise.

That being said, I wasn't particularly fond of the glitches. I've heard a few people mention them before, but when I sat down and played through Beyond Earth, I found them to be quite bothersome. None were game-breaking, but often they were reptitive annoyances that are completely circumventable... once you learn what they are. The achievement counters also seem to be off, as I found myself occassionally getting two points for certain things when one normally ought to receive only one... Not that I'm complaing about that though!

And the achievements are indeed a stellar part of this game. Civilization V was the first game to add them, and they often felt very grind-y and unneccessary. Beyond Earth slimmed most of those bad ones out, leaving in just a few for those gamers dedicated enough to endure the small bits of grind and reach 100% completion.

At $49.99 currently, Beyond Earth has quite a hefty price tag. I'd personally wait until a 50% off or more sale, just to feel like you had no doubt that buying this game was money well spent. If you can get it for that price or less, it's simply a steal.

reviewText:
This game is EXACTLY like Civ V, but with less features.
Here's what's similar but reskinned, renamed, or reorganized.
-culture is the same
-science is the same, just a web instead of a tree
-ideologies, unit upgrades, and unit promotions are rolled up into one and replaced with affinities.
-

Here's what's new:
-orbital layer
-aliens instead of barbarians.
-miasma
-spies are more important (actually a big deal)

Here's what's missing:
-city states (stations are a downgrade in complexity)
-less civs
-no luxury resources
-no world congress, in fact diplomacy is useless. I've finished a game without ever doing any diplomatic stuff.
-no religion
-a UI that helps.
-victory conditions that make sense

Basically this game is a reskinned and simplified version of Civ V.

reviewText:
Bought and played the game the day it was released.  Played it for a few days and stopped.  Year later I picked it up again and after a few hours I remembered why I stopped.

Fun at first, but after a while the issues creep in.  The game is a decent improvement from Civ 5. The mechanics are identical but they were never a problem, graphics/animations/sound are good, the units are exactly what you’d expect from a Civ game (with a few interesting twists), and the tech web is an interesting addition.

But, as with the last Civ game, performance gets exponentially worse the longer you play it.  I play marathon games, and by turn 900 it’s taking 2+ minutes for all NPCs to go through their turns.  The interface is clunky and unintuitive – worse than Civ 5’s since they’ve crammed in more things.  Navigating the the planet is a chore - aliens (like the barbs in Civ 5) are annoying, there are miasmas every other tile (which damage your troops), the other 1/3 of the tiles are canyons or mountains which your troops can't traverse (you'd think if you have the tech to colonize another planet you might be able to get over a hill).  And ffs let me rebind keys.  Let me use WASD to control the camera and hotkey things the way I want.

reviewText:
Many reviewers expected Beyond Earth to be Alpha Centauri 2, which it is not. Neither it is a Civilization V mod. It IS a new game, which, although share some features of Civ5 (hex grid, battle system, unit classes, wonders, resources, neutral units) and AC (ideologies, sci-fi techs), is played differently.

The main focus in BE is on affinity (ideology) choices. As you specialise towards a particular victory type, you need to focus on specific technologies. Each next progress level gives you an affinity point, which in turn provides you with useful perks (upgrades) for your units + bonuses. These specific perks will radically change your units as you progress on specific affinity path (alien-like units, machine-like units or human units).

The culture works in a similar way as in Civ5. After certain level of culture is reached, you can acquire virtues (4 virtue categories – Might, Prosperity, Knowledge and Industry - in 3 tiers), which work in a similar way as social policies in Civ 5. There are synergy bonuses for focusing on same category virtues or same tier virtues.

Also, there are quests, research pods and exploration areas, which substantially can boost your progress over the time. As well as the destruction of aliens and alien nests, especially with certain Might virtues.

The victory types are following: Domination - conquer all other players; Contact - contact alien civilization; Transcendence (requires Harmony specialisation)  - civilization fully adapts to the new planet and becomes enlightened; Promised Land (requires Purity specialisation) - bring Earth population to the new planet; Emancipation (requires Supremacy specialisation) - conquer (free") Earth.

So
date: it's a completely different setting in Beyond Earth. And you require a different approach from what you're used to in Civ5. Although
recommended: the same basic rules are still in place: e.g.
hoursPlayed: a) food is population
voteText: population is everything; b) science is progress
helpfulPercent: progress is victory.\n\nWhen I played Beyond Earth for the first time
votesHelpful: there were certain innovations that annoyed me
votesTotal: but after playing a while
votesFunny:
I got used to them and they started to make sense for me.
For example:

1. Technology tree is replaced with technology web
commentsCount: which makes it hard to find things

reviewText:
Where to start with this title? Firstly I'll get it out of the way and say it's a good game, no question. It's far from perfect but if you like civilization then you will like this title.

I fear the single downfall of this game lies in the development. It's as if Firaxis did not have a large enough budget to fully complete this game to make it unique. There are a couple things that bother me with the game so far, the voice acting and it's oh-so-similar CIV 5 likeness. Maybe this was my own fault coming in to this game expecting something COMPLETELY different or something similar to Alpha Centauri. Not that any of these reasons are terrible but I think I worked it up in my head that this game was going to be the perfect blend of Alpha Centauri And Civ 5. It's not, it's good but far from a breakout series.

The sole thing I would say about the voice acting is that it needs more work. Each civ does have a unique voice actor but when wonders are complete or you're read a definition you get the voice actor who also voices the Kavithan Protectorate. Should this bother me? I think I was just spoiled with Civ 4 and Civ 5.

On to the good stuff - There were a few things I really liked almost immediately after starting. The futuristic theme lends more capabilities and options for the familiar civ player to start with. I love planetfall, this is basically the enactment of your ship touching down and establishing your first colony on the planet you choose. Before this you are allowed to tweak how you start and what starting benefits your sponsor and civilization get. These options range from scientific, cultural to militaristic benefits to help you mould your civ before you start planetfall, Pretty cool stuff.

The addition to upgrading your military was a very nice change. Depending on how you steer your civilization this can define what type of militaristic units you get. The 3 directions you can split in to are determined by how you research your technologies. Researching technologies can give you points towards an affinity which can affect your military in very unique ways. This is in addition to veterancy which was not removed but instead improved on.

Overall I would say this is a great title. I have been playing it since release and don't foresee stopping any time soon.

Go out and get it!

reviewText:
Beyond Earth feels like an entry title into the series. With that I mean that it sure is a nice game on some fronts and it rolls with the alien theme, it let's you down if you are looking for that Brave New World vibe.

The game feels and acts like a reskinned civ 5. The units let your expectations down, the year is somewhere in the future, and at this point still you have 'melee' units which in civ 5 style exhange hits with other units. The addition of satelites is a nice touch, however that feels like its the only thing added. You still have your Civ 5 units being a Melee unit, Ranged unit, Artilery unit and cavalery unit. However instead of the upgrades of these units being tied to your technology they are now tied to your affinity (basicly your ideology).

How I do like the affinity system it does force your research, and strategy with that into a singular path. Since discovering certian technologies grant you affinity points you are forced to pick those techs up, which give you a false hope of an immense tech web with lots of choices. On top of this you'll find that (especcially) on higher difficulties that you don't have a free choice of affinity, with that your playstyle as well, either. You will be looking at what strategic resources are nearby and you will pick the affinity that goes with the specific strategic resource which happens to be in abbundance near your landing zone.

On top of this the unique feel you used to have for your civilization is gone. Leaders talk less and feel less interactive as well. Furthermore instead of the leader sitting in their Throne room" they now just show the leader without any background. The uniqueness of your civilization and your games you'll play are gone as well since there are just 8 factions. If you enjoy playing larger maps then these games will always be with the same factions. Factions have a random personality now as well it seems
date: so no more war mongering shaka.\n\nAlong with the uniqueness of your civ missing
recommended: you'll find yourself looking for a lot more if you compare this to Civ 5. The victory system is simplified now
hoursPlayed: you have 3 basic victory types
voteText: 1 is bound to your affinity (basicly build a wonder after researching the right techs)
helpfulPercent: 1 is bound to finding an artifact using the new scout system and the final one is domination. However the first two victories basicly feel like research X asap and perform action Y asap after that. So dumbed down you have 2 victory paths which is a huge letdown to the 4 victories in civ 5
votesHelpful:
which also felt unique in their playstyle.

Performance wise civ BE runs great. I have had no crashes and it doesn't seem very taxing on the machine either. The game looks very nice from an observers viewpoint. However from a players viewpoint this is no longer the case. Be prepared for a lot of blue. The techweb feels like a blue hive which includes vague options and lacks color in general. You really can't find any tech or wonder or any other distinction in the tech web easily. On top of this the overall view of the game is messy. You cant really see terrain clearly and this results in you hovering with your mouse over all the terrain to see the yields (or turn the show yields option on).

All in all this game is a great let down for the expectations set up by its predecessor. If you are new to the series you can pick this up to get a general feel of the Civ series. However your bucks are better spent on the full edition of civ 5 which all in all still feels like a superior game. Rating = 4 / 10

reviewText:
The biggest disappointment. A massive dropped ball. The things they could've done but instead they chose to reskin and strip out core mechanics from Civ V... probably to drip feed through as DLC.

A game franchise I thought I could trust. All you game companies are just painting yourselves up to be the same.


What's wrong with this game? Lack of variety, no real... civ feel. The tech web sucks, the interface sucks and the graphics for the planet sucks. The opportunity to have no realistic limit on technology, to incorporate some sort of alien interactions to the game etc... and this is the best they can do?

This game is an insult to gamers and I urge you not to pay full price for this. I'd pay max £10 in it's current state. It's a sorry addition to this great franchise and the excuse of this being a spinoff from the main civ series does not wash it's filthy hands clean.

reviewText:
It's hard to describe this game and give it a grade. On the one hand, it was a lot of fun playing through my first victory and going through the tech tree and so forth as Kavitha. But it just felt so....Civ V-like. Yes, the graphics are different, the sponsors are different, and there's different buildings, units, and wonders. But the mechanics feel like Civ V-reskin.

First off the good stuff: I like how the minor powers/city states only occupy one tile. You were probably annoyed one way or another when Monaco took that fountain of youth tile or another natural wonder. It's good to see that the sponsors get a lot of land to use. Also, I like the outpost criteria. I think that should be in Civ 6. Giving an output/settlement a few turns to fully develop is something unique. Rome wasn't built in a day right? :)

I also really like the quotes.

Now the things I don't like: boring leaders (they sound dull and uninspiring), boring units (there's only to be 3 types of units, vs unique units for each civ in Civ V), boring music (I played my own music when I play, and I  - Civ V's music was awesome with the peace and war themes), boring wonders (I had to look through all the wonders the first time, although it's quite easy to see that the ones that need more production are the wonders), some virtues are OP (propserity - bottom right with -25% health - and the other health benefits in that tree, make that area the new Tradition tree. YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT IF YOU WANT TO WIN. YOU HAVE NO CHOICE, unless you want to enter -20 health), and by far, this feels like an unfinished game. When I won through victory, the ending was so anticlimatic, and I went That's it?". It's quite obvious that similar mechanics like religion will be in the game eventually: I want to worship Space Gandhi. But until I can
date: I can't really recommend this game at the regular price.\n\nReview subject to change with future patches and expansions."

reviewText:
I usually do not write reviews of games, but the many negative reviews suprises me, and I feel that this game deserves better than that: In my opinion, this version of Civilization is the best one ever.
I rarely complete a regular CIV 5 game, as I usually find that it has too many things to manage. Also, I am a sucker for thematically games, and regular CIV 5 just does not hit it for me (Bismarc founding religions BC??).
CIV BE on the other hand, is more streamlines with less to manage without sacrificing having to choose how to build your civilization. The concepts of non-linear techs gives so much more when it comes to customizability. On the thematically side, affinities, the freedom of the techtree, non-historically bound factions and the concept of alien worlds gives me much more than regular CIV ever did.
I keep my fingers crossed for an expansion, as there are so many possibilities within the frame of the theme.

reviewText:
I've never played Civ 5 only Civ 1, Civ 3, Civ Revolutions, FreeCiv and Civ 4 beyond the Sword. Which I think is one of the reasons I really like Civilization: Beyond Earth.

The one unit per tile is a massive improvement over using squares. No more doom stacks... the sci fi setting makes it as there no more archers that can fire across the English Channel in this game. The lack of historical figures is an improvement over using historical characters. It tended to make the game of CIv abit funny having a faction leader that never ages lol. Sorry this is coming from somebody who plays Paradox and Total War titles.

The affinity system and the new and improved tech tree are well executed.

I was a bit wary about buying this with some of the mixed reviews. But so far and  an hours play time in I am enjoying it. Mind you  I have not played CIv 5 so the criticism that CIv Be is a glorified mod is understandable.

This game can only get even better with some more expansions.

Bought this on sale at 50% because I never pre order games.

reviewText:
Tons of hours off-line.

Alright, so here are the questions I wanted to ask before buying this game.

WOW, IS THE GAME REALLY AS BAD AS THE RATINGS SUGGEST???

Most (not all) of the negative ratings are people uber ♥♥♥♥♥♥ they paid $50-60 dollars for the base game back in the day.  If you paid $50-60 for the base game, you'd be uber ♥♥♥♥♥♥, too.  If, however, you paid $20 like me (or even less with recent sales), you'd be fine with your purchase.  The base game really isn't that bad; it's not particularly memorable, but pay $15-20, and you should avoid any buyer's remorse.


DOES THE DLC HELP? IT'S KIND OF EXPENSIVE.

Yes! Rising Tide boosts Beyond Earth from an okay game to a very good game.  If you even remotely liked Beyond Earth, pick up Rising Tide immediately.  If you have neither, you should be able to get both Beyond Earth and Rising Tide together for around $40-50 in a future sale.  While the DLC might have too high a price tag, the two items combined are definitely worth $40-50.


LOTS OF NEGATIVE REVIEWS ARE SAYING TO STICK WITH CIVILIZATION V.  SHOULD I BOTHER GETTING BEYOND EARTH IF I ALREADY HAVE CIV V?

Most defintiely.  Beyond Earth is NOT just a poor man's Civ V with a space skin thrown on.  Instead, I would say it's built on a Civ V chassis.  Players will recognize many of the same concepts and game mechanics, but also notice significant differences.

Just a few:

1) aliens" function quite differently from "barbarians" in older games

2) the tech "tree" is really more of a "web" now
date: and many of the technological choices have no equivalent in previous Civ games.  They didn't take the existing tree and say
hoursPlayed: let's just call it 'space bronze working' now."\n\n3) affinity levels -- how your civilization will relate to the Old Earth and your new home -- have a significant impact on the types of buildings
voteText: military units
helpfulPercent: etc available to you.\n\n4) there are some cool new types of victory scenarios.  Ahhh
votesHelpful:
nothing like the feeling of sending giant alien hybrids through a warp gate back to old Earth to "emancipate" them from their petty bickering.


It's a decent base game
votesTotal: well worth a $15-20 investment.  As with Civ V
votesFunny: I think it will become a truly great game once all the DLC dust has cleared.  Jump on the bandwagon now and enjoy the ride."

reviewText:
First of all the game is not bad per se but for me it is lacking overall in general and especially compared to its predecessor Civilization V.

The first thing you will realize is that most of the game is just like Civ V so there is not really a change there. But unlike Civ V, especially with all its addons, has a lot more to offer than Beyond Earth. The different civs are only a few and not really interesting. The difference between the civs is also negligible. The progression via affinity according to Supremacy, Harmony, or Purity is a nice idea but they are only 3 options compared to the numerous in Civ V via religion or culture. If you wanted you could win the game within a short time because the different goals, with the exception of domination maybe, is fairly easy. The tech you need to research does not take too long and then, if you have a strong town with good production, build the wonder fairly quickly and after about 75 turns it is over. Meaning the computer can also win easily in higher difficulty. I do not know if the AI actually does that because I did not get to those above normal difficulties yet. Marathon feels like normal speed in Civ V and is over quickly as well.

The diversity of units is very limited. You basically get 1 unit of each type. 1 ship, 1 plane, 1 artillery, 1 infantry and so on.

In general diversity is what I think is the problem that is most lacking. Nothing that they cannot add with mods or updates but at this point I rather play Civ V or Endless Legends.

reviewText:
I'm giving this a 7 out of 10, because as a stand-alone game, C:BE a good 4X strategy game. But, I'm so used to the masterpiece that is Civilization 5 : Brave New World, that this rendition sadly pales into insignificance. Many of the features that made Civ 5 what it was have either been heavily simplified or removed entirely - good examples being the unit variety and faction identities/bonuses.

Good/New features :

I like the addition of the orbital layer - it adds another dynamic to empire building and warfare.
The new Affinities (Ideologies) are a different spin on Civ 5, and I think do give you a feel of what your Civ represents in terms of values.
Miasma - it feels like a major pain to start out, and if you play as Harmony, you can turn it to your advantage - a nice touch.
The Virtues tree (social upgrades) are a nice touch giving you the option to progress either in a single tree or multiple trees - each having bonus boosts (i.e. you get bonuses for spreading across multiple trees - unlike Civ 5).
The Quests - it adds a nice way to customise buildings to your specific playstyle, and gives nice little boosts to your empire. Ultimately though, it's a mechanism to reduce the number of buildings in the game.
The favour system in diplomacy is a nice touch. If you don't need anything from another faction, they trade you an IOU which can be called in later.
The visual appeal is a nice change from dull and boring earth :o)  Although, the graphics overall aren't really an upgrade over Civ 5 (not that it was needed tbh).

Things that disappoint me :

The tech web - although a decent idea, it just seems to be a random collection of upgrades that you stumble into. I never get a feel that I'm progressing towards something meaningful. Example : In Civ 5, acquiring Dynamite was a major boost for your Artillery capabilities, and you would often divert resources to getting it as early as possible if you were planning a war. You don't get that feeling in C:BE.

The wonders are........Meh. They are small and fairly insignificant boosts that have little synergy with each other. Again, Civ 5 often required you to build/acquire certain wonders to achieve certain victories.

The lack of atmosphere". This is a new planet shrouded in mystery! The quest system is good for customisation
date: but they could have done so much more with it to give you that feeling that this is a weird and wonderful new place that you have to grapple with to get the most out of it. The Aliens are basically the "Barbarians" of Civ 5 - but they seem to flip a coin as to whether or not to attack you. Once you get to mid-game
recommended: they are irrelevant as a force - you might as well terminate them on sight
hoursPlayed: even playing as Harmony! Would have been much better if they made the natural inhabitants an AI-only faction in their own right
voteText: and link quests to them depending on your Affinity.\n\nThe "health" system. It's basically "happiness" from Civ 5
helpfulPercent: but seems to be more forgiving. You can expand very aggressively in C:BE and not suffer too much. If you did that in Civ 5
votesHelpful: you'd find life very difficult if your people weren't happy. The "softening" of this expansion bottleneck means that you are engaging far less with your neighbours to acquire happiness or manipulate the game in your favour via a league of nations/UN - oh wait
votesTotal:
luxury goods don't exist anymore either. Why do I need to talk to anyone again?

The NPC stations; the C:BE equivalent of City States. They are a trading option for a single trade route - nothing more. You don't fight over them. They don't fight for you. They don't consume land and foil your best laid expansion plans. You can't take them over. They don't give you a bigger voice at the table of international diplomacy - nope...they just sit there and give you a few extra resource points - and if you're unlucky they appear out of the blue and stop you from planting an outpost where you want it. Meh.

Economy - I never feel like Energy (Gold) is a bottleneck. If you had an abundance of gold in Civ 5
votesFunny: you could do so much with it. If you weren't a gold friendly faction
commentsCount: you'd sometimes struggle to make ends meet - to field that Dynasty crushing army.  Where there were big gold sinks in Civ 5 like maintaining alliances and control over city states
column16: upgrading units etc - the absence of this limits the use of excess energy to rush buying units and buildings.  So far - Energy is just something I casually look at. It's rarely in the negative per turn. It's just not a resource that needs to be carefully managed like in Civ 5.\n\nLack of unit diversity - There are not many units at all. Only different ways to customise them via increases in Affinity. It's like the buildings - less of them
column17: but you can customise them.\n\nAll in all I'm disappointed - After Civ 5 and X-COM
column18:
Firaxis were the only software house I'd ever pre-order anything from. I'll be thinking twice now.

That said - this game does have potential for modding and future expansions. My advice is to park it until that happens. Civ 5 only became truly great after the second expansion.

For people who are new to the Civ franchise
column19: you'd probably enjoy this game.  For Civ 5 veterans like myself
column20: it's a bit of a let down that leaves you chomping at the bit for an expansion."

reviewText:
Hello readers.

At the time of making this, I have had only 6 or so hours of game time. Normally this would be far to little to write accurate review, and you are right!

The first thing I did when I start the game was of course the settings, see how everything is set. First thing I noticed, no 1920x1080 resolution supported in full screen. I got confused, which game in 2014 didn't have it?!
I went on the web and found out this is normal for those with a specific refresh rate of a their monitor, I guess this somehow got pets the superb Q/A testing.

Fine, I will play it in windows mode

I looked at the choices I could get, and I noticed that you only have 8 Civs, this was kinda mediocre to me when you compare it to the previous game, and because they aren't  the 'known' civ's of the world, it felt very lacking.
The bonuses of each civs as well made them far less unique then I thought. But ill just go ahead and pick something.

After 'personalising' my faction ( which with the limited choices you cannot really call it that ) I entered  the game!

First thing I noticed, no awesome voice overs of William Morgan Sheppard or  Leonard Nimoy.
I started, settled, and explored with my unit, already felt a bit CiV 5 but that doesn't have to be bad.
I found something to use my explorer on, started to dig around and then it already started, next turn, next turn and next turn. Not much going on.

I started fiddling with the UI and noticed so much is missing and its all very blend, while in previous civs it all looked quite nice with art and stuff, this game is just made out of bars that anyone can do! The minimap is very annoying coloured, everything is very dark which means you got to suck the player in for that next turn.

Then suddenly other civs joined, landed on the map and I could see where they were,  meaning no exploring what so ever to find that other civilization. Played some more, heard my first research completed, no cool pop up, a very average voice over ( sorry.. ) made a new city with a oversized settler, started seeing the other civs units, all the same, as me, no uniqueness. I started looking some more throught the UI, Affinity, Virtues, Researching.

I had a quest popping up asking me for a station to drop near me, I made my choice, it dropped down and well that was it, you can trade with this station but for the rest it does nothing. Imagen a city state without workers and units around it while growing and feeling sort of alive, no here they are just dead buildings. Speaking of quests, at first, I loved em, they do give a bit of lore BUT they the bonus is always very small, in the end, its just picking something you go for or what you need. You quickly just pick and forget.

While I don't mind the Web of researching, its not good and it is very boring, while you see cool artworks from CiV 5, this again feels really cheap.
Other civs started to ask for things, when I read what they had to say, it was pure copy paste from CiV 5.. and that is when I started to have enough. And I saw flaw after flaw and flaw. Wonders, I build them, never knowing I actually made one! Why? They aren't 'wonderful' I honestly thought they were just a building! When I started upgrading units, ah a bigger gun! Awesome!...

150 turns in, trade spam became annoying, you can have as low as 2 trade routes on a city.

(as you can tell by my writing I start to become a bit more unforgiving, exactly how I felt during my play session for the first time )

I noticed that sure, affinity will make your units look different in end game, but they will still be exactly the same as any other civ that has it, while I know that in CiV 5, modern age it is the same as well, before that you had a couple of ages feeling relatively unique compared to the rest. Mods made this even better.

As you have noticed I said nothing about the aliens, that's because they have nothing to do with the game, they are there, being annoying but nothing else, even when you kill nest after nest, nothing.

I then gave up on the game, it was just to boring, to tedious and it has no soul, i feels like almost no effort was made into this.

I do have one positive, I have to say, is the music, its beautiful  and I am 100% sure, that's the only reason I played it for this long.

I will not recommend this to anyone, not at full price, perhaps at 10 euros max. I will also never recommend this to a CiV Veteran, because he will see this too. As far as it goes for me, this is a MOD, and a bad one at that.

I still cannot get this game to play, even after applying all of the suggestions from all online sources I can find. It gets to the same place every time and freezes. After starting up, and going through the setup screens, I get to the screen that has the << Excerpts from Colony Archives >> ... and that's where it stop working, every time. Here is the info:

I'm running Windows 7 Professional, fully up to date with SP 1, on a 4GB 64-bit Intel Core i7 w/ 8 2.8 GHz cores and an NVIDIA GeForce GTS 250 diaplay adapter. I've tried each of two screens, one a 1920x1080 Sharp HDMI TV and the other a 1680x1050 ASUS VK222H, and I've tried both in combination.

I haven't added my report to the throng of similar reports already filed, but I would just like others to know that having this kind of problem is a possibility. I would love to play this game - I loved Alpha Centauri, and Civ 5 - and I hope this kind of problem can be fixed for all of us who would like so much to play the game. Fixed, and soon.

reviewText: I foolishly decided to trust the positive reviews and am now left with a buggy and to be honest, a rushed game. Sid meier's is making a habit of releasing unfinished games that require patching and then releasing a paid patch cough cough brave new world to try and drain his fans of their earnings. This game is lets face it dull, the graphics are vibrant but not in the good way as i often felt my eyes being strained. The ads show off a wide new range of victories but once you play the game you'll know thats its just bs. reviewText:
I was so hyped for this game, i'm a Civ veteran, been playing every game in the series since the first Civilization game. I have over 150 hours on Civ5. So i was looking forward to this game as an advancement to the franchise.

What i got was a cash in on a famous franchise, that has all the mechanics of civ 5, but none of the personality or features. And some people will say that it will get better in the expansions, but even civ 5 vanilla had more soul, features, and appeal than this game does in it's current state. It feels hurried and un finished.

To put it in perspective, i have more hours put into Euro Truck Simulator 2 than this game =/

Very disappointed, i feel a little betrayed by one of my favorite game studios.

reviewText:
This is easily the weakest Civ in modern memory. It would have made an excellent mod for Civ V, but is absolutely not worth paying the full price for. If you are a massive Civ fan, it might be a good purchase but Civ V still remains a stronger game in every single measurable aspect.

Presumably, until the first DLC release there are only eight playable civs. However, it does not make a difference as the civs do NOT have unique units. Instead, what units you can build depends on your 'affinity'. As you level up through the enormously complex tech tree, you will gain points towards one of three affinity trees depending on what skills you train- Harmony, Purity or Supremacy. Essentially this means that there are actually only an absolutely pathetic three sets of units possible to build.

Wait until the Christmas specials for this one, folks.

reviewText: The interface is awkward and poorly implemented and the mechanisms that allow a win are ill defined and vague.  The appearance of the units and cities is nice, but as it is non-traditional it is difficult to determine what is happening.  The terrain of the alien world is unsurpringly alien... but this means there is no easy way to determine what value a patricular tile has.   Ranged unites seem to have their ranged attacks modified by terrain type i.e. on a hill you shoot further... but it is not always obvious why your ranged units suddenly can't engage targets at there normal maximum range.  The diplomcy AI is fickle in the extreme... allied and trade partnered with someone throughout 300 turns then without any indication as to what offense you've given they say You've gone too far I declare war!" This might be realistic in human politics but is certainly no fun to play."

reviewText: Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth, takes the Civilization franchise into the Final Frontier. Settling an alien world, with new choices, familiar themes, allies and adversaries, I found the AI to be more sophisticated than even Civilization V, with alien creatures capable of wiping out soldiers with a single strike in the beginning of your campaign. You must be on your guard as the terrain itself can be hostile, with miasma deposits that damage you when you get near. The research tree is much more extensive than previous Civilization games, and is more dynamic, as opposed to linear, with branches and leaves to the research tree. I found this game to be more difficult than V, but it has a decent tutorial system to help you through the transition. I think for hard core lovers of the Sid Meier's Civilization series, you will have those who love it, and those who hate it, due to the changes. I think it is a pretty fun game, even with it's new features.
