reviewText:
Something is seriously missing from this game that was in every other Civ.
I can still spend 10+ hours playing a game of Civ 5, but this game... after an hour I'm bored and wondering what's on TV.

Pros:
- I didn't know any of the techs or buildings so I had to read all the descriptions which was kind of novel for me.
- The UI is pretty to look at.
- Not as bad as the latest Sim City.

Cons:
- Tech web is confusing.  Why not leave it as a progressive tree??
- Flat, over simplified UI.  I really have to learn what all these symbolic monochromatic icons mean?
- Visually, the map is hard to look at and determine what land types and resources are what.  Not enough contrast.
- Units upgrade automatically and they all get the same upgrade.
- Of the three games I've played, I lost all of them very abruptly with no explanation why, or inclination that i was about to lose.
- Very few and bland wonders, units, civs.  Let me guess - DLC?
- Game pace (techs, building times, etc) seems off to me.  It might be the way I'm playing though.

- Missing a certain 'je ne sais quoi' (I'm totally serious about this.  play the game and you will see.)

reviewText: It's totally proper to say that Beyond Earth is an imbalanced game. Some aspects of it is just simple and even silly. It needs a crucial upgrade to revise its systems, especially the trade routes. Moreover, you actually have only 3 ways to win since your affinity is the subsidiary of the alien resources near your capital city and you might not choose the affinity you like if you want to win the game.\nThe positive thing is that the icons and buttons in Beyond Earth are flat and you could control your troops easily and accurately with your fingers touching the screen of your Ultrabooks.

reviewText: I am a huge Civ fan but I have to say I would not recommend this game at all.  It is Civ V without all the fun.  New tech tree is nice but not very user friendly.  Turns are very boring and I usually quit the game because I am bored which I never have done before.  Diplomacy is a joke and almost non-existant.  Only real combat is the incredible number of alien life spawns that pop up even at the very beginning of the game.  I would not pay for this game...at least not at full price.  More of a mod than a true new game.  Very dissapointed.

reviewText: Beyond Earth brings a good look at what humanity might have to face when it reaches a new world. The game play is similar to nearly all recent Civ games, you need to research for technology, culture gives you certain bonuses, etc. I do like how they integrated alien life and how they vary in strength. They seem to be similar to the barbarians in the normal civs, but they also have super strong units like the worm/leviathan that you still need to watch out for later in the game. it's a well balanced play, I would like to see maybe playable alien races incorporated in, but that might change the direction of the game too much. Overall, pretty good game if you like the civs, I wouldn't by it for $50, but $35 seems to be a good price for it in my mind.

reviewText:
This game is not a bad game. It just don't think that it is worth 50 dollars. If you are a huge civ fan buy this game but keep in mind that it is basically reskinned civ5. Civ5 was  a great game but this game looks too similar.

Pros:
-As addictive as civ5. This game whittles away much time easily.
-The planets look pretty good. This is running on the civ5 engine so it does not look next gen but it looks good.
-The aliens are great. There are quite a few varieties and they pose a good beginning game challenge.
-The tech tree is cool. There is a lot of customizablity.
-the affinity system is good but could be more extensive. Most ways to get affinity points are passive (research this tech or choose a quest) but it is a nice addition that I'm sure will be enhanced in DLC

Cons:
-There are not very many different units types. There are no civ specific units, and there are very few types.
-This game is obviously built around DLC, there is a lot that should be here (more than just 8 civs) that have been left out
-The few civs each feel identical and have almost no differences. At least the civ5 rulers were actual people.
-There are not very many victory types. There is domination, first contact, and one affinity specific vixtory open to you. No culture, monetary or science victory can be won.
-The AI is unpredictable. They attack without pretext and are almost the same as in Civ5.

All in all, this game is not bad. I just find it hard to recommend this for 50 dollars. If it is on sale then I think it is worth it.
Score: 6.5/10
voteText: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just terrible, the game is nearly unplayable in a literal sense. Any online play takes several tries to get off the ground because the game crashes constantly in multiplayer, although it is admittedly better in LAN play than over the internet.  It tends to be a toss-up whether or not the racial faction bonuses will work at any given time. The mechanics are unimaginative, with a completely uninspired tech-bubble that lets you decide exactly the way you wish your civilization to be the same as everyone else's because the techs are scattered all over the place and full of requirements from other techs placed far away on the tree. In the year 2014 there's apparently no way to make an algorithm that even attempts to balance starting conditions. In effect, it's pretty much the exact same deal as with civilization 5, although the tech bubble is less intuitive and harder to construct a proper build out of.

Barbarians, one of the most annoying and random features of civilization 5, has been given a steroid treatment so that the game can rocket into the dull trope of all alien worlds somehow inexplicably playing host to naturally bullet-resistant life-forms. Rather than being an interesting event and object of interaction with the world, the aliens pour out of nests, meaning that depending on your location they will either be an insignificant nuisance that you don't really need to take a stance on or absolutely obliterate any chance of staying competitive with anyone who was placed elsewhere on the map. Their aggression is mostly tied into the nests - if you are surrounded by them then too bad, if not then you might not even need to escort your workers and colonists to new locations. This is unmitigated by the techs for dealing with them, due to their being placed on high tiers and randomly around the tech bubble.

You're not alone in dealing with the alien threat, however. Every now and then an unafiliated outpost will land somewhere in your expansion circle, forcing you to go to war with them or 35 turns before they go away. Sometimes two outposts disagree about which one of them is going to ruin your day, and make you decide - never give you the option to tell them both to screw off. This happens at random times throughout the game, and you have no control over it. These are the exact two random events that will happen - outposts taking your spot, and aliens taking your spot. Other players may also take your spot, but that's to be expected as you can also take theirs, being that they don't fall from the sky without warning.

This game is lazy at best, more of a late beta than a full release in most of the ways that matter. If you preordered, but are intending to play with friends who did not, you can't use the bonus map types - which is pretty stupid, but the blow is softened by the fact that the new map types are basically small variations on the old ones. In their botched attempt to basically recreate Alpha Centauri, Firaxis has managed to leave out most of the interesting parts of this predecessor - the tech bubble is bad, there is no lore to speak of, the factions are bland, even the quotes are terrible - and mashed it with the worst parts of Civilization 5's engine. Just awful.

reviewText: Sid Meier's Civilization has been one of my favorite PC series since I first laid hands on Civilization II. With the more recent release of Civilization V, my love for the franchise was rekindled; the revamped, addictive gameplay model was remarkably difficult to put down. When Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth was announced, I figured developer Firaxis would keep the trend going. Thankfully, that's definitely the case.Beyond Earth, as its name implies, is a sci-fi-tinged take on the Civilization formula. On different alien planets, you establish an outpost that becomes a full-fledged city. The names of the planets matters little; instead, each planet represents different map layouts. Some feature multiple land masses and smaller bodies of water separating the land, while others may have an extremely large land mass surrounded by ocean. There's a decent variety to choose from, along with more advanced types that feature tougher climates and layouts than the standard set. You can also dictate the overall size of the map, allowing for two, four, six, or eight different sponsors on any map.As you might suspect, a sponsor is essentially a nation or faction controlled by you, another player, or the AI. Beyond Earth features a total of eight sponsors. If you're willing to delve into the optional Civilopedia, you get a lot more information on the background of each sponsor and how each relates to real-world cultures. Each sponsor also has a distinct attribute.There are even more options at your disposal when beginning a new single-player game. Aside from picking the size/type of map and sponsor, you also choose a colonist type. You can also choose your spacecraft, which grants additional bonuses, like the ability to see all coasts or see all alien nests on the map despite the standard fog" that needs to be lifted via exploring units. Finally
date: you can choose what cargo to bring on your journey
recommended: essentially providing another bonus.Having all of these starting options and choices helps to make each single-player game feel unique

reviewText:
Played a massive map game with 8 factions that lasted around 21 hours. And lost due to the new purity exodus victory type meaning I could not select the just one more turn option. 10/10

Probably more like a 7.5/10 as it isn't as full as Civ 5 and most of the factions seem to play much the same as each other. The new affinities, unit upgrades and things that replaced ideaologies are quite fun and definately more influencial on gameplay.
The load times seem a bit longer than necessary but it doesn't take an enormous amount of time.
Graphics are fairly similar to Civ 5.
The map generation seems a bit uniform across the map as I think I just got Tundra and desert which lead to a fairly brown game.

If you want to wait for some expansions to flesh it out or the game to go on sale then have a look at Pandora: First Contact. As it is fairly similar and costs £22.99 at the moment.

If you enjoyed Civ games and or sci-fi strategy you will probably enjoy this. I would definately recommend getting it when it is on sale if you are on the fence.

reviewText:
I almost didn't buy BE after reading so many reviews damning it all the way Hades. But I'm a big fan of Sid Meier and went ahead and purchased.  At first I could totally relate to all the negative comments. It really did seem like Civ 5 had been reskinned and renamed, but without the good stuff.

What I discovered after sticking with it awhile, determined to get my money's worth:
- This is not Civ 5, therefore you cannot play with exact same strategy as Civ 5. Similar, but different enough you will need to adjust a bit
- There is a learning curve. Most overwhelming I found was the Technology Web. Definitely takes a while to wrap your head around what is important and when to research.
- Wonders do help ALOT. If you build the right ones. Again, there is a learning curve
- Read up on the Affinity's, pick one and go hard
- Unless you only want to go to war for a Domination Victory, check out the ingame help, learn about the Victories, pick one and go for it

On the down side:
- Trade routes are a nuisance. You always seem to give away more than you receive, but it can help things keep ticking over. You can more or less put them on auto pilot if you want to
- Overall the game is a bit bland. In an effort to make it look futuristic all the developers have achieved is making it samey" imho
- Lack of variation in the color scheme adds to the sameyness feel of things
date: it also makes identifying different types of units etc challenging at times\n\nOverall I am greatly enjoying this game. Each time round I discover something new and find a new depth. If you enjoy strategy and are prepared for a learning curve then you will enjoy BE too."

reviewText:
Civ Beyond Earth is an interesting game. Fans had been wondering when they'd see a spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri for some time, and Beyond Earth takes it into the modern era nicely, very much its own thing but with nice consistencies in lore and in some returning unit types, but apart from that, everything is redesigned from the ground up and is balanced pretty nicely for whatever type of game you're looking to get, from long and epic on huge planets to short, sweet and scrappy with a handful of opponents in close proximity. There's also a plethora of different map types and features to keep you occupied for hundreds of hours if you let it, particularly with the Exoplanets map pack. My favorite is a fixed-orbit planet, with scorching desert on one hemisphere, frozen wasteland in the other, and a sweet spot around the highly-contested equator area. There's a lot of little touches that add a lot of depth and replayability, which I like very much.

A lot of people I've asked about it have given it flak for feeling like a mod of Civ 5 they charged full price for, but they're forgetting that Alpha Centauri was just an improvement on the Civ 2 engine, and it was just as unique and brilliant. I don't mind this, and I really feel like you get what you pay for with Firaxis games. Their QA has never been perfect, though. Even this far down the line, there's still graphical glitches and spelling errors remaining deeper into the tech tree. Not as many as there used to be, and I recommend just a little bit more power than Steam's recommended settings if you're looking to buy the right hardware to max out the graphics in this game.

I am torn between recommending the expansion at this point or not. It adds a LOT to the game and distances itself further from what could honestly be called just a Civ 5 mod." The gameplay is expanded into the ocean
date: with enhanced graphics for undersea tiles a welcome feast for the eye
recommended: with all-new tile enhancements and coastal graphics. Sea bases are finally a thing again

reviewText:
Firstly, I do not recommend this game until a large amount of issues get cleared up, yet, like Civ5, has plenty of potential ahead.

I would advise for Civ5 fans like myself to hold off another few weeks or perhaps months for a rather large variety of fixes to be brought in.

Perhaps It's best to note some of the obvious faults and cons of the game to give you a more indepth idea of what you could be dealing with:

- Bad wonders; pretty pathetic bonuses after putting in the effort of researching the required tech and a simply bad visual introduction to the wonder once completed.

- Ranged units; melee strengths greatly reduced, averaging around 1:3 ratio to its ranged strength, however, this has obviously been introduced to some substantial increases to ranged units capabilities, but without a melee supporting unit, don't bother taking them outside the city tiles.

-AI / computer players; Don't bother playing any games under Very hard difficulty if you're looking for any kind of challenge. They avoid affinity levels like the plague and bounce around with 1st level units as long as they can. Oh, and they no longer trade resources, just 'favours', which of course can be saved up and used later to sway their minds, but playing beyond 200 turns with a pocket full of favours doesn't get you very far.

- Stations (city states); Low hp, low defence, don't have a ranged attack, don't absorb land, rather poor late game benefits (even at tier 3), they dont call for help, computer players will demand you stop attacking them even when you're the one trading and protecting them!

- Health; The old Civ5 happiness system has been replaced by a health system, which is entirely dependant on buildings which take some time to research and build and rarely benefit you beyond +3 increase. A few late game tile improvements grant you health also, but at rather steep costs. So don't expect to expand your empire beyond 3-4 cities without falling well below the health line.

- Beginning bonuses; plenty of reasonable choice, however scanning for alien nests only works on turn 1, +1 population for capital city is rather poor even on a marathon length game, CIV bonuses are rather poor compared to Civ5 Civ's, but obviously we will need to wait a few months for another 5-10 Civs to be introduced.

- Easy tech; Adopting the Scavenging virtue with the first level purity affinity grants your scouts immunity to alien attacks and are free to roam the world destroying every alien nest in site for a sweet tech bonus, the aliens assult any other unit near nests and rarely end their turn on top of the nest making for easy explorer pickings. This method has bumped myself beyond the AI every game.

There are plenty more issues to touch up on but you start to see a trend affecting almost every element of the game. But I feel that some pros should be listed as well, this is Civ after all!

- Aliens; love them, so much more annoying and stronger than barbarians, with mid-end game units like the siege worm and KRAKEN floating around the world. Making explorers and ships likely to die within a few turns after automation as they blindly stumble into the claws of the local fauna.

- Outposts; Great adaptation to city development, stops those pesky neighbours from landing a city 4 tiles from your capital. easily destroyed, no ranged attack, slow border expansion, great all around.

- Unit evolution; as you gain affinity levels, your units gain strength and unique bonuses! and not to mention a new skin. Instant upgrades for all units is rather unbalanced but this makes for a much more diverse game and interesting wars.

- Tech web; With the choice of rushing to end-game tech or slowly developing every capability, taking away the linear approach has been a fantastic improvement. Of course, being futuristic makes it rather confusing at first, I highly recommend a few minutes reading over potential improvements before selecting what to research next.

- Quests; Needs some work, however its great to have some goals pushing your game play, kill the giant worm! or even free the slaves from far base one! It would be nice to see some foriegn country specific quests encouraging a more violent game.

Well there you have some basics of the game to ponder over, I've met plenty more issues and oddities that need to be worked over in the next few weeks but this game does have great potential just as Civ5 had when it was first released.

I can see that the game has been rushed for release before it's time, but with the next 2 or 3 major updates, this will be worth buying for all the strategy and Civ fans out there.

reviewText:
So yeah. I've defended this game against naysayers for a while now but I think it's about time I ate my own words somewhat.

While BE is undoubtedly still a decent game, playing it for the past 10 or so hours has made it abundantly clear why there should have been an open beta. And I'm not referring to complaints about how this doesn't live up to the legacy of SMAC or how it's too similar to Civ 5. I wish those were the only issues. Suffice it to say there are a lot of missteps that really shouldn't have made it past the testing stage. The game is missing a lot of key UI features and shortcuts that were already present in Civ 5 and you'd think would have transitioned quite easily into this title.

For instance, why are we never told when something is built? Unless it's a wonder, the city just prompts you to select something new without ever telling you what was just completed. And while I'm glad to see more trade routes, why do I need to refresh all of them over and over without any option to just leave them to continue trading until canceled? I realize that wasn't an option in Civ 5, but with all the routes we have to micromanage now, it really ought to be.

Meanwhile, things I'd like to have dragged out - such as victory completions - are even more lackluster than in Civ 5. It's just a water color painting and an option to either play a few more turns or leave to the main menu. That's it. Where are the endgame screens with the graphs and maps and a rating of my performance or anything else that would offer the player some semblance of closure and completion? Totally absent. On the other hand, if I lose, why am I never even told what victory condition was used to win the game? I can't even check in the quest log because there's no option to Keep Playing" if I lose.

There's no way to track the victory progress of rival factions beyond vague quarterly updates
date: so I'm forced to limit the game to the only victory conditions I can keep tabs on
recommended: namely Timed and Domination. There's also no diplomatic view to see which factions are at war with each other
hoursPlayed: the aliens can more or less be avoided until you're powerful enough to completely crush them
voteText: after which they become completely irrelevant
helpfulPercent:
and the quests will occasionally have bizarrely impossible tasks such as constructing a petrochemical plant near a city that doesn't have a petroleum resource.

These are all things that really should've been implemented or ironed out before even setting a release date.

I enjoy the sci-fi aesthetic

reviewText:
It's playable, it's pretty, it's pretty stable at present, but it's not terribly gripping, and it doesn't move the series very far.

The redone virtues trees with rewards for both breadth and depth are interesting, sure.

The tech web has been done before (see, say, Endless Space) -- and it shares the common problem that the techs are a bit abstract and unfamiliar, lending itself to eiher ignoring all the names and descriptions to optimize for in-game benefit (if you're interested in playing *well*) or futzing around and finding yourself on an inefficient course.

The sponsors aren't terribly different, the AIs still provocative idiots who aggress at the drop of a hat but have no clue about actually waging an offensive war without massive production bonuses and aren't amazing on defense either, covert operations are still grossly inferior to the Civ 4 mod White Lies/Black Ops".  The UI is terrible and Firaxis should replace their designers with the guy(s?) who wrote InfoAddict.  And the fact that Firaxis has announced *another* 'SM' game in development suggests that attention and resources have probably already been shifted and that the Civ:BE spin-off won't be receiving much more.

It's still on my SSD
date: but it's not calling out to me.  Valkyria Chronicles is a more interesting strategy game with more soul
recommended: and I'm more likely to go back to Dominions 4 if I want some 4X -- at least in the latter I can amuse myself by grafting copper arms onto Gelatinous Cubes and have them wield swords
hoursPlayed: and other silly things.  The AI won't keep up there
voteText: either
helpfulPercent: but at least I can be gratuitously funny and creative while I stomp them with werewolves using two-handed swords or maybe a moose trained as necromancer."

reviewText:
While the game is fun to play hundreds of turns one after another. There is a few issues that could make anyones gaming experience a nightmare. My laptop operates on Windows 8, which as you may know loves to update all the time and when ever it feels like it. In order to play a game off steam I have to keep my windows 8 up to date. But thats not a horrible thing.  What really sucks is while in-game a message prompts you to decide to help a friend, ignore him/her and etc. The message  requires a decision in order to move on because it is that players turn. While in this prompted message I can click on any button and all the visual and sound effects still work. Except nothing happens. Message stays there, game doesn't do anything (let it sit for an hour to think). The game has a lot of bugs, that were cheaply brought over from the previous games interface. What you get is what you bought, right? I suggest staying away from this game, the $50 is a sunk cost. The game is worth only $25 for the amount of content it brings forth. Overall the gaming experience is long, lacking a good bit of fun and drags out everything. You will be playing for 300-1000 turns probably.

Zooming in further would be nice to look at details, even with the graphics up almost the whole way.

Overall: 3/5
Lacks content, and fun.

reviewText:
Civ Beyond Earth has a broken game balance. It could have been better.
Most game features are just retextured versions of the Civ V game. Culture from Civ V are shrunken down and renamed Virtues. Affinities are slightly tweaked versions of the Ideologies from Civ. The range of military units has been vastly diminished, though customisation is a good, new, feature.

An entirely new feature are the Quests. Quests were supposed to be interesting, but they quickly are repetitive.
Do you want to add food or culture from this new building you build?" is repeated multiple times. A few
date: game changing quests would have been an improvement. Civ BE does anything but. It inudates the player with dozens of quests which have barely any effect. They quickly become uninteresting and more of a hassle.\n\nThe "Stations" are the stunted
recommended: crippled City States from Civ 5. They do not claim territory and do not have a diplomacy option. They never spawn units and are essentially just trade nodes for you to trade with
hoursPlayed: each providing a bonus.\n\nWonders from Civ 5 which used to give plentiful bonuses and game changers such as doubling the army have been scaled back. For 1400 production points
voteText: you can build a wonder with an intelligent sounding name which is marginally better than a building with a quarter the production cost. Wonders are also astonishingly varied. While some yield meager bonuses

reviewText:
I really can't recomend this game as  It is in essence just a Civ V mod, and  an inferior game to Civ V: Gods & Kings to boot.

As a big Civ/Sid Meier fan for many years and games, I was pretty excited to get this game.  I was hoping it'd be a successor to Alpha Centauri, or at least a nice upgrade to Civ a la Gods and Kings.  What this is really is a mod of Civ V without a lot of the hooks for me, personally.

The gameplay is very similar, but the games flow is nowhere near as smooth or intuitive as Civ V. Some of the main selling points really are not well thought out, and don't add much. The quests are boring and the 'choices' one can make add very little. The Aliens really are in a similar vein to barbarians, and not really interesting.

Combat is very similar to Civ V. The AI is good, but not better than Gods & Kings. The tech trees are odd, and while fun to read through, not that fun in an actual game. While offering choice, the game is actually even more linear in nature than previous Civ titles.

My secondary complaint is the game isn't fun at a macro level. The goals are odd. The faction choices bizarre. The Miasma and environment issues are actually more tedious than enjoyable.

The design appears to be a mailed in rushed additional expansion labeled as a new game.

If you don't have Civ V, I'd suggest you nab it. With all the expansions it's a far more satisfying and fun experience. If you have Civ V with the expansions, then there's really no need to buy this game. You already have the exact same graphics gameplay, and a deeper and more fun experience available without needing to spend 50 bucks.

Big thumbs down.

reviewText:
I have a few complaints.  There are only two victory types, your typical domination where you take over cities and then a science victory. There might be quite a few science victories but it’s all a tech race. The civ you pick has very very little meaning the only choice that matters is your affinity leading to their only really being three civ types on the map. I feel like this makes the game supper boring. The complete lack of unit types in the game is also very off putting. There are no bombers, subs, anti-tank units, anti-air units or missiles of any kind. They completely removed the united nations concept as well.

All in all this is just a reskinned and less deep version of civ 5. If you like civ 5 just keep playing it until they put out the inevitable $20 dlc to give us the full game.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After 25 hours playing Beyond Earth, I have to cautiously say that if you haven't purchased Beyond Earth yet, wait. Wait for a sale, wait for possible DLC or expansions.

There's simply not enough content, not enough diversity, to keep me engaged. Without a wider variety of content, most games feel the same, and aside from the early turns, each progresses in the same way. The sponsors (civilizations) differ from one another in only the most minimal way, and other pre-game choices are just as drab. Some of the hype surrounding Beyond Earth touted the number of different ways you could set up your nation before the start of the match, but in practice these choices only have a minimal effect, and one that fades into near-meaninglessness.

This trend, of blandness and shallow choices, permeates the entire game. The list of veterancy promotions for units has been gutted to two: an instant heal and a minor power increase, which is a very boring let down. Wonders offer resource bonuses much like regular buildings, lacking the character and unique abilities seen in the Civilization games, and without the beautiful art and fanfare we used to get. Speaking of fanfare, the victory and defeat screens are also minimalist, and don't offer you any post-game information or statistics. Instead, you are offered the choice of quitting to the main menu or (if victorious) continueing to play. That's extremely anti-climatic. Even Alpha Centauri, if memory serves, offered a turn-by turn territory map so you could watch how the various civilizations grew and shrank.

The tech tree's organization, an interesting departure from tradition, suffers because the icons displayed lack adequate differentiation in shape or colour. Not only does this make the tech screen somewhat ugly, it also leads to needless tech-by-tech searching to find out which technology unlocks the specific unit, building, wonder, or ability you are looking for. That's information you should be able to find at a glance.

Map presets and custom options are both sparse, and even with the preorder DLC they pale in comparison to previous games. You are unlikely to be presented with any novel maps, which is a shame, especially with the new map features (canyons, miasma) that could be used to really spice things up.

The list of available units is slim. Yes, you are presented with options to customize them based on your chosen psuedo-ideology,  but far too many of these choices are dry percentage increases, and they don't alleviate the damning lack of variety. You get one air unit, two navel units, and a scant handful of melee and ranged land units.

Quests are a neat new addition, but again the interesting aspects are mired down by the majority of quests" prompting you to choose between one of two options.

The trade system

reviewText:
I tried to like this. I really, really tried. Why can't I like this? Why, after almost 350 hours in Civ 5, does more of the same not appeal to me?

1. 1 unit per tile. Hooboy. Big design choice for Civ 5, making its return in BE. Annoying at times in C5. Damned near impossible to work with in BE. The maps are smaller, which does nothing to help the system. Unit clutter is extreme with the addition of canyons and the tight maps (even on the largest shuffling around 4 units can be a major pain). The AI is still clueless as to how this system works. C5 has been out for 4 years. 4. Years. During that time Firaxis has yet to figure out how to make the AI understand one of the most important core gameplay elements. It bogs down the game until warfare just becomes a flat out tedium and not worth the trouble.

2. Smaller maps. In addition to the issues with 1UPT, the maps just aren't as impressive. Expect to be jostling sooner, over more worthless terrain, with the same blundering AI that feeds units piecemeal into the grinder. The epic scale has gone. In a game like this, epic is what it should all be about.

3. Unit design choices. This is a mixed bag, more on that later. But the...I want to say lack of forward thinking on the way units branch is frustrating as all get out most of the time. I'll take a specific example here, but it's by no means my only gripe. The supremacy branch gets a unique siege unit. Said unique siege unit has 3 range but is very slow. It needs to set up to fire. Ok, that's fine...so why does it not have the ability to perform indirect fire? Why is that not one of the upgrades for the unit? It's supposed to be one of the most powerful artillery platforms on the planet but it can't call in strikes on a unit on the other side of a forest?

4. The stripping away of information that was previously available in C5. Example: Trade routes still function pretty much the same in BE, with the exception of internal trade, which is no longer just shipping one resource (production or food) one way. Cool. So why did they remove the tool tip that demonstrates why the values are what they are and what is going in each direction? Why does the base game lack information on what a city just finished producing (something firaxis has promised to fix, but there's already a mod out for)? The loss of the strategic map, the giant charlie foxtrot that is the city screen, the lack of a simple turns til gain counter for science and culture...why? Was it slowing gameplay down that much?

5. The AI itself. ICS is back in full force. The AI is just as bad as ever, except the options to deal with them have been limited even more (I'll get into that later). Forcing colonies 3 tiles away from each other does nothing to stop the AI from spamming as many of them as they can, with no rhyme or reason, no particular emphasis on strategic resources or valuable terrain. Now that more cities actively slows research acquisition, it would be nice if the AI was designed to plan intelligently. The handling of promotions, of which there are now only one type (permanent bonus to strength) is ALWAYS delegated to the immediate +50 hp if an AI unit has taken any damage.

6. Diplomacy. Still as bad as ever. Remember that bit about less information? Here's an example again: One AI decided it didn't like a trade outpost next to my capital. I, having been trading with said outpost for quite some time, was surprised and upset to see a swarm of units come in and start attacking it (one at a time mind you). I went into the diplomacy screen to see if there was an option to tell said AI to leave the outpost alone. Nope. No ability to say I like this place and if you continue to attack it I will stop you." The AI was no doubt surprised when I declared war
date: simply to protect a resource I was actively using. Oh it gets better. After butchering their expidition
recommended: the AI promptly offered me peace and one of their colonies. I hadn't even gotten a unit close that colony. I had no intention of even attacking any of their colonies. They just gave it to me.\n\nLater in the same game another AI declared war on me without warning. This I don't mind. It's a nice surprise to finally see them take some intiative...and 1UPT combined with the small map and rubbish terrain meant their army never even attacked my colony before they got massacred. Again
hoursPlayed: almost an immediate peace offer including one of their colonies. Not a piddling 2 or 3 pop either
voteText: a full developed colony. In a war they were the aggressor in. While my army was tied up on the other side of the continent and in position to retaliate

reviewText: Unrefined, cumbersome, broken, yet still seems more fun than Civ 5.  The virtue tree is neat.  The unit upgrading system is fun, yet inconsistent (if you don't select an upgrade because you're looking to take a different upgrade path, your unit will still cost more, but have no benefit from the increased cost).  City managers for automated improvement building are gone.  Just finding the building queue and where to set your specialists is beyond poorly designed.  Actually, the city screen as a whole has taken a huge step backward from Civ 4.  Workers have no command to build a road network of their own, aside from the most basic route-to command.  Dozens of times, I have had to reapply the go-to command to my units.  Practically zero explorable objects on a large map.  Trade routes become quite annoying as your empire grows, as you have to re-apply the trade routes every 30 turns.\n\nOh, and the game is occasionally unwinnable.  The game bugged out when we dominated the opponent.  Team 2 was removed, but no victory was given.  We even went and finished a second victory condition, but that simply made my game crash.  I was unable to rejoin the game, as it won't allow you to join a game where there is only one team.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of Alpha Centauri, I was longing for this game, hoping it would recapture that magic and bring it back to us with updated graphics and an UI that didn't suck.

In short: It doesn't.

The general atmosphere does a decent job at imitating SMAC: SciFi Setting, fictional tech quotes, aliens, and so on. Beyond Earth even goes - well - beyond Civ 5 by adding the orbital layer, covert ops, quests, excavations and the affinity system.

Unfortunately (based on my limited trial run) the affinity system feels like a slog and doesn't even come close to replacing the custom unit system of it's inspiration. The rest of the disappointment can be filed under the one thing that Beyond Earth absolutely nailed from Alpha Centauri: The terrible UI. Obviously 15 years are not enough to fix that. The trade route system is annoying busywork, the help system is even worse that in SMAC but the most brain-dead design decision must have been to blur out the most essential stats every time you enter a management window.

Firaxis could salvage this game with nothing but some UI-teaks (coincidentally exactly the same thing that SMAC would have required for a re-release). But as it stands now this is a waste of enormous potential.

reviewText:
I was skeptical of Beyond Earth at first.  The hype was that it would be the long-awaited revival of the brilliant cult classic, Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.  After what I'd heard about Beyond Earth mechanics, it sounded like the defining characteristics of the game had been passed over.  Social Engineering and Prototyping are nowhere to be found, shaping the very continents through terraforming and sea bases are missing.

But now, with a few additional playthroughs behind me, my perspective has changed.  Do NOT look at Beyond Earth as an Alpha Centauri remake.  Treat it as a stand-alone project.

I have heard this title described as 'Civ 5 in space' and I feel like it's a mildly misguided assessment.  The elements that tie Beyond Earth to Civilization V are simply the baseline elements that make a Civilization game.  As a veteran of Civilization games since 1991, I can confidently say that Beyond Earth stands as much apart from other releases as any other and you'll enjoy learning the new technology trees, units, buildings, and virtues (similar to the previous game's Social Policies) and bending them to your advantage.

For new players to Sid Meier games, this is a fun 4X title that may overwhelm you with choices at first, but in time you'll come to appreciate them and use them to your benefit.  The visual and audio aesthetics of the game are pleasant and smooth, lending a great deal to the atmosphere, though I would say the faction leaders could use more development and variety.

For loyal Civilization fanatics, you may find the new mechanics (especially the technology) fractured and far more open than previous games, but it will become a benefit as you learn your way around the trees.  Variety and freedom of optimisation are the name of the game.

To summarise, it's a fantastic game and money well spent.  Where Civilization V crash-landed with severe multiplayer issues and coarse gameplay, Beyond Earth arrives with a relatively smooth landing.  There are no gamebreaking bugs.  Across some fifty hours of gameplay, I have had one crash and it did not repeat.  I look forward to the release of expansions sometime in the next year, with any luck, and what they will add to an already well-rounded title.

That said, please remake Alpha Centuari for us, changing as few elements as possible.  We beg you.

reviewText:
Until Rising Tide is released, I simply cannot recommend this game. It's been out for around a year now, and only then did Firaxis realize what was wrong. They released it in an incomplete, unbalanced, unforgiving condition.

I'd lovingly pay to actually have the complete version of this game, and I already have. But for now, let's outline some details.

-The diplomacy of the base game is absolutely halfassed, and the AI's are way too predictable.

- Affinities are a fantastic addition to the civ formula, but it seems like the Harmony affinity trumps all every single time. Thus surfacing some serious power balancing issues.

-The miasma. Who's idea was this.... it makes the difficulty so artificial it's crazy.

-The amount of tile improvements you can build gets extremely overwhelming. It would have been better to just upgrade each existing one and and a few new ones, rather than have a new one for every other technology on the absolutely massive tech tree.

To sum up my thoughts on beyond earth, wait until rising tide comes out.

EDIT: This NEGATIVE REVIEW is for the standalone base game. If you want a fantastic Civ experience, then play this game with the Rising Tide expansion.

reviewText:
This is literally worse than Civ 5.

There a bunch of different victory types, but they all basically involve building some kind of late game wonder and waiting x amount of turns until it makes you win.

You can't have a culture victory because they removed culture, tourism, and religion.

You can't have a diplomatic victory because they removed the world congress and turned city states into a single hex that you can make trade routes to. They also removed luxury resources and severely decreased the importance of strategic resources so you don't have anything to trade for.

You can have a domination victory, but it's almost pointless, because as said there's no luxury resources and barely strategic resources. A domination victory doesn't flow over fighting for valuable resources. You just fight because there's nothing else to do.

The game plays the same way every time. Look around at what strategic resource the game started you with, floatstone, firaxite, or xenomass. Then choose an affinity based off of that. Research all of the techs that increase that affinity and get your end game wonder. Spend all your culture on the prosperity tree and choose health on all the quests" so you don't have negative health (happiness). Ignore your neighbors completely because they don't do anything. Wait for your wonder to win the game."

reviewText: I have over 1,500 hours in Civilization 5, a game they invested a lot of development time over several revisions. The game design for Beyond Earth is a great idea and has potential for a start. It was very obvious they used the Civilization 5 base engine to develop the game rapidly. Beyond Earth on the other hand was simply released without thoroughly being tested.\n\nBecause of their reputation as a company, they also increased the price tag Beyond Belief" considering the overall product. I would have just waited a year if I had known of its current state and my trust in the corporation just dropped. The business goal of money
recommended: and more money with rushed development just doesn’t work in the gaming industry without taking a hit.\n\nI extended game play by building up to understand the tech tree and learn the strategy. I tried a standard sized default map and set it up to only be won by domination. I could not complete this game I set up because of a tech tree game defect
hoursPlayed: but here is what I did see before I gave up.\n\n1. When you conquer all cities of a player
voteText: they are still in the game! They show on the score board (mini option window)
helpfulPercent: they have roaming units
votesHelpful: they interact with your leader and are still able denounce you
votesTotal:
and they can conduct spy missions (I caught one)!

2. Key resources for the 3 possible paths is not balanced if you choose to focus on only one. I was only able to build at most 3 Supremacy titan units with little remaining resources for much else (some buildings require them). I eventually equaled in Harmony and  I was able to build about 10 titan harmony units with plenty of resources left over. There is an obvious advantage for Harmony.

3. <CRITICAL> The tech tree cannot be fully researched. I was only able to continue my game until I had to pick the last research item and the game locked on its selection screen. I was unable to tab out or focus on a Task Manager screen to kill the game. It kept throwing me back to Beyond Earth. Definitely not ready there.

4. The tech tree is not a good game design because it’s not large enough with the idea that a player should focus on one of 3 main paths. This should have been thought out more and presentation was difficult to see in a quick overview. The zoom in and out feature should just be removed if it cant be done correctly. This should have been wiped and redone in presentation.

5. You can only reach a max of 18 in one of the paths
votesFunny: but there is no reason not to be able to go higher. I was even able to select a greyed out option to increase beyond 18 (took the point away and gave me nothing). There should be no reason to stop it in presentation even if it doesn’t affect game play. I felt cheated out of a point even if it had no value.\n\n6. The initial options to set up a game with bonuses advantages is a great idea over the set advantages in Civilization 5
commentsCount: but it fails to present the initial racial titles even though it is obvious during the game the origins exist when speaking different languages that follow a Civilization 5 format. A simple presentation flaw that doesn’t match achievements either.\n\n7. The AI should be guided by victory conditions

reviewText: This game has a massive amount of bugs in it. reviewText:
I can't reccomend getting this game. Maybe when it's a couple dollars on sale...

The game was released with major bugs and overall feels unfinished. After nearly 2 months they finally released a fix, but that ended up breaking the game even more. For the support this game gets alone do not get this game.

The gameplay is fun enough, similar to Civ5. It does add some interesting new gameplay which is fun to play through. One aspect I don't like is that you cannot disable Aliens like you could disable Barbarians in Civ5.

All in all the game is ok, and would normally be something I'd suggest buying when you see it on sale, but given the support, do not buy.

reviewText:
Great game, definately worth picking up, and definatly worthy of the Sid Meier's Civilization name.
The lag present in Civ 5 lategames when computing NPC actions is reduced in comparison; making it faster however the attack frames occasioinally stick making everything you do in that turn delayed.
Looks amazing.
Compared to other Civilization games it is significantly easier to learn and the tree system they implemented puts an interesting twist on the game that hasnt been present since Civilization Revolution.
Theres a few issues with late game versus early game scaling, and how the bots react with this, and the same usual factor of maintaining your productivity and your Happyness.
Changes to Resources:
Happy = Health.              Energy = Currency.

Compared to Civ 5, I'd stick with Civ 5 atm as its a little more prefected, but with a few tweeks I can see this becoming a great game.
As of Jan 16, 2015 I'd recommend it, and on a scaling of 0-10, I'd give it probably 7/10. I suggest picking it up well its on sale, which it frequently goes on.

reviewText:
Civilization Beyond Earth is without a doubt an excellent and fun game, sadly most of the reviews are trying to compare it with Civilization 5 + Gods and Kings + Brave New World or Alpha Centauri, but lets remember that expansions and dlcs should be released eventually and the game will become even better and also the game balance will come with time so dont expect a recently released game to be 100% balanced. I really dont get why so many bad reviews, this game definitely doesnt deserve it. Below I will point some pros and cons of the game and stuff that i would like to see on future dlcs/expansions:

--> Pros:

- The new aliens are a nice challenge on the early game, especially Siege Worms because you never know how they will react.
- The new Affinity System is great, it gives players an option on how to devote their colony, so do you want your colony to remain pure and follow Old Earth ideologies? Or maybe make cybernetic enhancements on your people and spread chaos and havoc with robotic armies? Or maybe be one with your new planet and domesticate and integrate the alien lifeforms for your own purposes? Well, its your call!
- The new map exploration is awesome, with your explorer units you search for Supply Pods which will give you small yields of Science, Culture or Energy and even a free Solar Collector or you can reveal the secrets of Ancient Ruins that will give you boosts on researches or the option for an affinity level or even investigate a crashed space ship which could countain the logs of a failed colonization mission giving you acess to new quests.
- The new quest system is very interesting and offers the players many challenges across your games, the quests are generated based on how you are playing the game. Example: Spotting a Siege Worm will activate a quest that involves killing it and the reward will surely pay the effort, or making a trade route with a independent Station may trigger another Station to give you a quest to destroy their rival Station and as a reward they will give you a boost on the yields they provide. There are also quests that involves affinity levels and they will help you to develop you colony based on your actions during those quests.
- The new orbital units are a great new feature, it allows you to deploy from Solar Collectors to boost the energy generation of your city to satellites armed with giant lasers that you can use both for defend or attack.

--> Cons

- There are very few sponsors (only 8) so there isnt much diversity on the games, at least they can pick different affinities.
- The combat on Civilization Beyond Earth surely need some balancing, cities are much more powerful now and if you want to play Space Atilla early game it will be kinda hard since most units will be melted by the cities defense on the early game so you need to spend a lot of time on making very large armies if you want to conquer cities early on, however later on that is not a problem because the units at around 12 Affinity Level are already very powerful and it takes less than 5 turns if you are well positioned to conquer a capital, based on this the game pratically forces you to go for a domination victory on the late game where everyone else is at around 50%-75% on another victory type.
- Trade routes are waaaaaaaaaaaaaay overpowered, every city can set 2 trade routes and if you get an auto plant you can get another one so basically its 3 trade routes per city. In my opinion a good number would be a max of 4 Trade Routes per Civilization and you can improve that to maybe 6 or 7 by making wonders, affinity bonus or quest reward.
- The wonders on this game provides very weak bonuses, so most times you dont even bother making them because the bonus they grant you aint that great. The ones i usually make are the Ectogenesis Pod and the Gene Vault mainly to aid the city growth on the early game.
- All the units are of the same color, ok you can see the colored icon but it would be nice if the units had your sponsor color.
- Only 2 naval units, there is a ranged cruiser and a carrier, it would be nice if we could build submarines or a melee naval unit to conquer coastal city using only naval force.
- The User Interface is confusing since everything is pretty much of the same color, seeing what is your city producing, on how many turns it will grow or how many turns to finish that beautiful wonder is very confusing and hard to see because everything including the small numbers are of the same color of your sponsor but im sure that can be polished.
- The tech tree is nice and gives you freedom to focus on what you want, but it takes some time to get used to it and know what leads to what or what you need to reveal or improve the resources.
- Covert Ops are waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay overpowered.

--> What I would like to see on the future

- A religion system that could work with your choosen affinity
- More military units, especially naval ones
- More sponsors, i think a number of 16-20 sponsors would give a good diversity to the game
- Sponsors should have unique units/buildings. For example the PAC could have a special worker unit that improves tiles a lot faster and have +1 movement since they are focused on production or the ARC could build a special Spying Agency or another build which improves the spying activity.
- Different alien types, it would be badass if there were different types of aliens based on the map type or something like that, that would add diversity to the game.
- Improved military AI, sometimes the AI takes some very dumb decisions when you are at war with them.

Well, thats my review for Civilization Beyond Earth, Im really enjoying the game and i believe that this game just need some polishing and im sure that with the future dlcs/expansions it will become even better than it already is.

reviewText:
It's actually a step down from Civ V in a way. Civ V with the expansions has more options regarding things like the world congress and tourism. Civ V obviously also has a broader scope if you consider the techologies and stuff available in each age.

The reason I recommend it however is that I find the pacing in Beyond Earth to be a bit faster and more dynamic. Things start to get interesting a lot a quicker. The early stages of Civ V can be a bit boring. The music is really top notch as well and the graphics are good. The wars can feel pretty dramatic.

It fall short of the greatness of it's spiritual forefather, Alpha Centauri however, which was arguably better than it's counterpart, Civ II. Beyond Earth is certainly not better than Civ 5.

Yet if you are a Civ fan looking for an alternate challenge/scenario, or new to this genre I recommend it as it's very easy to pick up and play. The faster pace does make campaigns quite interesting and if you are new to the genre and like sci-fi I would recommend. Especially if on a promotion! But if you are a Civ 5 fan looking for something better than Civ 5, i'd avoid it.

reviewText:
Civilization Beyond Earth truly deserves the title of spiritual successor of Alpha Centauri. Although it requires a bit of unit diversity, even with the upgrades, you'd still miss the custom unit creation that was available in Alpha Centauri. Factions are diverse but not too distinct from each other, which makes them somewhat easier to get used to quickly. Gameplay and turn times are much smoother than in Civ 5, especially in later phases of the game in a very large map you'd feel the difference of ai completing their turns much quicker.

As i read the comments i see people who haven't played Alpha Centauri but fans of Civ series are a bit confused and calling this an expansion pack of sorts. It simply isn't. Just take it as exploring, or rather migrating to an alien planet because earth is no more habitable and imagine all that 'future tech' in Civ games are new set of techs in here. Sure it takes time to get used to but it doesn't prevent it being so much fun.

It will become a legendary successor when they add more factions, a little more unit diversity and some other dlc add ons but it's still a must buy right off the bat for any Civ or Alpha Centauri fan.

reviewText:
This game... is clearly is half-done.

The AI is brain-dead, and turtles. There's NO threat at all of having war declared upon you.
Even at higher difficulties, this game is a city-building sim, except you can't make more than
3 cities until 200+ turns in.

The UI is not intuitive, there's a lot of information that is missing that you should be able
to see in various interfaces, the civilopedia, diplomacy screen, etc. that is just missing altogether. You don't actually understand what everything DOES until you try it by playing a few times through.

Aliens are only a threat to your trade routes and units that get too close, not to your cities.
Affinities are mostly broken, wonders are underwhelming and aren't worthwhile - none are
much better than a regular building, but at several times the production cost?!

All of the faction leaders are bland. There's NO difference whatsoever in any of their behavior
or characteristics in game - it's like eating a big bowl of cardboard.

Don't buy this game until... actually, don't buy this game AT ALL.

Don't buy anything else Firaxis develops from now on either, for that matter.

This is yet another lesson, in NEVER PRE-ORDERING A GAME, EVER, FOR ANY REASON...

...not even if it's an overhyped, overpriced Civ game.

reviewText: Purchased this game meeting the minimum requirements and was able to play the game but with a massive amount of crashes. Game was updated and then i was unable to even load the game. reviewText:
How do I begin?

I love Civilization Games. I have been here since the start. I did my best not to get too hyped about this game. I had been scared that this game would totally flop. I would have preordered a collector's edition without any hesitation. My fears were many.

After really thinking hard and playing this game and trying so so hard to like it, even love it. I have to say that I am truly disappointed.

I am too upset about it. Everyone else have made great points and I am in total agreement. This game lacks personality, creativity, and polishing.  User Interface is a mess, diplomacy is non-existent, the races are too bland, so vanilla.   So much potential, This game feels rushed.

Why did you do this Firaxis? Must I wait for an expansion for you to fix the content?

I like the fact you took risks with the new affinity and tech system, I like the orbital layer, but it all falls short. There is only a small definite amount of units to choose from. None that are unique, no upgrades that are unique.  I understood the favor system in trade. but favors are treated like a commodity in this game, you trade it just like you would a resource. Which is terrible idea. Favors are called favors for a reason, and they should have more weigh.

What went wrong?

There are many major bugs? I couldn't play fullscreen with the correct resolution? You didn't care enought to play test this game?  Anyone would have been happy to? No need for paying anyone for beta testing!

As much as I appreciated that you tried to take Civilization to the stars, you failed. I am sorry.

Let's see how you can fix it.

7/28/2015 - Dev still had no fixes, and decided to make us pay for a new expansion to fix it.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth was not good. Hmm, maybe, that's putting it lightly, it kinda sucked. For a game that could have been great, it was sub-par. A glorified Civ V mod.

Then Rising Tide came out. The 1st eXpansion for Civ:BE, quickly followed by two patches. What we have now is a good game.

That's right, Civ:BERT (I love this acronym) is a good game. Is the AI perfect? No. It needs to learn how to wage war. But it does eXpand fairly well on the higher difficulties. It does a decent job with diplomacy. It has a reasonable mix of units. It reasearches well enough to beat me to wonders. The affinities got better with the new hybrids. Lots of improvements everywhere. I love the aliens and how they differ from one environment to the next, I just wish they were smarter is all.

All in all, the game has improved, and dare I say that with another proper expansion with quick post release patching the game could really shine? Yes, I dare.

If you want to read more, go check out eXplorminate.net for the in-depth reeXamination and Audible eXtension podcast.

reviewText:
Look, I love Civilization. I've been playing Civ since I can remember, it's where I learned probably <70% of my world history, and I'm 20 years old. I've been playing since Civ 2, and I can actually remember Test of Time coming out. I should love basically anything Civ. But for several reasons, I feel completely let down.

1. Several game crashes. I was prepared for this, lock ups happen and I set autosave to every other turn just because of this.

2. The aesthetic is just terrible. It's a bland mix of greens and browns even with graphics maxed, you can't see units in cities at all and it's incredibly annoying to try to figure out what miasma is, and as a strategy game, losing 10% of your units HP can be a game losing mistake.

3. The tutorial SUCKS. Like, big time. I've played 14 hours and I still have absolutely no idea how I'm supposed to progress through the affinities. It seems like it's just random quests + using the gaudy tech web, which takes a lot of my agency away.

4. The tech web is interesting, but it's unbelievably confusing. There are so many options and halfway into the game you've got 18 options and none of them are a clearly useful tech. The constraint of being linear in the previous Civ tech trees added elegance to them, this time the freedom has made tech wildly unfun. I could very easily see what my path was going to be in other Civ games, and lining up timings with other facets of the game was not just fun, but it was exactly why I played those games.

5. Combat unit upgrades might as well be random. They tie into the affinity system that is already murky with no explanation. Your affinity level translates directly into how strong your combat units are. This means that if you keep getting quests that require end game techs or to destroy Alien Nests when there are none near you, you lose to your opponent who ramps up 5 affinity tiers ahead of you and busts into your base. More lack of agency.

6. UI falterings in hotseat. I wanted to show my friend this game because I was excited about it, but after 5 turns or so the graphics started disappearing, like the prompt that your city needs a new production. Some of the prompts also don't show up in single player as well, like city growth. Not being aware of what's going on in the game can be really taxing, the reason that Civ V had so many prompts was to free up the player's mental resources and make it more about the strategy and less about the memorization.

There are a few more smaller problems, but all of these are core issues with the game. Look elsewhere for your 4X gaming for now, it will be a LOT of work to make this an enjoyable game for me.

Edit #1 After playing another game, I ran into affinities being rewarded through excavations, another random element which the player has little control over, I got 4 affinity upgrades and destroyed my opponents because I had a massive unit upgrade advantage.

Edit #2 After another couple of games, I've actually come to realize that the choices you make as a player don't really matter against the AI. So, if you're only wanting to experience an easy game in single player, go for it. There is a turning point at which you're just always ahead of the AI. Which is okay I suppose, if it weren't for screwy multiplayer.

Anyway, if you want to play single player alone, you'll get about 30-40 hours before you feel like you've done mostly everything.

reviewText:
As a hardcore Civ fan I have to say I was more than a bit let down by this release.  I completely understand some issues are bound to be in the release version of the game.  What I am mystified about is the sheer number of obvious game play breaking bugs that were in the initial release.  And when I mean obvious I mean glaring in your face omissions.
I have to wonder what the internal testers were up to?  If core mechanics are barely functioning then maybe you should have just disappointed the community with a pushed back release instead of dumping a half finished game on us.
Sadly this game feels half finished.  The lack of even the most basic ending sequence was a major let down.  Want to see some stats on what you did? Too damn bad.  Expecting some neat cut scenes for world wonders?  Too damn bad.
The tech web was a let down as well.  In the end you have virtually cleared the whole thing anyway.  They only real choices you are making are within the leaves that concern the affinity system.  So the hype of choose your own path" was complete hogwash.
Another let down were the actual units.  I get the affinity system changes the looks and abilities somewhat of the units.  It just seems very sterile.  Very few options for units.   I guess I was simply spoiled on older Civ games with a much wider selection of units.
In the end I can't say I am satisfied with my purchase.  I have hopes some patches will fix some of the ciritical problems.  So if your planning on buying I would wait a few months until the dust settles and pick this up on sale."

reviewText:
TL;DR - Overall, this is not a bad game. I was just hoping for so much more.

For the most part, this is a Civ 5 reskin on another planet. The research tree has been converted to a research web, starting in the middle and spreading out in a direction you are interested in. While this has been done before in other games, it's still a pretty neat mechanic that I personally enjoy over the traditional tree. There exists a Health System to limit the expansion of your Civilizations which provides you with buffs or debuffs if you haven't expanded in a while or if you have committed to the appropriate research topics. I found this seemed to hinder me more often than it helped me when I focused on a conquest campaign but on a research intensive run it seemed to aid me. Re-tasking trade convoys becomes a tedious chore in the mid to late game that leaves you quite thankful that there isn't a 'corner the market' economic victory

A questing system has been added to this version of Civilization. While they do add flavor to this bland drink of a game, their only true purpose is to add affinity points to one direction or another. Please make no mistake, the tales the quests themselves weave and the rewards you receive for them are interesting, but in the long run they do little to affect your game.

I found that the various endgames leave your victories quite hollow and vague. Each endgame I experienced felt like they were the prologue of some other work of science fiction rather than an end to the one I was playing. Perhaps the developers wanted the end to feel open, or were leaving room for sequels/expansions/dlc/etc. I managed to get to three of these endings before I lost the desire to replay to game to see others. Truthfully it feels like someone walked into the developers studio one day and said 'Times up. Ship it as is.

I cannot recommend this game. But the reason I can't recommend this game is a terrible one: nostalgia. At some point
date: this was tagged as a 'spiritual successor to Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.' Alpha Centauri was one of my all time favorite turn based
recommended: civilization style games. This game is *sort of* like Alpha Centauri in that it is also a civilization style game that takes place on an other planet. But this is where those similarities end.\n\nI'm sure there are other who will enjoy this game. I just don't."

reviewText:
Civ Beyond Earth is, at it's core, a very well done, thorough, and interesting MOD. It is not worthy of a stand-alone game. It's not worth the $60 retail price. As a life-long fan of Civ games, this one just isn't for me. It's opaque, glitchy, at times thrilling, but mostly very boring. Incredible promise, abysmal delivery.

I'll continue to play it, just to see if it gets better with time, but my initial impressions will be hard to overcome.

Overall, I think I should have stuck with Civ 5 and it's well-established mod community.

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend Civilization Beyond Earth at this point. It is extremely basic and barebones of a Civilization game, like playing a demo of something that was supposed to be grander. It doesn't feel like an alien world experience at all, the random roaming aliens are very generic, and every tile in the world (excluding miasma which is a hard to see and annoying unit damaging element that the AI is unable to pathfind around) is direct copy of Civilization 5 tiles. There is barely anything new to see in Beyond Earth, even though it's supposed to be an hostile alien world it ends up being less hostile and less alien than our very own Earth.

The civilizations of Beyond Earth are also plain, there are only a few small statistic changes between them. They have exactly the same units, same city graphics, and obviously they are all human too, just different races / genders) so they definitely don't feel alien, just generic.

Many of the things are just reskinned to look new, but underlying mechanics are the same. All alien resources are just normal resources in Civilization with sci-fier names, all alien tiles are literally the same functionally but just have a different visuals to them. Sadly even the visuals of the alien terrains are a bit bad, there are barely any variation (like visual difference between desert and plains, or tundra and grasslands) and everything is similar shades and covers. Mushrooms are alien, right? Lets put mushrooms everywhere. Purple is alien too? Yup, lets shade everything with it. Obviously every terrain type has their own textures, but the contrast between visuals of area is very very low.

Happiness has been removed and replaced with health (it works the same, except your citizens don't get super healthy when they get ecstatic :D). Gold has been replaced with energy and at least I haven't seen much difference there. Policies have been replaced as Virtues and the Virtue system is more interesting (with bigger talent trees) but barely different from Policies of Civilization 5.

Pure complaints aside, there are good things in the game too. It is nice to see a non-linear tech tree, even though they could have gone a bit wilder with it, instead they were afraid of really mixing things and ended up with half-linear tech tree that is more realistic but less fun as game mechanic. The satellite overlay is a nice concept, but they only work as temporary boosts. There is a simple unit tech upgrading system and it seems really nice.

Perhaps at a later date in DLCs they'll fix and add things to spice it up. Currently it is not worth buying at a full price and you'll end up with very bad value for your money if you pay a full price now and add expensive DLC later.

reviewText: After playing a game of this, it feels way to similar to Civ 5.  I still love the one unit per tile strategy system but I would prefer to play Pandora with the expansions more.  There are more systems in Pandora than what Beyond Earth currently offers.  I am not a fan of the instant spy network and leveling up intrigue to cast huge capital decimating powers.  Feels there is little risk to just pumping this up.  There are really 3 different paths to take and to level up your military you should be pumping into an affinity to get more powerful units.  So instead of going for a specific research, any research with that affinity or quest will get you more powerful units - assuming you unlocked the basic version of course.  So to get the most bang for your buck, you can get a social/economical research upgrade and later on grab an affinity with it to boost military as well.\n\nOverall I would not recommend this game in it's current state but that is about how I feel with every Civ game that first comes out.  This game really is about a $100 to be recommended and that is when the expansions come out.

reviewText:
As someone who has played Civilization 5 for 250 hours I can say that while this game is very similar to Civilization 5 it has enough differences to be worth the price tag in my eyes. However as the game is likely to recieve expansions and dlcs that will take it from a great game to a fantastic game it may be worth waiting for a sale before buying. My review will mostly be comparisons to Civilization 5. With this in mind here are my thoughts:

Interface;
The interface design on the game is tightened up a bit on the main screen. Its a bit more sleek. However as a result some information is a bit small and hard to find at first as a result. Very functional and works just like Civ 5 for the most part. The biggest interface complaint is the Tech Web. The mostly blue and white coloring along with the almost unnoticeable difference between wonders and buildings on it makes it a chore to look at and sort through. Fortunately mods are already coming along to fix this so its not as big an issue as it might otherwise be.

AI:
A little better but the same as always. The game explains why the AI hates or loves you though so their reasoning is a bit more transparent. Unfortunately the AI is as dumb as always and having played on Gemini difficulty mostly they seem to barely present a challenge to an experienced player. As usual it seems like the main thing that keeps AI players afloat is the massive amount of cheating they do but in this game it seems like they don't do quite as much of it. The staggered spawning doesn't really matter because the AI returns to parity quite quickly. All in all its the same as its always been with the AI in Civilization. I  personally find the AI to be the weakest part of this game just like in Civilization 5.

Civilizations:
What has been lost in variety from Civilization 5 has been made up for by balance and customizability. Providing a series of mostly balanced options the game offers you a chance to customize how your Civilization starts and prevents the first 5 turns from playing out mostly the same every time. While I do miss some of the more fun and unique units and buildings from Civilization 5 I think the system used here is overall better. The loss of Civilizations with terrible bonuses is good. These Civs do seem to lack personality but to be honest they never had personality in Civilization 5. Any personality attributed to the AI by players was created by the implied history of America for example.

Gameplay:
On the surface it appears to be incredibly similar to Civilization 5 and in a lot of ways, it is. Units can't stack, the map is hex based, resources are reskinned but the same, ect. Despite this the game plays quite differently with aliens proving more dynamic and challenging than barbariens ever were. Spies have been revamped and are both more useful and interesting. Trade routes work on a by city basis as opposed to a global limit encouraging massive trade empires. The culture trees promote far more diversification and interesting strategies with their synergy bonuses. The tech web, a huge change to the previous tree system of Civ 5 diversifies each Civilization far more than unique bonuses ever did and allows for many interesting strategies. Except for the Domination all the victories have been revamped creating interesting ways for players to win and allowing for a lot of time for other players to interfere. Expeditions and resource pods create more variety and must often be fought over by the aliens squatting nearby. Miasma while often irritating makes positioning all the more important. Sattelites, one of the bigger new additions have many varied and useful effects on the land beneath them. I could keep going on but in the end while most of the changes feel small in my opinion they all add up together to create a game that feels and plays very differently from Civilization 5. It is certainly an iterative sequel but it is a different game from Civilization 5 in a myriad of ways.

I am greatly enjoying my time with this game warts and all and I look forward to the dlc and expansions that will make it even better.

reviewText:
Hmm...

i have mixed Feelings about this Game.

First i was amazed by the new Hud, Fractions, Units, by the new research System...
but now after about 50 hours its already boring and im happy when im done with my Achievements to uninstall the Game.

Pro and Contra	 + New Fractions, Units, Hud, Techtree/Researchsystem
+ The Graphics and Animations are a little better than at Civilization V.
+ Nice sounds and good ambient Music.
+ Steam Workshop Support
+ The Multiplayermode seems to work fine, but take this with caution, only played 2 Matches.
+ Running smooth and didnt crash a single Time in 50 Hours.


- The AI is terrible. Sometimes unable to build Units, just bulding Cities and even more Cities, not gathering ressources.
At other times they attack you out of the blue, for no reason.
And this happens like a gamble, totally random and can happen on every difficulty.
Often all the AI does is a) nothing besides spamming Cities or b) Steamrolling you with a an Army that contains mostly just one Unit type.
If you play with AI vs AI, your AI is mostly nothing more than a victim. On higher difficulty they just get rushed without resistance.
For fun i tried several settings like 2v1, 3vs1, 2vs2  and even 6 AI + Me ( playing defensive) vs ONE Enemy AI, and guess who won? the Enemy rushed one unable Teammate after another.

Also hilarious, when the AI ends up with a cashflow of MINUS 7000 per turn, like this

- If youre not familar with Civilization IV or V, its hard to find into the Game, the Settings, Hud, and Overview are very confusing.

-  Wonders and Quests have an insufficient  or confusing Descriptions. Also some Quests are bugged in case that they wont be completed, even if you did all required tasks, and sometimes they just repeat themselves over and over again.

- No Match Statistics after the Game. I loved to see a Gameoverview at CiV 5, but here it seems to be missing.



All together Beyond Earth has some nice new Changes, but also a lot of Civilization V in it.

Thats not bad, but considering the high Price, Broken AI, confusing Descriptions&Menus and that the lack in variety makes the Game boring after only" 50 Hours
