reviewText:
If I had to give the game a grade, would a B, not the best game I have ever played, but it holds its own, and is fun to play.

First off, comparing to to what everyone will do - Sid Miers Alpha Centauri - It looses out here, the main things I enjoyed in AC, the movies, the voicework, and the dark focus, are all gone. Beyond Earth has a much brighter outlook in most ways, the aliens aren't horrifying, the factions are kind of tame, and in general, things feel less intense.

But, not comparing it to that, its an extremely solid civilization game. It feels much more streamlined than everything so far to me, with passive unlocks and techonoligcal boosts, units never don't feel like they go obsolete, and buildings steadily increase in worth throughout the game. The quest system provides customization to your buildings which is nice, but I still feel like there is one fundamental thing that dissapointed me in this game-

The game is fun and streamlined, but it could have had so much more worked pumped into its story and presentation, and would be awesome if it had.

reviewText:
I have 676 hours logged in Civ 5. It was my first experience with the Civilization franchise and I loved the game from the beginning, though as expansions were released I came to realize just how lacking the game had been when first launched. Despite this, I would still have rated vanilla Civ 5 as a pretty good game. Naturally, when I heard about Beyond Earth I was very excited.

I expected it to be very similar to Civ 5 but more polished and with innovative new systems that would enhance the user experience. I expected to get a Civ 5 game that was worth being its own game. I have been VERY disappointed. The jump from Brave New World to Beyond Earth seems to be the same as from Vanilla Civ 5 to Gods and Kings. This is a stand-alone expansion, not a full game. I can see the potential for it to be great, but it feels unfinished. I've played for only a few hours and I don't really feel any urge to play any more.

In my first play through, I noticed the following negatives:

-Some buildings don't actually work. I built a Progenitor Garden (+20% health in that city) and it did nothing. I spent a lot of energy to build it immediately and the building didn't provide any boost to health. I haven't built all of the building and wasn't really paying attention to most of the buildings that I did build, but I can't help but wonder how many other buildings didn't actually have any effect at all and were just wasting energy.

-Units weren't cleared from the Unit Upgrade window. As I upgraded more and more units, they simply overlapped each other graphically in the window. This is not a game ending issue, but I would have expected small stuff like this to be smoothed out before release. It adds to the rushed and unfinished feel of the game.

-Baffling AI. I actually had an AI offer to renew a trade with me and when I accepted it, they refused and demanded that I offer them more to continue the trade. THEY WERE THE ONES THAT OFFERED TO RENEW THE PREVIOUS TRADE IN THE FIRST PLACE!!!! There are too many examples of bad AI in this game, but this example really epitomizes the players experience in dealing with the AI in most aspects of the game.

- Related to the previous point, general diplomacy sucks. The AI holds onto old grudes FOREVER. For example, if you tell them to not build cities near you, that has a negative effect on your relationship for the rest of the game. I know that this occured in Civ 5 too, but I really expected some better diplomacy and international relations in this game. It's been 300 years... get over it already!

-Each colony feels the same. Each sponsor gives a unique bonus, but this is not enough to change the feel of the game. Playing as any of the sponsors feels exactly the same with no appreciable difference in cultures. Each of the sponsors is obviously supposed to represent some faction that controls some large portion of Earth, but aside from the accent of the leader, there is no difference in the look or feel of the resulting colonies these sponsors produce.

-Affinities. First, I like the concept of the affinities: that each group would have a different approach to the alien world on which they landed. That said, I would have preferred to have a system in which I could choose affinity abilities like with ideologies in Brave New World except using these new affinity specific resources instead of culture.

There were some things that I did like:

-Quests. The quest system adds a new level of customizability to the game. After constructing a building, a quest decision is presented to allow the player to choose one of two effects to add to that building. For example, you might be able to add +1 culture or +1 production to all of a certain building for the rest of the game.

-Improved espionage. I like the changes to the espionage system, though this aspect of the game also suffers from feeling a bit unfinished.

-Tech Web. Rather than a linear progression through a tech tree in which you will inevitably end up with all of the technology eventually, the tech web requires more strategic planning as to which direction your colony will take.

These are really fairly minor changes for a full game. It seems as if the developers decided that because Civ 5 already exists and was a big success, that they could get away with minor improvements, change the art, and pass it off as a full game. If this was a brand new franchise, Beyond Earth might have worked as a fresh concept. Civilization fans expect more than a passable game though.

I will probably buy the inevitable expansions and/or DLC, but only when they are on sale; the improvements that are sure to come should have been included in this release and I refuse to pay top dollar for upcoming additions.

I am actually very upset that I spent $50 on this game; if I could get my money back, I would. I will keep this in mind if you somehow manage to make another new Civilization game, Firaxis. Lesson learned... don't preorder because the game won't be finished.

reviewText:
I've played every Civ game including Alpha Centauri.  I'm a pretty big fan of the games in general, but this one is a lame duck in my opinion.   The tech tree is messy and nonsensical, there are no faction specific units or buildings, and the unit progression is lame.  It is in every way significantly less good of a game than Alpha Centauri.  The fluff is boring, the end game is boring, the world interaction is boring.   Even though Alpha Centauri was an alien world,  it was easy to 'understand'.  The tech blurbs were sensible, the 'memoirs' phase of leadership added great fluff, units were awesomely customizable, the tech tree made sense.

Beyond Earth doesn't make much sense, doesn't really seek to appeal to the user.   Building a wonder feels boring.  Resources feel somehow both boring and disconnected.

It is literally like they took the worst parts of Civ 5 and the worst parts of Alpha Centauri and made a game from that.

There are some tiny UI improvements, I guess.

reviewText: If you enjoyed CIV5 and love a sci-fi flavor on the best empire building strategy franchise out there, then I highly recommend you pick this game up. Nevermind the whiners crying about a lack of content, comparing this game to CIV5 + $80 worth of DLC. More content will come, and there is already community submitted content via the Steam Workshop. The new additions to this game from CIV5 are worthy of note, and definitely give the game a flesh of it's own; the covert ops game mechanic alone makes for an interesting addition to the different strategies you can use to achieve victory, the tech tree is an interesting visual interface change from the boring list you had in the previous game, the new quest mechanic is also a nice touch in giving each playthrough a unique feel.  If you are on the fence, I recommend at least trying the demo. I pre-purchased this game, and I have no doubt that it was worth every penny. I really look forward to what else Firaxis has in store for this game. Cheers.

reviewText: I enjoyed Civ V but do not recommend Beyond Earth. This game is an absolute grind from start to finish. When your empire gets large, expect to spend tedious hours micromanaging your trade routes. The planetary environments lack variety, and tiles with toxic miasma can be very hard to distinguish. The aliens are bland and there's little joy to be had in exploration and discovery. The game is simply not very much FUN, and I can't see how updates and patches will change that fundamental problem.

reviewText:
I reccomend this game with heavy reservations.
Having dumped 40+ hours in it, I'd say it definitely is still fun.
I had such a hardon for this game, but I was pretty disappointed in the end. The AI is terrible, I played normal in a massive Domination match, and was never attacked even though I played very aggressively and constantly spat in the face of my opposition, allowing me to slowly plow over the massive map over the course of 600 or so turns with little-to-no retaliation. Even mass-scale assaults were met with maybe 1-2 gun ships buzzing my infantry before being shot down.
The spy system is a bit more advanced the previous ones, but it's the only thing the AI is good at countering, making it almost useless, but I haven't played it against a live person.
The aliens, after you upgrade your infantry to level 3, aren't at all a threat, making clearing them a very, very easy task using a single of the mid-to-late game infantry to plow through them. Though, near the start of the game, the aliens can make expansion and resource aquisition extremely difficult, adding to the fun.
In Civ 5, the barbarians leveled with you, making you constantly need to contend with them in heavier force than they had, but the aliens stay a measely 8-16 strength, and you'll have building defences that prevent combat altogether. The Seige worms (equal to a mid-level unit) are either far too aggressive early on, or not at all, leading to a quick death or a slight irritant.

I enjoy the difference in technology routes, using Xenos as allies through Harmony, staying pure" to humans

This game is poorly optimized, and thinks my drivers are not up to date, and doesn't work on some new high end machines. The quests are the same each time with little variability. I will go back to waiting for the next update to Age of Wonders 3.

reviewText:
It was a YES until 2 hours into the game !!

The wost and main reason for negative review: Extremely hard at medium settings and ridiculously easy in easy mode...

If you are the type of player that needs YouTube statistics experts to find out the perfect game paste and dictate to you what you need to do to be most efficient, then this is the game for you !!

If you want to try out your own strategy, you will play several hours before eventually failing completely and the motivation to replay it will be low, due to a high and significant amount of diverse playing methods and options which most, if you do not watch youtube videos, will end again in failure.


If you are a Civ. vet, get this game. If you played one of the series before and are a casual player that likes to try out his own method, then this is not the game for you.

At standard difficulty, what happens?

- Aliens keep harrassing your base, preventing expansion without conflict
- Military units take up too much of your resources
- You beat aliens in order to expand, needing resources and slowing down your base expansion while meanwhile, all other NPCs prosper.
- After you killed Alien nests, they reappear a few moves later anyway
- Suddenly your base is surrounded by NPC naval forces, while you are struggerling again against alien attacks
- Giganting Worms erradicate big portions of your base
- NPCs all keep prospering....

So, if you want to play it on easy mode but then it is simply ridiculously easy, be my guest, but if you do like a bit of a challenge but with more guaranteed results, then there is no such difficulty for you, as I am sure that experience Civ. players won't find it easy either playing this game on medium difficulty.

I am very frustrated, because this game is so great with so much potential that gets ruined by unfriendly difficulty for new players, in the easiest mode, even a 5 year old can play it left-handed, but where is the difficulty mode that allows new comers to be challenged a bit too, without immediately having to consult youtube what to do and when to do it, basically playing someone else's game?

I hope this review could help. I am glad I got to try this game, and I will have to pass, unfortunately, because it is such a great game if its difficulty settings would make sense.

reviewText:
Beyond Earth continues the recent trend of Firaxis where they create a pretty game, but the AI is so laughingly incompetent unless it gets huge boosts to disguise that. I'd recommend waiting for a free weekend and finding out if you don't mind the real lack of depth once the discovery phase is over. reviewText: Honestly what can I say? There's just so much wrong in this game and most of it has been summed up by the previous reviewers. reviewText: A very poor attempt to another full fledged Civilization game. Beyond Earth misses marks where Civ 5 set them high. Everything in this game is average at best. Instead of feeling like a full game, it seems like a polished mod. I'm sure future mods and dlc will deal with a lot of these problems, but right now it is not nearly worth the $60 price tag (Or even $30 for that matter). The customization and tech trees are lackluster. The available leaders and Civs are uninspiring and downright boring. Even the opening title screen is meh!\n\nI would like to think that this game will get better with time. Right now, there is no telling. I will be saving my money for a discounted complete version of the game. I will highly recommend anyone else to do the same.

reviewText:
I would have liked to enjoy this game. I'm a big fan of the Civilization series, and anything scifi is always a plus in my book. However, this game... Starting off, you have extremely limited options as to where to start your first city, which can seriously set you back in the early game. The science tree or graph or whatever is an absolute mess, nearly unreadable, confusing for old fans of Civ and completely overwhelming for any newcomers. All the tiles look the same (I had to hover over most tiles to figure out what they were), the aliens are absolutely everywhere, stopping your explorers and then randomly killing them for no reason... And the miasma, which could have been interesting, is just far too abundant to be anything but a serious annoyance. The actual civilizations themselves, or the colonies as they were, in addition to being very few in number, are also extremely bland and seem to have practically no differences from each other. The leaders have next to no personality, and all their little log excerpts seem to be dime-a-dozen platitudes about the loss of Earth and the squandering of natural materials - or then destruction of the aliens.

It's such a shame, because this could have been the best game in the entire series with a little development. The basic idea was there, and there were so many ways this could have gone. I would give wads of cash for something more akin to Civ meets Mass Effect, where there's an actual variety of species and planet types. The civ leaders could have actual character, and the aliens, too - why were they not sentient? Why could I not play as them? Why are the aliens so meaningless to the game?

And don't even get me started on the problems with the multiplayer. I got kicked out more times than I can count, and I probably stared at loading screens more than I got actual playtime in. Finally, I had to give up without completing the multiplayer game, because my constant dropping was making it stand still for everyone else. Additionally, the game would occasionally freeze for no reason and force me to restart it to be responsive again. I've never had issues like that with any other game. I don't know if the free weekend was crowding the servers or what, but it was basically unplayable.

Such a shame. I guess I'll have to get my Civ fix and my scifi fix separately, then.

reviewText:
Beyond earth is the next part in the Civilization series.  Where in V, winning  by science, send your people to the stars beyond earth let you pioneer new worlds.

At the start you can choose between a few conglomerates. Unlike V, where the perks are set to a leader, you get to choose them.

When you have played civilisation before you feel at home yet a little disappointed. When you start you see the changes and well they are nice in the beginning. You have a grid as tech exploration which gives you more freedom.
The orders which you could choose in V (after DLC and certain timespan) are replaced by affinities which are there from start. And you have virtues instead of social policies.

The affinities are linked to researching tech and unit upgrades to affinities.

So yeah everything is there and it has a nice ring to it.

Then why the diappointment you might think. Well imo this game has such potential you can only feel sad about the missed opportunities.

The playable factions are just human. Aliens are mere barbarians in this game. The planets you can choose to pioneer are only earthlike planets. You have 3 choices". One with a few large masses (like earth) One with one big landmass and a big ocean with possibilitie of small isles (pangaea) and an island like planet. But none of them have an alien look.
So all the possibiliteis of strange new planets to explore or some weird alien races to play aren't there.

So yeah at the current state and price I simply cannot recommend the game. It has so much more potential but feels more like a mod than a full game.

Will I keep my eye on the game. Definately. With some nice mods it can become a great addition to the civ series."

reviewText: Feels incomplete. I've played and won a few games on higher difficulties and don't feel compelled to play any more. I've been a huge Civ fan since the original and poured hundreds of hours into Civ 5. Civ 5 and some of the predecessors offered complex gameplay that required unique strategies to suit your civilization, starting position and desired victory type. The current version of BE seems monotonous and the same basic strategy can achieve most of the victory conditions. I quickly felt like I was checking off boxes trying to win Steam achievements without really having any fun.\n\nThe game had a lot of promise with the tech web and affinities, and I think it is still possible that I'll enjoy this game one day if they add more content and work on rebalancing. In its current state it isn't recommended.

Cons:

reviewText: I really cannot say I recomend this game, nor would I disrecommend it. It uses the same engine and same diplomacy trade ect ect ect as CIV V. Which is not a bad thing per se. As I understand when Civ V first launched it was not received well but with the additions of DLC it became a much better game. Both good and bad. It is bad because we will have to purchase a 30 dollar DLC to make this a truly great game. I will say however that the other civs were useless. I suppose I am only mostly though my first game but I found little interactions between the other Civs. This is probably due to the lack of luxury resources however. The aliens will be your primary threat as the other civs are rather docile. I am disappointed by the wonders in this game. In Civ V it was something special with music and a picture and a quote. Now its just meh. The affinities are a great new addition and it is neat to see them mix and mingle with how the other civs leaders look. and they provide nice little bonuses as well. According to the affinity you have the highest rating for some civs will love you and others will hate you. Either way this game is very similar to civ V. if you liked civ V than chances are you will like BE as well.

You establish your first base, weak, fearful, and kinda hungry.
You send out explorers, avoiding the miasma, and the aliens, only for them to get surronded by both.
You send out soldiers, only to watch them get slaughtered almost instantly.
You send out trading vehicles, only to watch an alien eat them on the way to a station.
For this is the frontier of humanity, and the rule of the jungle applies here. You eat them, or you get eaten by them.

Late-game is like Civ V, you kill, you conquer.
The usual stuff, just with different units.

Still, good game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText: People like saying that it is bad, but I disagree with that. People like saying that it is a reskin of Civ V, wich I disagree with as well. Beyond Earth has the affinities, the orbital layer, and satellites in general, better spying system (in my opinion), quests, the tech web, new resources which have a large impact on how a game will turn out (i.e. firaxite, floatstone), different units (as opposed to a civilization's special unit in Civ V, the affinity changes more than just a single unit). Aliens might be compared to barbarians, but you can not tame barbarians and have them help fight with you. The multiple special abilities you may pick from is a nice little feature to slightly impact gameplay, the trade system with foreign cities and outposts is good too. And when people say that it is a reskin of Civ V, its a Civ game. Did you want something else? I agree that the colors are dull, but other than that I would say that Civilization: Beyond Earth is a good game.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Great 50 dollar DLC.

What? It's not DLC? You're kidding me, this is like Civ5 with a reskin.

Oh. It turns out this is a full game, which was quite literally a reskin of Civ5 which they couldn't even polish up most of the things that shot that in the foot like bugs, bots, and not to mention an incomplete game. Seriously, Civ5 was like an incomplete game without DLC, and yet it felt more complete than this.

I guess I should say something nice about it, fine, let's see. Uh... Graphics are pretty? Alright, alright, fine. It's semi-interesting and absorbing. The Miasma interested me on paper as a hazard to avoid, but with so much of the ♥♥♥♥ing stuff it just became something really inconvenient. Don't get me started on how clearing out aliens and miasma pisses off bots, what am I supposed to do? Learn to adapt so my lungs don't end up looking worse than after fifty years of smoking? Alright, so the combat is... ... Half-heartedly interesting. Not as absorbing or unique as the last games and your tech web can really stun your ♥♥♥ in place in the dark ages trying to figure out which part of the tech web gives you what you need.

Overall, no. Just no. I felt like it was bad enough in Civ5 they cut out the spies and sold it on DLC, but now this is worse and only making me glad I got it on the free weekend.

reviewText: Its not civ 5, its not alpha centauri. Its Civ2: ToT's space scenario. But redesigned. The tech web I was excited about but is rather clunky in practice. Ive been finding it best to completely as much as I can focus on one of the three affinities. Mixing the techs usually puts you pretty behind, even though its limited benefits to steer off your affinity some of the techs you will really be able to use. Just had my closest to winning game and it was literally through grinding through techs and trying to stay out of war and not expand. War isnt what it used to be. Im so tempted to go back to civ 5 so I can have a grand campaign of a war with multiple civs. The balance issues at this point make the game hard to recommend, Im flying through games with really really low number of cities on bigger maps than civ 5 has given me since the custom maps mod was taken down. I still have yet to really break more than 9 or 10 cities max. One of those times I went to war with a fledgling faction. The units all upgrading at once is kinda fun. But once again theres alot of balance issues with being able to afford the epic units and not fall behind somewhere else. I think I have to step away from it for a while, wait til a patch comes out.

reviewText:
If you enjoy managing large civilizations and snowballing your way to victory this is not the civilization for you.  Everything about this game is balanced to produce smaller civs and increased interactions between civs.  This may be great if you play multiplayer, but for a single player fan like me, it takes away from the experience of leading mankinds first intersteller colonization.  Rather then wanting to climb over that next ridge, see whats there, and then optimize for the best city placement,; I'm forced to race against AI cities that are dropped right next to me.

This game is definetly not an updated version of Alpha Centauri.  Some of the innovations are great, the use of satellites, autoupgrading units, explorer expiditions, and affinities.  But other things are just off, the ability to cross oceans so soon after landing feels wrong.

The tech web is a very mixed bag.  Compared to past Civilization games that had a linear tech tree based on history, it makes perfect sense that in the future you could choose which path to pursue.  The problem with it was that I always felt that there was maybe one or two optimal choices.  Pick wrong and you would fail.  You need health, you need energy, you need better weapons from affinity choices, and you will always feel pulled by the choices.  In past civs there was always some slack with the tech choices.  Rather than techs giving me choices and rewards, I feel tense everytime I open the research window.

The virtue menu is also innovative, it gives you the option to customize your civ.  But everytime i play, it feels like there is only one good tree.  You have to take prosperity, anything else and you will fall behind the AI.  Maybe in multiplayer it would be a different story, but in single player it seems anything else is a waste till you max it out.

The civilopedia is awesome.  This may be the most narrative of all the Civilization games and the fiction inside the civilopedia had me opening the game just to read it.  And that shows a big problem with the game.  I was more interested in reading the civilopedia than playing the game.

reviewText:
Civ BE is too broken to recommend.  It would be less disappointing as a $10 mod and not as a $50 standalone game.
The graphics are generic and drab (every planet is interchangeable), the civs are limited to eight but may as well all be the same (they are essentially interchangeable), the music is innocuous but doesn't raise the tone of the game to personally be invested, and the general balance and pacing of the game is a slog.   Did I mention that the tech/affinity tree is essentially broken because of how poorly it is presented?  Too many troubles to recount for only ~12 hours of play time in.  I have very little interest in finding a reason to play this, but I will give it another dozen or so hours as a courtesy to all the other CIV games before it!

Civ BE should have been so much more.  All I am left with now is wishing I had my money back.

reviewText:
If you've already read other reviews, I'm mostly going to echo some of the same sentiments.

Civilization Beyond Earth really seems to take away a lot of choice that I grew to love (And be extremely frustrated by) in Civ 5.  This game really let's you do whatever you want; and although I enjoy a good sandbox, there just isn't too much decision making here.  You can level up in any given tech direction, affinity, or culture at will.  The only exclusionary forces to how you progress are the minor bonuses you chose to give to your military units.  Every other bonus you can get can just be min/maxed by playing the game longer.  In the end every empire I create comes out to be the same min/maxed plot-of-land expansion as the one I played before, despite all the options given to you in the beginning.    And the end game is just completely unfulfilling.  There's no lead up, or breakdown of the game; not even an option to play just one more turn! It's grayed out for me every time!  It just ends, and unless you're really quick at reading text before the box pops up to tell you it's over, then you may never know.  Yeah, that's right, the text box at the end is the same stock message for every game, with no details concerning who won, or how.

I do really enjoy the level with which you can customize your society, and that the NPC's and cities change in design depending on your affinity, and I will still continue to play this game,  but I don't think I can recommend it as it exists right now.  I guess we'll just have to wait for some DLC.

reviewText:
Firaxis somehow managed to make sci-fi CIV 5 in space boring. This game feels like a poorly thought-out mod. The aliens are brainless and easy, enemy AI might as well not be in the game, environments and graphics are bland, core gamplay is extremely shallow and simply not fun.

Strip away a ton of the complexity of CIV IV or V, tack on a couple of new systems that seem like they have choices but are really just checkbox farms for 3 boring resources and you have this game.

The only thing worth keeping is the new questing system, which is neat, but pointless in the overall scheme of how half-baked this game is.

If you love the CIV games do yourself a favor- wait for this game to be re-made with an expansion or two, or simply pass.

reviewText:
My first ever review...and sadly a negative one. I have been a CIV fan since the first game, which btw was the first PC game I ever bought, somewhere in the 90's. From CIV to CIV 5 I completed 1 game every 10 or 20 because I loved the early game stages...the exploration...the early choices...the first encounters. Then you had to decide which civs to befriend, which to attack, how to specialize your cities, etc.. By the modern age it was clear who was going to win so there I go to a new game, with a different civ and a smile in my face.

I don't know exactly what is the issue with BE but I could not endure more than 4 hrs in the first game and maybe 2 in the second. The tech web is confusing and it is not clear where I am going, the world is colorful yet dull, and I am not sure I am making meaningful choices throughout the game. Everything seems sooooo boring...

Not to mention a very annoying bug which prevents me from playing at low res (1,280 x 720).

Maybe I didn't try long enough but it was the first CIV game I gave up so early, and I played every single one of them. I sure hope Firaxis didn't lose its touch.

reviewText:
Played through it twice on marathon now.  You can see all the potential this game has, and I'm sure we'll get the gaps filled in a similar fashion to Civ 5's G&K/BNW expansions.  For now?
The wonders you can build are freqently tiny improvements (+1 production, +4 culture!)
I can't run this game on my AMD machine.  Same crash I got in Civ 5 Directx 11 mode crashes this game about 10 seconds in to a map.  Yes, the card support DX11.  This game only works with DX 11.
I've had explorers on auto explore kill themselves by pacing back in forth in maisma.  Most of the map was unknown at this point, and the unit simply moved back in forth near a mountain it fancied.
UI is missing some of the better features of Civ 5.  This can be worked around, but I miss being able to spend currency on a unit/building without having to go into the city's screen and toggle over to buying, for example.
Gone are the interesting factions, and a handful of empty shells with small bonus' have taken their place.
Want to beat a non-harmony loving AI?  Drop a miasma spreading satalite on their head and watch them melt.   All I got for dropping the miasma was a sternly worded chat from their leader.  On hard mode.  There's a satalite to clean it all up too.
Give this game some time, and we'll all be looking at hundreds of hours played.  At the moment, Civ 5 is much, much more entertaining.

reviewText:
As much as I would love to reccomend this as it's a great game I simply can't. It feels too much like Civilisation 5 just more confusing. The tech tree is a huge improvement over Civilisation V but along with the affinities feel like the only new things to the series. You may now only play as 8 different civ's which is fine as you can customise them but this means that you can no longer have the large 12+ player games. Another problem is that for the same price you could get Civilisation V + all of the DLC's (Civ V Complete Pack) which is much more completed than this.

I played it for about 4 hours when it went out and haven't played it since due to me just not wanting to play it. Which is the opposite of which Civ V made me want to do!

Finally, the multiplayer is absolutely godawful, worse than Civilisation V awful. In Civ V you could play multiplayer but it was nowhere near stable and with this I've practically given up on trying to play multiplayer at all. Until Firaxis gets their crap together I will have to say that Civilisation: Beyond Earth is no where near worth the money!

tl;dr Civilisation V is better in almost every way

What I'd give Civ V: 8/10

What I give Beyond Earth: 4/10

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth, you want the short reason as to why I wouldn't recomend it? It feels like a re-skin of Civ 5 with to many of the core features pulled out.

The long reason?

reviewText: This game has been on my wishlist since it first came out in October of last year. I'm not a direhard fan of the Civ games, having played Civ IV and Civ V, but I was looking to pick this up, because Civ in space sounded pretty cool. I didn't buy this game right away, because 1) I felt like it was overpriced for what essentially looked liked a Civ V clone, I perhaps would spend $30 on it, but no way was I going to sink $50 into it, and 2) This is Steam, and a new game from a very renowned developer as Firaxis was very likely to go on sale during the winter sale. So the game was released and I waited until Christmas to check it out. I went onto the store page, and noticed that this game got 'mixed' reviews. What? A game with the Sid Meier's Civilization name not getting at least above average reviews? I was skeptical about the reviews, but ultimately decided to hold onto my money. And then, to put the final nail in the coffin, the free weekend rolled around. I could finally try this game out for myself before deciding if I wanted to buy it. I no longer regret my decision to hold onto my money. This game is unfortunately a reskinned Civ V, with pretty much every good feature of it dumbed down. AI personalities are boring, the tech tree was interesting, but confusing and eventually just became a game of research the technologies that will get you affinity points". There was hardly any intro or help when starting the game

reviewText:
Overall, I'm pretty bummed that this game wasn't very fun/good.  I can't really recommend this to anyone because Civ 5 pretty much did everything this game does, but better (two exceptions being the tech tree, maybe, and then I liked the virtue system from what I played anyway).  The opening intro for the game is pretty sweet, though.

Admittedly I don't have much time in this game (I only played during the free weekend, and even that was only ~5 hours, because that's all I could stomach - and I have almost 700 hours in Civ 5, 230 hours in Endless Space, 1600 hours in EU4, etc), but I don't think I would pay more than $10 for this game - and even then I would have some hesitance.  Calling this game a mod may have been somewhat generous, as it's more like a watered down reskin.

The UI is pretty much horrible; they removed the demographics stats portion entirely; they literally just renamed the mechanics and changed the icons (happiness is now health, money is now energy); you just build the base unit of each unit type, which is then upgraded (automatically) to the next one that you pick when you raise your affinity (which is pretty much only raised based on what you learn in the tech tree); the alien mechanic is kind of weird(?), you can not attack aliens and do the Harmony affinity, but they still occasionally attack you and ruin your trade routes, so it's just best to kill them all anyway apparently; the diplomacy options are all copy and pasted from Civ 5 (except for earning favors I guess now, which it wasn't exactly clear how that actually works out in practice); and the whole premise for the game, mankind embarking off into space for their salvation...only to battle against each other and repeat exactly what they did on earth that they were trying to escape/fix - sure, I guess.

The only two somewhat redeeming parts of this game are the tech tree and the virtue system, of which I'm still undecided on the tech tree since it's seemingly not really organized any way specifically and different techs and affinities are strewn about throughout; but the virtue system is pretty cool, I like it (at least what I played of it so far anyway).

With all the space themed stuff and technological advances, it really just made me want to play Endless Space or Galactic Civilizations III. I wanted to like this game, but I'm not even sure expansions could save it without overhauling the UI and adding a little more depth. Not to mention there's no portraits for any of the pictures for units and buildings, just words and icons. The only other thing that was kind of cool was that cities start out at level 0 and have to gain enough influence to become a full-fledged city.

Also, for some reason, you see where the computers all start, for basically no reason whatsoever. Oh, and did I mention that Stations (the city-state equivalents that only work with a trade route now) just randomly spawn places? Like when you're ~2 turns away from settling that area with a colonist on the way down? Basically my reaction to the game as a whole, but specifically when that occured:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AjZuGas6yRQ

reviewText:
As much as I would love to reccomend this as it's a great game I simply can't. It feels too much like Civilisation 5 just more confusing. The tech tree is a huge improvement over Civilisation V but along with the affinities feel like the only new things to the series. You may now only play as 8 different civ's which is fine as you can customise them but this means that you can no longer have the large 12+ player games. Another problem is that for the same price you could get Civilisation V + all of the DLC's (Civ V Complete Pack) which is much more completed than this.

I played it for about 4 hours when it went out and haven't played it since due to me just not wanting to play it. Which is the opposite of which Civ V made me want to do!

Finally, the multiplayer is absolutely godawful, worse than Civilisation V awful. In Civ V you could play multiplayer but it was nowhere near stable and with this I've practically given up on trying to play multiplayer at all. Until Firaxis gets their crap together I will have to say that Civilisation: Beyond Earth is no where near worth the money!

tl;dr Civilisation V is better in almost every way

What I'd give Civ V: 8/10

What I give Beyond Earth: 4/10

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Civ BE is too broken to recommend.  It would be less disappointing as a $10 mod and not as a $50 standalone game.
The graphics are generic and drab (every planet is interchangeable), the civs are limited to eight but may as well all be the same (they are essentially interchangeable), the music is innocuous but doesn't raise the tone of the game to personally be invested, and the general balance and pacing of the game is a slog.   Did I mention that the tech/affinity tree is essentially broken because of how poorly it is presented?  Too many troubles to recount for only ~12 hours of play time in.  I have very little interest in finding a reason to play this, but I will give it another dozen or so hours as a courtesy to all the other CIV games before it!

Civ BE should have been so much more.  All I am left with now is wishing I had my money back.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you've already read other reviews, I'm mostly going to echo some of the same sentiments.

Civilization Beyond Earth really seems to take away a lot of choice that I grew to love (And be extremely frustrated by) in Civ 5.  This game really let's you do whatever you want; and although I enjoy a good sandbox, there just isn't too much decision making here.  You can level up in any given tech direction, affinity, or culture at will.  The only exclusionary forces to how you progress are the minor bonuses you chose to give to your military units.  Every other bonus you can get can just be min/maxed by playing the game longer.  In the end every empire I create comes out to be the same min/maxed plot-of-land expansion as the one I played before, despite all the options given to you in the beginning.    And the end game is just completely unfulfilling.  There's no lead up, or breakdown of the game; not even an option to play just one more turn! It's grayed out for me every time!  It just ends, and unless you're really quick at reading text before the box pops up to tell you it's over, then you may never know.  Yeah, that's right, the text box at the end is the same stock message for every game, with no details concerning who won, or how.

I do really enjoy the level with which you can customize your society, and that the NPC's and cities change in design depending on your affinity, and I will still continue to play this game,  but I don't think I can recommend it as it exists right now.  I guess we'll just have to wait for some DLC.

reviewText:
Firaxis somehow managed to make sci-fi CIV 5 in space boring. This game feels like a poorly thought-out mod. The aliens are brainless and easy, enemy AI might as well not be in the game, environments and graphics are bland, core gamplay is extremely shallow and simply not fun.

Strip away a ton of the complexity of CIV IV or V, tack on a couple of new systems that seem like they have choices but are really just checkbox farms for 3 boring resources and you have this game.

The only thing worth keeping is the new questing system, which is neat, but pointless in the overall scheme of how half-baked this game is.

If you love the CIV games do yourself a favor- wait for this game to be re-made with an expansion or two, or simply pass.

reviewText: If you are looking for a continuation in the legendary Civilization Series. Turn away, this isn't it. Not to say it's inherently bad, but it just isn't Civ. I absolutely love Civ V and while Beyond Earth does scratch the Civ itch a bit, it brings a different experience to the table. Yes, the gameplay is shockingly similar to that of Civ 5, but what it brings new is wonderful. An overhaul of the previously named Culture and Social Policies" is now streamlined and way more useful. New "quests" and major decisions have to be made that influence your "civ" one way or antother- one of my favorite aspects. And finally

reviewText: A fresh look at the Civilization formula, with great aspects of the old with lots of new and exciting fetures to distiguish it as a unique game, rather than a parasite on the success of the franchise. it seems lacking at the moment, but it is the same feeling as playing civ 5 without Brave New World, and has just as much potential with future expansions. It comes with a more personal gameplay experience, alowing a degree of cousomization to your army, and quests that shape you future based on your own decisions. This is a game hat deserves to be under the Civilization banner.\nRising tide is a step in the right direction, adding more unique aspects, and expanding existing ones. I love ocean cities, hybrid affinities and new units. the game feels more fleshed out now, but it still has ways to go. The update is like gods and kings for Civ 5, it's good, but BNW is around the corner. i would not reomend playing without the expansion, because the base is undeniably lacking.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri that aims to be different yet familiar to those who had played the venerable Civ-in-space from decades ago. Unfortunately, it falls short of reaching the same excellence of AC let alone surpassing it. Although it has some great graphics (based on the Civ V engine) and uses almost similar mechanics from Civ V, albeit with differences to depict its futuristic setting, the Civ:BE at times feels shallow and seem to lack the depth and engagement of other Civ titles.

An expansion entitled Rising Tide is suppose to improve upon the base game and it is hope that the new content will be able to lift the game from mediocre to awesome. Despite its flaws (other reviewers have already pointed them out so I won't repeat it here), Civ:BE still has potential. It is hoped that Firaxis will continue to support the game by releasing more content that not only improves gameplay but also establish it as a standalone but excellent title that inherits AC's DNA without replicating it.

In short, it is a recommended purchase for those interested in sci-fi themed colony building sims. However, I would only get it during sales as the current status of the game does not warrant its full price.

reviewText: If you like turn based games, you are going to like Civ: Beyond Earth. It has the best and most fun elements of Age of Empires and Risk and that in a neat looking futuristic theme. There are a lot of diferent and complex, yet coherent mechanics which are explained very well in the early game. For instance, you have the questing system, which explains you how you should play the game but at the same moment it is an important mechanic that you'll keep on using as the game progresses. You can play against the AI with advanced diplomatic options (at first I thought that I was playing against real humans, so there's that :P), but it is even more fun when playing against your friends.\nI dare you, play a hundred turns and try to not get addicted. I bet you can't :D

reviewText: My first review\nThis game stand alone is phenomenal. I do have some complaints, but none are necessarily game breaking. For example, the buildings in your cities are very forgettable and many seem useless. This was a similar issue in civ v though, with the useless buildings. So what it usually turns into each game for me, is a plan my affinity ahead of time, don't attack the aliens, only research things for my affinity, and only build free buildings since money is so hard to make in this game. Also, I'm still unsure how healthiness even works, but it's still by far much better than happiness from civ v. Not the best civ game, but coming from an owner of every civ game, this is still extremely fun. On a personal note, I always try to roleplay when I play civ, and when I get late game, I hate how it stops on future tech. If someone made a game merge system between civ v and BE, it would be so cool to pcikup late game and work on military space ships.

reviewText:
I payed this game through once and I can honestly see this replacing Civ 5 for me. I get that there is some hate for it. It falls short a bit and it might feel a little bit light on features but a does a lot of things right for me.

1. Barbarians are interesting this time (and are alien lifeforms)
2. Lots of interesting and unique paths toward victory and victory objectives
3. Clean and sexy UI
4. Spying is now AWESOME and easy
5. Trade routes make more sense
6. Really interesting and creatively redesigned tech tree
7. Deeper diplomacy than in Civ 5
8. The best core gameplay features from Civ 5 are all still here
9. Impressive customization options at the start of each game
10. Everything is just much deeper and better designed than in Civ 5 at this point.

The criticisms people have for the game tend to be that it was buggy (now it's not), it was expensive (I just bought it at half-price), it wasn't as fully featured as Civ 5 is with all its DLC (but BE has DLC coming in a few months and Civ 5 was awfully disappointing before DLC came out), and it pales in comparison to Alpha Centauri (I just didn't find that to be true). I think they may have polished things up and improved things greatly since release because it just doesn't deserve the crappy to lukewarm reviews it has been getting. It's a solid game.

I hope they give Colonization the Civ 5 engine treatment next!

reviewText: Excellent Game. I have around 40hrs offline on it at least. 100% Fun I read many of the reviews and was worried about this game being full of bugs. Personally its worked GREAT! OVERALL despite a few minor tweaks I'd like to see in this game and others GREAT JOB FRAXIS Please create more Colonies Or another affinity New Aliens would Rock also. Great balance Don't screw that up with DLC thanks again

reviewText:
Buy this game when on sale with DLCs included. This game has a lot of potential, but is underdeveloped. It could be a nice Civ game with a kick-♥♥♥ story line, but still not there, especially with the latter.

Gameplay: Affinities are well integrated into all aspects of gameplay. The tech web is a fresh addition to a system that has been practically unchanged since Civ2. Aliens are kinda cool, but need more depth. You now choose the upgrades of your units.

Biggest problem (edit:is now corrected) - AI does not react to the new concepts, making the game incredibly easy as of now.

AI will ignore affinity techs until late game, meaning you just need to do two quests, get lvl 3 of random affinity and crush the entire map with upgraded units. The fact you get free upgrade to all units immediately after it is available also contributes, but AI is the bigger problem.

Like in all CIv games, AI doesn't really care about your victory progress, it pursues only its objectives. This is still valid here: you can go on a domination streak, the other Civs will not rally against you. You can place a Mind Flower smack on the border with a Purity Civ, they will ignore it. Considering that 3/5 victory types in this game are to build and hold a planetary wonder, this has to change.

For the first time in Civ game health (hapiness) is simply a nuissance. March through the map, -45 health, who cares?

Story: Again affinities. Everything revolves around who you choose to be. Storyline-wise, these three choices feel very logical and distinct, as they are core in everything Sci-Fi. The sponsors' and leaders' background has integrity. There are a lot of flaws in the details, however.

Most of Civilopedia is nonsence (Memetwork" - 9gag is now a world wonder). Half the technologies feel like you are researching the same thing
date: too much random meaningless words thrown in. Unit upgrades lack description. Orbital stations lack description. What the hell is this Great Mistake?"

reviewText:
Friend tells me how Beyond Earth is a super cool space age RTS game. (Never played a civ game before)

Decide between Grey Goo and Beyond Earth without researching either.

Beyond Earth has cooler artwork.

Choose Beyond Earth.

Start a game on normal.

Damn it Anderson, this isn't an RTS....

Cry a little bit.

Start as Brassilia, spam spess mahreens and combat rovers along with some other randon stuff.

Now im at -7 energy per turn, okay....

Cry some more.

Ohh look another player just landed with no defenses, lets go kill them and take their base.

Send spess mahreens, and combat rovers to the helpless" enemy base.

Watch in total awe as my many units got utterly obliterated.

Now im stuck with no units and -7 energy per turn.

Unistall.

10/10 would attack that base again"

reviewText: If you are looking for a continuation in the legendary Civilization Series. Turn away, this isn't it. Not to say it's inherently bad, but it just isn't Civ. I absolutely love Civ V and while Beyond Earth does scratch the Civ itch a bit, it brings a different experience to the table. Yes, the gameplay is shockingly similar to that of Civ 5, but what it brings new is wonderful. An overhaul of the previously named Culture and Social Policies" is now streamlined and way more useful. New "quests" and major decisions have to be made that influence your "civ" one way or antother- one of my favorite aspects. And finally

reviewText: A fresh look at the Civilization formula, with great aspects of the old with lots of new and exciting fetures to distiguish it as a unique game, rather than a parasite on the success of the franchise. it seems lacking at the moment, but it is the same feeling as playing civ 5 without Brave New World, and has just as much potential with future expansions. It comes with a more personal gameplay experience, alowing a degree of cousomization to your army, and quests that shape you future based on your own decisions. This is a game hat deserves to be under the Civilization banner.\nRising tide is a step in the right direction, adding more unique aspects, and expanding existing ones. I love ocean cities, hybrid affinities and new units. the game feels more fleshed out now, but it still has ways to go. The update is like gods and kings for Civ 5, it's good, but BNW is around the corner. i would not reomend playing without the expansion, because the base is undeniably lacking.

reviewText:
Friend tells me how Beyond Earth is a super cool space age RTS game. (Never played a civ game before)

Decide between Grey Goo and Beyond Earth without researching either.

Beyond Earth has cooler artwork.

Choose Beyond Earth.

Start a game on normal.

Damn it Anderson, this isn't an RTS....

Cry a little bit.

Start as Brassilia, spam spess mahreens and combat rovers along with some other randon stuff.

Now im at -7 energy per turn, okay....

Cry some more.

Ohh look another player just landed with no defenses, lets go kill them and take their base.

Send spess mahreens, and combat rovers to the helpless" enemy base.

Watch in total awe as my many units got utterly obliterated.

Now im stuck with no units and -7 energy per turn.

Unistall.

10/10 would attack that base again"

reviewText:
When Civilization 5 was first released, it was unfinished and--obviously--lacking in polish. It wasn't until its DLCs released that it became a solid title.

Beyond Earth, at its release, is unifinished and lacking in polish.

I have no doubt that BE will become a solid title once it's polished up (via DLCs, I'm sure). At that point, it'll be worth buying. Until then, it's a nice beta release.

- edit - 07/24/2015 -edit-

Still a down-vote. It's a neat title with lots of possibility--but the diplomacy is still weak, and the game is still lacking in character or soul or personality. The devs have, themselves, admitted to this, and I think this is one of the things that will be DLCed up in the coming months.

On a more interesting note, I find it neat that a large number of the wonders had to be rebalanced to simply be considered useful. Just speaks to how not-ready this title was for release.

In any case, DLC will be out in a bit. I'll probably Day 1 Download because, hey, why not.

reviewText:
A very deep and thought provoking 4X...if only for a few hours. Only can recommend for those who are very hardcore Civilization fans and are willing to shell out $50 for about as much content as Civ 5 had at release.
Pros and Cons further down, TL:DR version here.
DO NOT purchase this game if you have not played Civilization V with all the DLC and are looking for a good Strategy game. You can get Civilization V Complete for the same price as this and have hundreds of hundreds of hours of content between the DLC and the Workshop. I only recommend this for the very hardcore Civilization fans who can deal with not amount of content. Firaxis always has expansions to their games now, so I would wait until the first expansion is out to consider this game, if you're in need of a new 4X play Age of Wonders 3 or Endless Legend, you can even go old school and kick it with Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.
If you have $50 to spend then go for it. This is a really good game and it shows, but the lack of content will leave you wanting more and the price tag is not enough for me to recommend it to anyone but the most fanatical Civ fans.


Pros:
+ Deep and thought provoking narritive into the victories and how you advance as a civilization. Augmenting yourself with technology or becoming more alien, or rejecting the two.
+ Huge UI improvements, everything is much neater than Civilization V, no more right-clicking through 200 Citystate messages and quests.
+ Non-Linear technology web, allows players to plan and use more strategy in their game.
+ Steam Workshop Support
+ Builds off the Civilization V engine, allowing newcomers to feel welcome and experts to jump right into the game and expierence the new features themselves.
+ Revamped policy system,  lots of bonuses and extra goodies allowing for a much better time for those who don't rake in loads of culture, while rewarding those who do.

Cons:
- Lack of content is HUGE in this game, especially coming off the wealth of content Civilization V with all the DLC had. Games take nowhere near as long as in Civ V. You will find yourself out of things to build reletively quickly, not many buildings and units.
- Maps are reletively small and barren, there aren't any landmarks to discover and there aren't enough Civilizations to have a large map akin to Earth like in Civilization V, there's no real thrill to exploring, just getting slaughtered by aliens.
- Diplomacy is non-existent. It's just like how it was in Civilization V, but doesn't take intol account the futuristic setting very well. Trading resources means nothing because you don't need any (besides oil), the ones you need are granted to you by developing affinities, and they do not do anything for your people (no happiness increase, no city-state quests to fufill, no we love the king day)
- AI is brain dead. Every game I've played the AI doesn't go for a victory other than Domination. They end up warring with each other eternally, attacking aliens (attacking aliens make every alien on the map more hostile to any civilization) and just having so many units that they lose hundreds of energy (currency) per turn.
- Barely any buildings to make, no units either.
- No Great People, even Generals and Admirals.
- Games take a short amount of time, even on Normal and Epic times due to the ease to achieve victory and lack of other content.

I'd give it about an average score, 6/10. What's there works well and blends nicely into the game, it runs very well and everything looks gorgeous. But it's not enough to keep your attention for more than a little bit at a time (you can obviously tell from my playtime. I have ten times this on Civ 5.) Wait until more expansions come out and the price drops. This game is NOT worth $50. It's worth $20.
